debateinfo.title: HORTICULTURE MARKETING AND RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The purpose of this bill and the accompanying Repeals and Consequential Provisions Bill is to create a new horticultural services company.

The new company will be formed when the assets, liabilities and staff of the existing Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC) are transferred to the new company. A trust is also to be established to hold the reserves of the Australian Dried Fruits Board, which is to be abolished under the legislation.
The formation of the new company has strong industry support and is the culmination of over two years of hard work by the industry in partnership with the government.

The proposal for the new company began with the green paper in February 1999, when the Horticultural Industry Alliance Steering Committee examined the options for a new corporate framework for horticulture service delivery. The aim is to deliver better industry ownership and involvement in marketing and research and development for the horticulture industries and to allow the synergies between marketing and research and development programs to be fully exploited by the industry.

Following widespread consultation with industry, a white paper was prepared recommending a new blueprint for industry service delivery involving the establishment of a single company operating under Corporations Law to replace the AHC and the HRDC. It was estimated that moving to a single horticulture services company would provide approximately $0.5 million annual savings in administration when the company is fully operational.

The industry, supported by the government, considered in detail how the company might best be set up and run, given the current 25 levy paying sectors and voluntary contributors to the existing corporations and the possibility this number might expand under company operations.

The model embraced by industry, and supported by the government in this legislation, involves industry representative bodies owning the company through its membership and providing for individuals or other bodies to contribute funds for marketing and research and development.

Each industry body or others contributing funds to the company, through the statutory levies or by voluntary contributions, will hold voting rights in the company in proportion to the level of funds they contribute.
Funds of approximately $2 million are to be held in a dried fruits trust which will be accessible to the dried fruits industry for marketing programs.

Levy payers will have the opportunity to consider the investment plans developed by an industry advisory committee at an annual levy payers meeting. The company will then arrange the most cost-effective delivery of these marketing and/or research and development plans.

The company will receive the assets, liabilities and staff of the two existing corporations. Net assets to be transferred are valued at $20 million and primarily comprise industry moneys held on behalf of the horticulture industry sectors for marketing and research and development programs.
In order to provide for continuity of programs and staffing from the AHC and the HRDC, all staff and their entitlements are being transferred to the new company.

The role of the company will be to provide marketing and research and development services to industry and to administer export control powers currently held by the AHC. The government will continue to match research and development funds provided by the horticulture industries up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production, as applies to other rural industries. In 1998-99, the government matching for horticulture research and development was $15.2 million.
The legislation provides for the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to declare the company to be the industry services body and the export control body, if certain conditions are met.

These conditions include the requirement that the company be limited by guarantee, have an appropriate constitution that recognises the industry and public accountability role of the company and that the company has signed a deed of agreement with the government to fulfil these industry and public accountability requirements.

If the company changes its constitution in a manner considered unacceptable to the government, becomes insolvent, or fails to comply with the legislation or the deed of agreement, the legislation provides for the government to retain the right to declare another body as the industry services body or the export control body or to retransfer the assets and liabilities to another suitable body.
These safeguards have been provided in the legislation to ensure the company delivers what the industry and the government expect of it.

The government will also allow the new company to administer export control powers in a specific market, for a specific product, where it can be shown that the arrangement is beneficial to both the industry and the nation.

The most notable current use of export control powers relates to the export of oranges to the USA, where Australian growers have been able to earn price premiums from the export of quality fruit that meets the USA import quarantine requirements. Since 1991, when the trade began, exports to the USA have grown to over $40 million per annum.
The company will be able to issue export licences and continue to use the current export control powers for a further two years, where these have already been approved by the AHC.
After two years, the further use of export control powers will require a new five-step process to be followed by industry and the company.

This involves preparation of a case by the industry, extensive consultation with industry and final approval of the export control by the Secretary to the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA). This new five-step process also includes the preparation of a regulation impact statement by AFFA to ensure the proposed use of the powers complies with national competition principles.

The company's ongoing use of the powers will be subject to conditions set out in the deed of agreement and to Administrative Appeal Tribunal review to ensure exporters are fully informed of the use of export control powers.
The new company arrangements are expected to deliver significant benefits to the horticulture industries. These include:
· design and delivery of research and development and marketing services would be integrated into one company, to allow the provision of `market driven' research and development programs,
· afford industries the flexibility to determine the arrangements that best address their individual circumstances,
· generate streamlined and focussed industry programs that have the capacity to realise synergies between research and development and marketing,
· harness the expertise of other members of the horticultural supply chain, where appropriate,
· and promote commercial innovation at the farm business level through providing programs that complement the activities of individual growers.
The bill is strongly supported by the horticulture industry, which is to be commended for its efforts in bringing this initiative to fruition—in partnership with the government.

About 28 separate horticulture industries are party to this agreement. It represents the beginning of a new era for the industry. I compliment the leaders of the industry for their foresight, and also Senator Judith Troeth, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, for the way in which they have worked through the complex issues which have culminated in this legislation being brought before the House today. I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Lawrence) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: HORTICULTURE MARKETING AND RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill accompanies the Horticulture Marketing and Research and Development Services Bill 2000.
The purpose of this bill is to provide for:

· the transfer of assets, liabilities and staff of the two existing corporations, the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC), to the new horticulture services company
· to protect existing staff entitlements in the transfer
· the flow of statutory levy and matching R&D funds to the new company
· the transition period for the use of export control powers of the AHC
· provide for a trust to hold Australian dried fruit industry reserves
· completion arrangements for final annual reports of the two corporations
· the regulation making powers under the act
· repeal and consequential provisions for other acts, including abolishing the AHC, the HRDC and the Australian Dried Fruits Board.
These arrangements are necessary to establish the new company and provide for the legislative arrangements to apply in the future.
The act also provides for the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to declare the transfer day for the new company and for notice of this to be published in the Gazette within 14 days.

The AHC and HRDC are required to assist the establishment of the new company and the act provides for the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to issue written directions to this effect as needed.

All assets, liabilities and staff are to be transferred to the new company, with the exception of an amount of $2 million of dried fruits industry reserves, which is to be held in a dried fruits trust for future industry marketing programs.
These reserves have been built up over many years and the dried fruits industry have requested that a trust be established to allow for industry control of these reserves in the future.
The transfer of assets to the new company are to be exempt from stamp duty and other state taxes in order to preserve industry funds.
The bill also provides for the repeal of the AHC Act and the HRDC Act and the consequential amendments to other acts as a consequence of this. I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Lawrence) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT (AUSTRALIAN WORKPLACE AGREEMENTS PROCEDURES) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 4 October, on motion by Mr Reith:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —To add to my comments from yesterday evening, the thrust of what I said then was how disappointing and how disconcerting I think it is for fair-minded Australians that we have replaced a system of rational consideration of industrial matters on the basis of equity and fairness by an impartial adjudicator with a law of the jungle situation where parties to an industrial relationship are being compelled to determine outcomes on the basis of sheer might—either economic might or industrial might. Logic and reason that have been the history of Australian industrial relations for the last 100 years have been dismantled by this government. That really is a tragedy and completely short-sighted because there will be many instances where it will not be the employer that has the economic might over employees but, in the short-term future and in the long-term future, employees will be in industries that have the upper hand because of labour shortages or pressures of deadlines, whatever they might be. So having outcomes determined on the basis of those practices of intimidation either because of economic strength or because of sheer, brute, industrial might is equally reprehensible to fair-minded Australians.

speech.para: What is concerning is that this whole process of Australian workplace agreements is unquestionably being used as a counter-negotiating tactic by employers to reduce collective negotiation. Logic says that a worker, particularly in a situation where that worker does not have special skills or qualifications, will be at a significant disadvantage to an employer in a negotiating situation. There is no doubt that history has proven time and again that the only way that workers in those vulnerable positions are able to retain or indeed improve their conditions is through collective action. We have seen recent examples being reported. For instance, in a recent decision of Justice Ryan in the Federal Court involving the Burnie Port Corporation in Tasmania, he found:

quote.para: ... it is clear that the corporation was concerned to render the [enterprise bargaining agreement] inapplicable to port operatives and cold-store operators in order to bring down the wages and working conditions of the corporation's employees in those classifications.

speech.para: In other words, the corporation was insisting that new employees sign Australian workplace agreements rather than rely on a form of collective agreement that had applied to one employee whose employment application it rejected. As I mentioned last night, in an ongoing dispute between the Commonwealth Bank and the Finance Sector Union, in the Federal Court just last week Justice Finkelstein made similar findings, at least in the context of an application for an interim injunction against the bank. Justice Finkelstein said in the course of the case:

quote.para: It would be wrong for me to do otherwise than to find a sufficiently arguable case that the bank sought to coerce the union to enter into new enterprise bargaining agreements to replace those whose nominal expiry had passed.
And the means by which the bank hoped to bring this about was to induce its employees to leave the union by offering them Australian Workplace Agreements.

speech.para: This has been happening in Australia in the last couple of months—indeed in the last week. The significance of Australian workplace agreements is, firstly, that they are being used to undermine the collective bargaining process and, secondly, that they are being used as a means of driving down terms and conditions of employment. It is a matter of great regret in this country that instead of talking about how we can enhance productivity through greater communication between employers and their employees, and indeed encourage employee participation in decision making, we are looking at a situation where employers are being compelled as part of competing with each other to try to drive down terms and conditions of employment. Indeed, often those pressures to drive down terms and conditions are being motivated more on the basis of rumour than fact because Australian workplace agreements are by legislation secret documents, so there is fear or apprehension building within industries where one competitor says, `Well, my competitor has just entered into Australian workplace agreements', and the rumour as to what conditions have been cut forces them to try and up the ante or, more precisely, further reduce terms and conditions.

Australians are people of commonsense. They are aware of the inequality inherent in the employment relationship in terms of bargaining power, especially if they do not have special skills or qualifications. It is not as if we do not have experience to look at. What this government is proposing is not all that new. We saw similar legislation in Queensland under the Bjelke-Petersen government. We saw similar legislation in New South Wales under the Greiner government. The Australian people know that such catchcries as `mutual consent' and `employee choice' are a lie. They know the reality of an individual worker going into the boardroom, sitting down at the table, more likely than not to confront the general manager, the personnel officer and an accountant, yet they are expected to enter into a genuine negotiation. Ordinary Australians know that it is a farce. Hence the reason that there needs to be accountability. If we are going to have Australian workplace agreements, there needs to be an impartial, fair and indeed thorough process to vet those agreements to ensure that workers are not being exploited by the inequality inherent in that relationship. Any fair-minded person must recognise that inequality. This is where we are concerned about the government's amendments.

The government is proposing to apply a $68,000 cap, after which there is no consideration of the no disadvantage test at all. That is an arbitrary figure, and $68,000—and that includes superannuation and other bonuses—is not an inordinate amount of money for ordinary Australian working families. Indeed, if only one party is working, that would be the bare minimum to sustain a mortgage in one of the capital cities these days.

The procedures to allow AWAs to operate even before being approved by the Employment Advocate is a recipe for exploitation. Moreover, it is going to increase the pressure on the Employment Advocate to approve agreements by the mere fact that evidence will be given to him that the agreements are already up and running and the consequences of him then subsequently rejecting those would mean that there would be a claim for arrears of wages.

The fact that the role of the Employment Advocate has been enhanced so that the Employment Advocate will be given a greater role in determining the no disadvantage test has been acknowledged by representatives of the department as a further diminution in the powers of the independent umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That is of concern. The fact that the approval process will enable the Employment Advocate to cut corners is also of concern.

The fact that AWAs, if this legislation is approved, will override collective agreements is of great concern. Perhaps one of the most concerning aspects of this bill is the fact that the Employment Advocate will virtually have the discretion as to whether he will permit continuity of terms and conditions of employment in situations of contracting out, outsourcing or transmission of business. If there can be anything more concerning to the security of employment of ordinary Australian workers, it is that prospect, if not the prospect of losing their jobs. There is no doubt that this legislation, if approved, will enable employers to significantly undermine and undercut the terms and conditions of employment of ordinary Australian workers and their families. We oppose the government's legislation.

talk.start.para: —This has been a broad ranging debate in which all aspects of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Workplace Agreements Procedures) Bill 2000 have been canvassed. I intend in my contribution to focus on two aspects of the bill. The first is the change that this bill makes to the role and responsibilities of the Employment Advocate and the second is the change that this bill makes to the transmission of business provision relating to Australian workplace agreements, and that is contained in section 170VDD of this bill.

speech.para: Firstly, to assess the role and responsibilities of the Employment Advocate, I think we need to go back to first principles and have a look at what the Employment Advocate does as opposed to what the Australian Industrial Relations Commission does—in particular, how the Employment Advocate functions as opposed to how the commission functions. When we have a look at that I think the differences are clear. The commission is an independent arbitral tribunal, an independent umpire, to which appointments are made from those with industrial relations expertise. They may have gained that expertise by working for employer organisations. They may have gained it from working for trade unions. They may have gained it from being involved in the legal profession in relation to industrial relations or they may be human resource professionals. The commission accords natural justice in its proceedings and acts in what could be loosely termed a judicial manner. Parties with an interest in proceedings get to appear and put their case. The proceedings are generally public, and decisions are publicly available and capable of appeal.

Contrast the independent umpire with the Employment Advocate. The Employment Advocate is one person appointed by the government. If that person has an employer bias, there is no ability to balance that with other appointments. Equally, if that person had a trade union bias, there would be no ability to balance that with other appointments. The work of the Employment Advocate is not open and it is not transparent. You cannot just go and watch the Employment Advocate making decisions in the way that you can wander around the various commissions in Australia—Nauru House in Melbourne—and sit in and watch commission proceedings. You simply cannot do that with the Employment Advocate. The Employment Advocate does not have these open proceedings and you cannot see justice, if you like, being seen to be done in relation to the workings of the Employment Advocate.

Indeed, I think the Office of the Employment Advocate can be described as a highly secretive outfit. I have had a look on their web site and some of the protocols by which they work would do a secret service organisation proud. I am not sure what they use for training videos in the Office of the Employment Advocate. One has a suspicion that they might use old James Bond movies. When you look on the web site of the Employment Advocate under a curiously headed section entitled `Research', it makes very clear to all of us just how secretive this organisation is. If you want to go to the Employment Advocate and have a look at Australian workplace agreements and you want to do that for a research purpose, these are the terms and conditions put in front of you. The web site says:

quote.para: Researchers can apply to the Employment Advocate for access copies of approved AWAs for research.

speech.para: So they are not going to show you presumably all of the AWAs; they might show you some of them. It goes on:

quote.para: To be eligible for access to the AWAs, researchers have had to demonstrate their bona fides and academic credentials, and satisfy probity and security requirements.

speech.para: So presumably someone goes and gets your ASIO file and makes sure that you have never had any contact with a left-wing organisation or something like that. You might fail the security test if you have. It goes on:

quote.para: All researchers who are authorised are subject to confidentiality restrictions and penalties similar to those applying to the Employment Advocate's staff. Researchers are not permitted to contact the AWA parties.

speech.para: One wonders how one would research the question of duress applied to workers to sign AWAs without being able to contact the parties, but then perhaps the Employment Advocate and this government do not want matters like that investigated. It goes on:

quote.para: The Employment Advocate has determined that unions and employer associations are not suitable researchers under this program.

speech.para: So every trade union official and everybody who works for an employer organisation must be a security risk or must not satisfy the Employment Advocate's view of probity. I am sure there are people working in employer associations and trade unions all over Australia who would be a little surprised that that judgment has been made about them, but the Employment Advocate apparently knows, without speaking to any of them, that they are not suitable researchers under this program. It goes on:

quote.para: Importantly, only approved AWAs are available under the access program. Correspondence between AWA parties and the Employment Advocate, and documents showing the Employment Advocate's assessment of AWAs and the reasons for decision will not be accessible under this program.

speech.para: As we would be well aware, the essence of the commission's proceedings is that it publicly makes available its reasons for decision. You can go and watch decisions being made. The reasons for decisions are published. You can pull them off the web, and you can get them in hard copy from the commission. Not so with the Employment Advocate—absolutely not. You must not have them. The Employment Advocate really seem to think they are a branch of MI5 rather than anything else. It seems to me axiomatic, having had a look at how they function, that we would not want the Employment Advocate to supplant any of the functions of the commission. You simply would not want to do that. You would not want to substitute secrecy for transparency. Yet that is precisely what this bill does in relation to Australian workplace agreements.

In section 170VCB of this bill, we find the Employment Advocate is made the ultimate decision maker in relation to whether or not an Australian workplace agreement passes the no disadvantage test—that is, that the agreement does not make the worker worse off. Currently, the ultimate arbiter of no disadvantage is the commission. This bill simply supplants that with the Employment Advocate. It is very clear that parliament should not sanction this move to secrecy. Government members are constantly telling us publicly and privately that they do want fairness in our workplaces. One wonders why they come in here and vote for the minister's legislation if that is their view, but somehow they manage to reconcile those things in their minds. Why should they be believed if they sanction this change? If you do not want workers disadvantaged, why would you sanction a process that hides from public view decisions about whether or not they are disadvantaged? I would challenge the minister, when he responds in this debate, to explain why secrecy should be preferred.

I now return to the other issue I mentioned at the outset, which is section 170VDD of this bill which deals with the transmission of business in relation to Australian workplace agreements. The issue of transmission of business has always been an important one in industrial relations. Because of the limited constitutional power of the Commonwealth in relation to industrial relations, when awards and agreements are made they are binding upon the parties to them, not upon employers generally. So from the earliest days of our industrial law, it was recognised that there was a real risk that an employer who became party to an award or agreement and who was unhappy about it could seek to avoid their obligations by transmitting their business to a new company which was not party to that award or agreement. To avoid this problem, our industrial law since 1914 has provided that an award is binding on the parties to the award and their successors, assignees or transmittees—that is, it is binding on the parties to the award and on people who have transmitted to them, assigned to them or succeeded to them part of the business of the employer bound by the award. That took away the ability of an employer who was bound by an award but unhappy about it to transfer their business to, say, a new corporation to try to avoid their award obligations. You could not do that any more.

In the current act, this issue is dealt with in subsection 149(1) in relation to awards, subsection 170MB(1) and 170MB(2) in relation to certified agreements and subsection 170VS(1) in relation to AWAs. This bill introduces a major change to the current law in relation to the transmission of AWAs to a new employer in that it empowers the Employment Advocate to make an order that a new employer is not bound by the AWA or is bound by the AWA but only to the extent specified in the order. This bill contemplates a situation where an employer sells his business and the employees of that business worked under AWAs. The employees go across to the new employer and they do the same work in the same workplace using the same equipment, but they do not do it any more under the same terms and conditions because the AWA which they had negotiated with their previous employer does not transfer across. So it really is contemplating a situation where there could be a diminution in conditions even from an AWA. We know AWAs do not generally offer generous conditions to workers because of the circumstances in which they are negotiated, but workers could lose even the benefit of an AWA in a transfer because the Employment Advocate makes an order to that effect.

Let us be clear about this: that decision would be made by the Employment Advocate in secret and shielded from public view. It would not be an open commission proceeding. The workers would get no right of appearance, though the legislation tells us that they are able to make submissions. Throughout industrial relations legislation, a right to appear is usually specified using the terminology `right to appear'. Given that the terminology here is that they have the ability to make submissions, one would think that probably means written submissions. No explanation is given in the legislation as to what would happen to workers who may have language or literacy problems which would prevent them from making a written submission. So this is a major change in relation to transmission of business. It was largely unexplained in the minister's second reading speech, and I think the minister should come into the House and detail why it is appropriate. If it were appropriate to give a body the power to order that an AWA not be transmitted from the original employer to a new employer, one would wonder why that body was not the commission. Yet again we see a move to secrecy, a move to doing things behind closed doors.

I have raised this transmission of business issue because I am concerned that this change is really the thin end of the wedge of what is going to be a general Howard government assault on transmission of business provisions. I had a look at a very recent ministerial discussion paper, which was released by Minister Reith on 26 September. It is entitled Transmission of business and workplace relations issues—discussion paper and is available with a media release, which includes very nice photographs of the minister and his colleagues. When one looks through this, one sees that the purpose of this ministerial discussion paper is really to circumvent a number of recent judicial decisions about transmission of business. Those judicial decisions have been made in circumstances where an employer has decided to outsource part of its work, and the workers who have been doing the work for the employer are transferred to the contractor. They end up doing the same work, basically in the same circumstances, but the only difference is that they are paid less and get worse conditions.

Indeed, in many of these outsourcing examples, the saving that the employer experiences through outsourcing is not gained through any grand new efficiencies or magic new management culture; the saving actually occurs wholly and solely because the wages and conditions of the workers involved are downgraded. Unions have taken legal action about those matters in a variety of circumstances and the courts have agreed with the unions that, if workers are subject to awards or certified agreements and that kind of movement of work—the outsourcing of work—happens, the workers should get the same terms and conditions for doing the same work. How outrageous is that—getting the same terms and conditions for doing the same work, so you will get paid the same on Tuesday as you got paid on Monday, though the identity of your employer has changed? There is nothing very outrageous in that, but of course this minister cannot stand a union victory, and consequently this ministerial discussion paper is the first shot across the bows to change the law so that workers can be outsourced and have their pay and conditions attacked in the process.

When you read through this ministerial discussion paper, it posits a number of fairly fanciful examples about outsourcing issues and then raises the alleged problems to employers when this outsourcing occurs. I thought that, if this is going to be an issue that this government is going to make a move on, it might be important for members in this place not to look at the fanciful examples but to perhaps understand a real example. The real example that I am intending to raise involves the City of Greater Dandenong and the Australian Services Union, of which I am proud to be a member. This is a classic outsourcing example. In late 1997, the City of Greater Dandenong decided to outsource its home and community care services through a competitive tendering process. As we are all aware, HACC services are provided to the aged and include specialist care provided to people with disabilities. The service employed 73 staff—the majority of them were women working part time. The decision to outsource this work led to the formation of a committee to develop an in-house bid—that is, the workers who were doing the work wanted to bid so they could keep doing their own jobs. They were told at various management meetings—all of which were minuted—that they would need to reduce their working conditions to retain the work. The reductions the council sought included reductions in relation to travel time, out of hours and weekend penalty rates, and public holiday rates. The women involved—part-time workers most of them—argued that they could not afford to reduce their income; fair enough, one would think. The outcome was the in-house bid being based on the existing award EBA conditions of employment.

At its February 1999 meeting, which was taped on both audio and video, the council considered the tenders for the HACC work and resolved to outsource it to Silver Circle. The difference between the in-house and Silver Circle's bid was $1.56 million over three years. Of course, those savings were predicated on the people working for Silver Circle not getting the same terms and conditions. The mayor from one of the councils at the meeting openly criticised the workers involved for not being willing to reduce their terms and conditions. The Australian Services Union took action on behalf of those workers—firstly, under the freedom of association provisions in the Workplace Relations Act, claiming that these employees had been discriminated against for a prohibited reason; that is, they had been discriminated against, because they were entitled to the benefit of an industrial instrument or an order of an industrial body. They also claimed that, in this case, there was a transmission of business—that is, these home care workers were doing work, looking after the elderly and the disabled in their own homes; then the work was outsourced and Silver Circle performed that work; many of the workers went over to Silver Circle, so they were performing the same work, in the same circumstances and going to the same client homes; the only difference was they were getting paid less. They argued that, in that circumstance, the award and EBA to which they were entitled when they worked for the council should follow them to the transmitted business—that is, to Silver Circle.

That case was pursued by the Australian Services Union, and it became clear to Silver Circle that it did not even have an arguable defence to the transmission of business issue, and nor should it. Consequently, it settled that matter with the union in September 1999, and that was because Silver Circle knew that the union would be able to clearly substantiate that the carers were performing exactly the same functions with the same clients. However, the case actually went to decision in relation to the freedom of association point. I think this is a very important decision and one which heralds a victory for workers around Australia in these circumstances. On 4 September, Judge Madgwick handed down a decision which was a victory for these home care workers. In that decision, it was substantiated that it is illegal for employers to encourage or coerce workers into reducing their working conditions in a competitive environment. An employer cannot threaten to outsource the services of those workers if they fail to agree to any reduction and cannot be seen to publicly criticise workers for not reducing their working conditions. That is a major victory for workers around Australia who are put under the hammer by employers, told that their jobs will be outsourced and that they will lose them unless they accept lesser terms and conditions. One option for the City of Greater Dandenong is to appeal this decision to the High Court. One would hope that the City of Greater Dandenong acts genuinely in the interests of its ratepayers and does not waste its money in doing that.

Can I conclude by saying that I think this is a very important decision, a major victory, and that all congratulations should go to the Australian Services Union in pursuing this matter: to Joan Price, the organiser who was involved; to the shop steward, Wendy Phillips; to Glenda Mathews, one of the workers there who organised social functions; and to each and every one of the HACC workers who stuck by each other and were extremely supportive of each other. Congratulations should also go to the legal team involved, which included Mordy Bromberg as counsel and Josh Bornstein and Kim Parker of Maurice, Blackburn, Cashman, industrial solicitors on behalf of trade unions.

To conclude, this legislation we have before us ought to be rejected. It ought to be rejected for all of the reasons put in this debate and, in my contribution, it ought to be rejected because of the change it makes to the role of the Employment Advocate and the transmission of business provisions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a great opportunity that we have in this place today to consider the Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Workplace Agreements Procedures) Bill 2000, if only for the fact that it gives us an opportunity to put on the public record the concerns which we in the Australian Labor Party, as the genuine representatives of working men and women in Australia, have about the direction in which Mr Reith, Mr Howard and the Liberal government of this country want to take the conditions and terms of employment of the ordinary, decent, hardworking men and women who make up this country of ours. Part of this package of legislation being introduced by the government today in this piecemeal fashion comes after the withdrawal of last year's More Jobs Better Pay bill and, as has been indicated by speakers on this side of the House, we will be opposing this legislation.

speech.para: This in fact is part of a trilogy of broken promises delivered by the Prime Minister and the coalition government since they came into office. The first was that there would never ever be a GST; the second broken promise was that petrol prices would not rise under a GST; and the third, and most critical in terms of this legislation today, is that no worker would be worse off under the industrial relations climate created by the government.

Quite clearly that last proposition is an absolute nonsense. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent the great industrial heartland that is Wollongong—the Illawarra. If Peter Reith or the Prime Minister cared to come down and talk to some of my constituents who were former employees of Joy Manufacturing or were former employees of BHP, either in its steel division or its coal division, or came down and talked to a range of other former heavy industrial employees, I think they would get a completely different picture of how well my constituents viewed the industrial relations reforms being put forward by the government. I am sure they would hear from those constituents their absolute joy—unbridled joy, unbounded joy—at the fact that Australia's senior executives are being given multimillion dollar payouts and that senior executives are being given share bonuses that, when tallied up, run into many millions of dollars. I am sure that they would share in the, as I said, unbridled joy of my constituents that that is happening.

My constituents run around all the time saying, `Isn't it great that the bosses of the banks and the senior employee organisations of this country are getting such great rewards.' They themselves know that their personal circumstances, however, have not necessarily reflected that great joy that these other people have been able to get for themselves. A lot of that can in fact be traced back to the fact that since 1996 there has been a concerted effort to undercut the terms of employment, the conditions of employment and indeed the real wages and living standards of ordinary Australians in this country.

This legislation typifies those sorts of concerns because it is about, effectively, a process of implementation, through AWAs—that is, Australian workplace agreements—which will see those standards, those conditions of employment, continuously undercut. Let me just touch on a few of these. Firstly this legislation seeks to grant the Employment Advocate greater powers at the expense of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. We know, we remember well, that John Howard's proudest boast was that he would come from the front and stab the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the stomach. He wanted to get rid of it. He did not want to have an independent arbiter, an independent umpire, out there that would be able to sit in judgment in disputes between employers and employees. Rather, what we saw created was this Employment Advocate who can simply tick off on any of these AWAs. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission's powers to arbitrate in many of these disputes therefore has simply been gutted and for no other reason than some ideological bent against the trade union movement in favour of one party over the other.

The fact is that in any dispute—it does not matter whether you are talking about a fight at home in family circumstances or whatever—it takes two to tango. Any dispute has two people or two groups of individuals, or two groups generally, that are fighting each other for a particular reason. In the case of industrial relations it is often about terms and conditions of employment. What we are talking about here are things like taking away some of those hard fought for and realistic sorts of things which employees at the workplace would like to retain. But with changes in technology, changes in work practices and so on, realistically, some of those things have to go. As a consequence, if there was an opportunity to sit down in a spirit of compromise, in a spirit of an ability to reach an agreement which would see benefits for the employee and the employer, then clearly that has to be a better set of circumstances. But we do not see that any longer. What we see is the power shift that has taken place because of changes which this government and this minister continue to push forward. And this is yet again another example of where that power shift would take place. It would clearly tip the balance away from workers and their ability to be able to negotiate an appropriate outcome for themselves.

My colleague the member for Lalor a moment ago talked about the fact that people who are doing equal jobs, doing the same work, are able to be coerced into taking agreements which are different. How stupid is that? Here we have, in this day and age, people who are skilling themselves—going through tertiary institutions or taking training courses and so on to skill themselves—so that they can continue to play a useful role in the workplace, as we know our economy is changing. Yet what we are being told is that this minister and this government would like to see people who have equal skills, who are doing the same job, not being recompensed equally. There is an inversion taking place there, as I said, and a change and a shift in the power relationship that an employee can have.

The bill proposes also the removal of the requirements to offer identical AWAs to comparable employees. Consequently, we believe that that is unfair. We believe that it certainly does not meet the Prime Minister's commitment that no worker would be worse off under any of these industrial relations changes that this government would bring into place. We can all recall the 1996 election campaign where the Prime Minister, then Leader of the Opposition, said, `Trust me on all of this stuff. We'll never, ever introduce a GST. Trust me on that. Trust me if you're a worker. Don't worry, you're not going to be worse off; you'll be okay under us. We're not going to change the circumstances. We are not going to change having collective certified agreements which offer opportunities for like workers to be recompensed in like ways. Everything's okay.' Yet here we see examples of where that clearly is not the case.

The bill will also remove the limited immunity available in respect of industrial action taken in support of a claim for an AWA. So, once again, we see this ideological bent, saying that ordinary folk cannot go and legitimately and legally try to protect their own terms and conditions of employment in some way. How often in this place—it is almost on a daily basis—does the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business come in here with the same sorts of tactics that we saw him support in the Patrick dispute with the dogs, the balaclavas and the thugs on the waterfront, expressing the view that anybody who is in a union is somehow a second-class citizen and any worker who wants to stand up for themselves in any way whatsoever should be subjected—and rightly so—to brow beating and basically be told, `This is the job: take it or you're gone.'

If the minister thinks I am joking about this or stretching the truth, he should come to certain electorates and talk to the people there. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you, coming from the electorate which you so ably represent, appreciate these sorts of views. The minister should come and talk to some of the people in the member for Gilmore's electorate, for example, at the defence base. He should go and talk to the employees of Serco. Go and talk to them at Albatross and just see what is happening as a result of the outsourcing program being pursued by this government. Employees suddenly find a private employer coming into Albatross and the company Serco Australia is given the responsibility for providing all sorts of services on the base, and it then decides to start the recruiting process. What it does is say, `This is the AWA that we are going to offer you, an individual contract. This is it.' Down in a place like Nowra, where unemployment is still unacceptably high, the people who presently work on the base and who are being asked to take one of these new AWAs are finding that the terms and conditions being offered are not as good as they once had. They are thinking, `Well, maybe I shouldn't do this; maybe I should hold out a bit.' But Serco says, `You've got a once in a lifetime opportunity to take this now, or out the door you go because somebody else is waiting in line.' There are hundreds of other people in that area who are taking such AWAs.

I am not singling out Serco as an example of this. But Serco in the particular case down in the Shoalhaven typifies a company which has embraced the industrial relations legislation which this government has put through—and if that is the law that is its right to do so. What it demonstrates clearly is that in a circumstance such as that—where, through outsourcing and changed relationships on a defence base like HMAS Albatross, we are finding the terms and conditions of workers being varied—they are worse off.

I point again to a few other examples within my own constituency. I mentioned Joy Manufacturing earlier. Joy Manufacturing, multinational company that it is, has a number of different outlets operating throughout the Illawarra. It is in manufacturing. It is in mining machinery. It is in a range of other things. There has been a massive industrial campaign within the Illawarra that has raged for a number of months now stemming from the fact that that company locked its workers out. It wanted to have changed circumstances for the terms and conditions of those employees, so what did it do? It locked them out so that ordinary hardworking men and women of that company could no longer access their place of employment. We had police. We had the trade union movement, represented by the newly reformed South Coast Labour Council doing a sensational job in mobilising support for those workers. We had peaceful demonstrations, peaceful rallies but, nevertheless, people making a point about Joy Manufacturing.

Regrettably, we have not seen too much of a breakthrough on any of this. We have not seen those workers feeling that they are `comfortable and relaxed'—in the Prime Minister's language. We have not seen those workers thinking, `Well, aren't I much better off now because I'm locked outside the gate and I'm not getting anything.' What we have not seen—under this legislation that this government proposes and in fact has enacted—is any way in which these workers feel that they are better off, as the Prime Minister promised.

What we have also seen in my area, though, is what I consider to be model industrial relations in operation, and that is at the Port Kembla coal loader. I would suggest that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business have a look at that model of how things work. I think the Port Kembla coal loader is a model for what should operate around Australia. A few years back, the Port Kembla coal loader had anything but an outstanding track record. Strikes were the order of the day. Why? Because we had a whole bunch of unions that had coverage on all sorts of different aspects of the way in which the coal loader operated. We saw that those unions sat down and recognised that in all of the cross-border disputes—which arose because somebody from one union perhaps went and did the job of somebody else and that union then walked out—they had to rethink their position to sustain the employability of the majority of people at that coal loader in difficult economic times for the Australian coal industry. At the same time, the management understood that they had to rethink their position as well.

What we have now seen is a reduction in the number of unions—I forget the exact number of unions, but there were multiple unions—to two unions that have the coverage of the work force on the coal loader. In difficult circumstances, they had to oversee redundancies as well. So here you had a mainstay industry for the Illawarra and for Australia in the coal industry, a coal loader which needed to facilitate exports so that Australia benefited from the export dollars being earned, and a union work force and a management group coming together to sustain those jobs and to sustain that industry. As I said, the result was improved management practice, because the management understood that they needed to change. They no longer wanted to see an adversarial role all the time. They no longer saw themselves as one part in a running industrial relations dispute. They understood that there was a need to sit down with the workers and actually work through some of these issues. The unions understood that that was a problem for them. They understood there were too many unions. They understood that, in these disputes which broke out, the need was there for rationalisation, and that occurred. They understood also that they had to sit down and be prepared in circumstances to look at terms and conditions and to come up with things which were good for the company, and they have done so. It has been difficult, as I say, because people have actually lost jobs as a result of it, but the industry is sustained now and they sit down around the boardroom table together working as they should be for the profitability of the company concerned and for the terms and conditions of employment of the work force at that coal loader. I would commend that. I have taken my friend and colleague the shadow minister for industrial relations, the member for Brisbane, down to Wollongong. He has been on-site and spoken with the folk there. His intention is to come back, because he sees that as an excellent example and a model for how industrial relations might work in this country. I commend it to him.

I also think that, when you look back to this legislation and look at some of the other provisions that are in here, you can again see why we in the Labor Party have some genuine concerns about it. There will be a removal of the limited immunity available in respect of industrial action, which I spoke about a moment ago. The legislation will allow AWAs to be made undercutting a collective certified agreement, even while the loader is in operation. If there is one aspect of this which, I have to say, grates with most genuine workers in the community, it is that. What this means is that, if there is a collective certified agreement that has been negotiated between employer and employee at the present moment in good faith and giving good returns for both sides, under the bill that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is proposing, AWAs—that is, individual agreements—can be made that can undercut that. So an employer can come in, because the law will allow him to do so if this legislation goes through, and undercut the collective agreement that is already there. For that, read `downgrade the conditions and the terms of employment'—and, I suspect, the wages—of those workers who signed up to that collective agreement.

If there is one aspect of this legislation which is a major negative for a region like my own and a city like my own, which has a proud industrial relations history, it is that. That stands out as being a major negative and sends a signal of danger to the workers that there is an opportunity here for their conditions to be undercut. It is again a continuance of the breaking of the pledge of the Prime Minister that no worker would be worse off. There are many other issues that this legislation contains that the Labor Party have considerable disagreement with. I might just say that this is not an ideological thing. This is not Labor versus capital. This is not that at all. What this is about is protecting the terms and conditions of ordinary working men and women in this country. This is about saying to all of those people, `We believe that you need a fair go.' We are saying that this legislation does not do that. We think this legislation tips the balance too far in one direction, and that is unfair. There is need for change, but I think people in the work force understand that. I am not necessarily sure that too many in management these days believe that is the case. We have to find that balance. This legislation does not do so. This legislation is flawed; it is flawed for a whole variety of reasons. As a consequence, it will be opposed by the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to the debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Workplace Agreements Procedures) Bill 2000 and support totally the words of my friend the member for Cunningham and those of my other colleagues in relation to this bill. We in the Labor Party will not be supporting it. I am sure it is no surprise to Minister Reith that in any event we have to ask: what is the purpose of the exercise? It is very clear to me that those sensible Australians, those thinking people, will say that this legislation has as its purpose division. It is not fair. It is not equitable. It does not provide Australians who most need the support of an independent arbiter with the support of an independent arbiter. What it does is take away their right to collectively bargain and be in a situation where they share common working conditions with people who do similar work in similar environments.

speech.para: We in the Labor Party have indicated that we plan to abolish AWAs. We do not support them, and it is interesting in the context of this debate that the people who will be most disadvantaged by this push to in effect take away the safety net from many working Australians, to take away the protections that are provided for in awards and to take away the protection that is available for having someone advocate on their behalf are, not surprisingly, those people from non-English-speaking backgrounds, women, workers juggling work, family and social obligations, young people and—importantly, from my point of view—those people who live in remote and rural areas. Generally speaking, despite the efforts which are being made by unions to provide the support and protection that these workers need, it is a very expensive exercise and a very difficult exercise to maintain coverage across a range of awards in widely dispersed areas of Australia where the populations themselves are scattered and where location is a disadvantage not only for those people seeking to service their members—the unions—but for all the people who live in those areas.

It should come as no surprise that, if you were to pursue the objectives that are outlined in the legislation that this government wishes to impose upon the community, you would be leaving these workers in a particularly disadvantaged position. Whilst it might be difficult with awards for unions to service their members in these regions, the fact that they have awards provides them with a platform upon which they can build. If you take away—as the government intends to—the comfort that is provided by a common approach to working conditions for these workers across regional Australia, then you are exposing these people to a position where they are virtually defenceless.

It is no surprise when you look at the work being done as a result of changes which have been made in Queensland that when the Queensland government—that is, the Beattie government—changed the way in which the Queensland workplace agreements were to operate to ensure greater protection for the interests of working people the Queensland workplace agreements became far less attractive to employers. In Queensland, the state commission is required to ensure that Queensland workplace agreements are not contrary to the public interest, and when it considers the public interest it may consider the relative bargaining power and the particular circumstances and needs of low paid workers, women, young people, outworkers, apprentices and trainees. As a consequence, the Queensland workplace agreements are now far more transparent, open and fair and, when negotiated, they are far more responsive to the public interest.

The statistics speak for themselves. Under the Borbidge government, an average of 282 new Queensland workplace agreements were agreed per quarter. Under the Beattie government, that number has dropped to 16—in other words, as the Leader of the Opposition said in this place, the fairer the Queensland workplace agreements are, the less attractive they are to employers. The point is that AWAs are not only not attractive but not even cost effective. We need to understand that even the person charged with oversighting AWAs, the Employment Advocate, has admitted that the low take-up rate of AWAs could be due to the high transition costs. We estimate that an AWA costs on average around $500. That in itself is quite expensive, compared with the $22 that we believe it costs for each worker covered under collective agreements covered by the Industrial Relations Commission.

I take my comments back to those people who live in the bush, who are subject to negotiating one on one with an employer. Bear in mind that, generally speaking, wages and working conditions in the bush are less attractive in any event than they are in the major urban areas. It also needs to be borne in mind that particularly—and certainly in my electorate—those workers who live in regional areas, remote communities, face far higher costs than their counterparts who live in major urban areas. So on the one hand they get less money, by and large, and on the other it costs them more to live. Yet now we have a proposition which effectively says that these workers should be denied the basic protections which are in place in the collective agreements which are covered by the Industrial Relations Commission and that they should expose themselves to the whims of employers—who, as we know now, are less inclined to adopt AWAs when the process for achieving them becomes more transparent and fairer.

We are being told now that these workers should not worry about collective agreements or the fact that the government is intent on nobbling the independent umpire, the Industrial Relations Commission, or the fact that they will have no-one to advocate on their behalf or the fact that they may have English as a second or third language or the fact that they may have only achieved a schooling of year 8 or 9. We are being told they should not worry about these things; they should feel confident under those circumstances to sit down and negotiate one on one with their employer on their terms and conditions. It is so ludicrous it is laughable, if that in the end is what is being proposed by this government in industrial relations. I note that when the Senate had an opportunity to look at this legislation and previously the bill of 1999 Labor senators made it very clear what they thought of these proposals. Indeed, they made it very clear what they thought of the intentions of the government towards the Industrial Relations Commission. In fact, on page 159 of the November 1999 report of the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee entitled Consideration of the provisions of Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 Labor senators recommended, in relation to the Industrial Relations Commission, amendments to the act:

quote.para: to provide a greater role for the AIRC in prevention and settlement of industrial disputes and to act in the interests of fairness and in the national interest;

to provide the Commission with the power to arbitrate on all employment related matters in order to ensure that employees have the protection of effective awards which provide fair and relevant terms and conditions of employment; and
discretion to be provided to the Commission to arbitrate in cases where negotiations to conclude an agreement have failed within a reasonable period.

speech.para: It comes as no surprise to see that the government has clearly rejected outright the propositions put forward by my Labor Senate colleagues. It becomes more interesting, however, when you look at the position of the government on these issues as evidenced by the information which came forward by dint of the inquiries of the senators. From the evidence, what it is proposing has become clear. I quote from evidence given by Ms Lyn Tacy, who is deputy secretary of the department. When asked a question by Senator Carr as to whether or not the procedures bill that we are talking about today would in fact be proposing a reduction in the role and powers of the commission, she responded:

quote.para: Yes, it is making the OEA responsible for all elements of the testing of AWAs.

speech.para: As the Labor Party members of the Senate committee have said, the issue of public confidence in the Office of the Employment Advocate was canvassed in the 1999 minority report. No new evidence has been put to the committee to refute the conclusion of the Labor senators then:

quote.para: Overall Labor Senators were not persuaded that the OEA has not undertaken its role in an unbiased manner. In any event, lack of public confidence in the impartiality of the OEA would be enough to dissuade employees from attempting to seek redress through this office.

speech.para: I ask you to contemplate what is happening here. We have a proposal, very clearly put, to diminish the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission, transfer them as they are, in whatever form, to the Office of the Employment Advocate and provide the Employment Advocate, perceived as being the employers' advocate as opposed to the Employment Advocate, with the responsibility to oversight AWAs. What thinking person, what employee, what worker in any part of Australia could truly have confidence in the fairness of that situation? This is not someone who is independent of government in the same way as an industrial relations commissioner is. It is easy to see that any objective test that you would like to apply to whether or not this person would be independent would not be passed.

I go back to the position of thinking about workers who live in rural and remote Australia. They do not have the local access that workers who live in Sydney or Melbourne might have to union officials. In most cases they do not have open access to third parties—legal advisers and others providing them with advice on the sorts of agreements that might be placed in front of them by a potential employer—that people who live in Sydney, Melbourne or other major urban centres might have. But under this legislation they will be compelled effectively to like it or lump it.

The protection that is provided through collective bargaining and the registration of awards through the Industrial Relations Commission, which traverses geographical boundaries and has some consideration of locational disadvantage, will not exist. These people will be at the absolute mercy of the employer. That is the fact of it. Whilst we will hear the minister come in here and berate us, as he does continually, on the efficacy of the arrangements which he is proposing to put in place and the fairness of them, by any objective measure they are unfair. By any objective measure they will disadvantage Australian workers. By any objective measure they are not good for this community. I am proud that the Labor Party has taken the position that it has. I am proud that the Labor Party has taken the view that we will oppose this legislation, because it is not fair, it is not equitable. Indeed, in my view it is most damaging.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to oppose the Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Workplace Agreements Procedures) Bill 2000, which is yet another attempt by the Howard government to strip away the rights of workers and deny the role of trade unions in the bargaining process. The amendments in this bill are essentially the same as schedule 9 in the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999, which the opposition and the Democrats had the good sense to oppose last year. According to the Bills Digest, this bill contains amendments that seek to:

quote.para: provide for AWAs to take effect on the date of signing or, if later, the date specified in the AWA as the commencing day ...
permit employees to sign AWAs at any time after receiving a copy of the information statement prepared by the Employment Advocate and an explanation of the effect of the agreement ...

speech.para: There is presently a condition where existing employees must be given a copy of the agreement at least 14 days prior to signing the agreement and new employees must be given a copy at least five days in advance of signing the agreement. The proposed amendments eliminate the requirement that comparable employees be offered identical AWAs. This is one of the most unfair and indecent parts of this bill. This will enable employers to discriminate against employees. Ultimately, it will create inherently unequal pay for equal jobs in the workplace. The Bills Digest goes on to point out that the proposed amendments would:

quote.para: Permit an employee party to an AWA that provides for remuneration of $68,000 per year or less to withdraw consent within a cooling-off period ...

speech.para: In the bill there are also amendments to the provisions which obstruct awards that had been made under section 170MX(3) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 dealing with the relationship between AWAs and certified agreements and awards. Basically, as the shadow minister for industrial relations said in this House yesterday, these are awards the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has arbitrated, and where the AIRC as a result of a dispute has determined there is no chance of an agreement it sets an award. The bill also allows the removal of limited immunity available in respect of industrial action taken in support of a claim for an AWA. This effectively prohibits an employee from accessing protected industrial action during the term of the AWA, and is therefore inequitable.

Finally, the proposed amendments are supposed to simplify the approvals process by: one, blending the existing assessment of filing requirements and approval requirements into an amalgamated one-step approval process by the Employment Advocate; two, removing the requirement that the EA refer AWAs to the AIRC where there is a concern that the AWA does not pass the no disadvantage test—the no disadvantage test is where the AWA is compared to the relevant existing award; the Employment Advocate would apply the no disadvantage test in all cases; and, three, providing a more streamlined process for AWAs that provide rates of remuneration greater than $68,000 per year.

I would like to record that the government's so-called simplification of workplace relations legislation will further abuse and erode the rights of ordinary Australian workers, those who have only their labour to sell, and increase the power of the wealthy employers who are driven by greed, avarice and the need to make profits at all costs. The original reforms worked to reduce the power of an employee or a trade union to take industrial action or seek review where review could be necessary. This simplification of the AWA process will see a further reduction in the already limited review process, because the current role of the AIRC to look at the no disadvantage test in AWAs will be taken on by the Employment Advocate. Once again, the public interest has been slaughtered.

This bill allows the government, for no reason except ideology, to diminish the already reduced role of the AIRC, the proven umpire between employers and employees. That is a disgrace. Let us look at the statistics pertaining to AWAs. A report titled `Agreement making in Australia under the Workplace Relations Act 1998 and 1999' states the refusal rate of AWAs was in 1998 only two per cent and in 1999 less than one per cent. Few AWAs, as you know, are ever challenged.

I note that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has just come into the chamber to wind up the debate on this bill. He thinks providing cooling-off periods is an adequate way of fully protecting employee interests. The minister is dead wrong. Employee interests will never be protected while the minister continues to pursue legislation which strips away awards, bashes unions and at all times prefers employer interests over employee interests. As my colleague the shadow minister for industrial relations, Arch Bevis, said yesterday in the House, the AWA process gives the employer an enormous amount of power, a free kick even, particularly when you remove unions, collective agreements and the independent umpire and when the employee is left to negotiate wages and conditions with their boss. I also note with serious concern that the current legislation permits AWAs to incorporate civility and faithfulness, and special employee obligations into contracts. Equally disturbing is that AWAs incorporate oppressive or remedial provisions which allow employers to take disciplinary action against employees.

I would like to ask the minister, as he is sitting at the table, what safeguards are provided to ensure that employees are not subjected to these unfair provisions in their AWAs or placed under duress to sign such unfair AWAs?

talk.start.para: —You should read the act.
—I have read the act, Minister.
—It is obvious that you haven't.
—I have. What guarantees can I give my constituents in Lowe that awards and rights currently in existence will not be further eroded? Obviously none.
—The only guarantee you will get is that you will send around a union secretary.

—The minister can interject as much as he likes, but the minister is only interested in looking after those who have the capital and the means of production and exchange. He is not interested in those who have only their labour to sell, who are the people that we are here to represent in this parliament.
—That is the language of the ideologue.
(Mr Nehl)—The minister will not intervene, and the member for Lowe will ignore—

—I will address my comments through the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker—I take your point—but, if the minister wants to have a crack at me, I emphasise that we are elected to this House to look after the ordinary people. We are not here to look after the rich and powerful and those who, as I said, have the capital and means of production and exchange; we are here to look after those who have only their labour to sell. You know that, Minister, very well.
—I am not; I am here to represent those ordinary people, and you are just creating insecurity.
—You are here just to represent union leaders.
—No. Minister, you have a record of just bashing the unions.
—Order! I have to say that the minister is not helping the House and I again ask the member for Lowe to address his remarks through the chair and to ignore any other intervention.

—I am doing my best, Mr Deputy Speaker, but the minister is being provocative. I will respond to interjections because, if they are going to be recorded in Hansard, I want my contribution to be recorded in Hansard also.
—Respond by all means, but do it through the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I was saying, with legislation like this there is no security for my constituents and their families, from Drummoyne to Homebush West and from Rhodes to Strathfield South and Enfield, to ensure that they will not be placed at a disadvantage in the bargaining process of AWAs. Minister Reith knows the truth of the matter, which is that these AWAs are in practice barely an `agreement' in the literal sense of the word. More often than not these agreements are of the type where, if the employee does not agree, if they will not sign the agreement, they have no job. Minister, is that fair? Plainly, it is signing under coercion. Coercion and duress are practices we should never encourage or endorse in a democratic society.

speech.para: I believe the minister is opportunistically using this bill to remove the collective bargaining system from existence, a system which is fair and decent for all Australian workers—all in the name of flexibility. The minister believes he has the hit the ball firmly into the employers' court. However, according to a report in the Australian on 7 June 2000:

quote.para: ... AWAs are not particularly user-friendly for employers.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has complained ... that the bureaucracy associated with AWAs is “onerous”, “convoluted” and “cumbersome”.
In short, the AWA reality is that they are expensive, complicated, unfair and unreviewable agreements shown in many cases to be less favourable in pay and conditions than collective agreements.

speech.para: Why would anyone in their right mind promote this process to employers as fair, flexible and straightforward when that clearly is not the case? It is also deceptive for the minister to continue claiming that the Workplace Relations Act gives employees an increased chance of better pay and conditions. Quite plainly this is ludicrous. I am very pleased to see that the shadow minister for industrial relations has come into the chamber too. Let us hope that in another 15 months he is sitting where the minister is sitting now.

The member for Cunningham, when he was speaking a little earlier this morning, asked why the government is not sitting down in the spirit of cooperation with regard to its own position, the unions' position and the ordinary workers. Quite plainly the government does not want to do this because, as the member for Cunningham so succinctly put it, it is only promoting the power shift from the ordinary workers to the employers. A moment ago the member for the Northern Territory exposed what the government is all about in terms of the Employment Advocate—it is becoming the employer advocate. Quite obviously that is unacceptable. Years ago the Prime Minister promised that under the new regime of workplace relations no workers would be better off.

talk.start.para: —Worse off.

—Sorry, would be worse off. Thank you, Minister. Quite plainly that is not the case, because those who come through the doors of my office in Burwood are certainly not better off. They are worried about job security for themselves and their families. When they are slugged with another broken promise, particularly in relation to fairness in workplace relations, they are very concerned about that. And they have been slugged with a GST.
—Are you against the GST?
—We are, because it is a regressive tax. You know that, Minister.
—Are you going to roll it back?
—Yes, we are going to make it fairer. That is what roll-back is all about.
—How are you going to make it fairer?

—You were not listening in question time over the last couple of days when reference was made to the enormous amount of revenue that your government is deriving from the increases in world oil prices.
—That's got nothing to do with the GST.
—It has got a lot to do with it because it is a form of revenue for the government. You are absolutely awash with money, all at the expense of the taxpayer.
—I can assure the member for Lowe that the chair is not awash with money. Again, he should direct his remarks only to the chair.
—I accept that, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I am being provoked by the minister sitting at the table.
—Talk about roll-back.

—I will talk about roll-back. The Treasurer was in here during question time yesterday and the day before talking about roll-back and saying that he has not heard the opposition use the term `roll-back'. We are using the term `roll-back' quite a lot, Minister. Roll-back is all about making the taxation system fairer. It would be a lot fairer if you handed back the revenue that you are deriving from the increases in world oil prices to ordinary people, because fuel prices affect everyone. It is scandalous. Roll-back is all about making taxation fairer. How can a 10 per cent flat rate of tax be fair? Quite obviously it is not. This government is a government of broken promises, not only in respect of GST but in many other areas. The government comes in here and talks about looking after ordinary people, but it is interested only in looking after those who are well off, not the ones who are suffering. This government is offering no security.

speech.para: To get back to this legislation, look at what Jeff Kennett did to AWAs in Victoria.
