The people voiced their opinions at the last Victorian election by getting rid of the then Premier of Victoria. This legislation is all about removing the safety net. A lot of people in my electorate of Lowe come from non-English-speaking backgrounds. Approximately 40 per cent of the people who live in my electorate were not born in Australia. They are disadvantaged by this legislation and the watering down of the awards. Obviously the awards which have been fought for by our forebears for over 100 years to give reasonable security to ordinary families will evaporate under your regime. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business comes in here with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and they tell us how the world economy is going and talk about the national interest. I cannot see that anything in the national interest is trickling down to the people who come through the doors of my electorate office in Burwood in my electorate of Lowe. As far as the government is concerned, the national interest seems to be all about promoting a climate for big business to make record profits and the closing of banks. The government's understanding of the national interest is that it is all about looking after and promoting big business. They do not understand that it is about public interest—looking after the ordinary person. The government is quite heartless in pursuing this workplace relations regime just to erode the security of families.

talk.start.para: —I have not lost it, Minister. Your Prime Minister made it quite plain that he was going to look after the battlers. Every day we read in the papers about `John Howard's battlers'. About the only thing the Prime Minister has done is create more battlers. You know that. Your legislation before the House today is making a contribution to that situation because it will create more battlers. You are not looking after ordinary people, and that is why I am speaking about the legislation. All the people who fought for very many years for the conditions and pay appropriate to the labour of ordinary workers would be turning in their graves today if they were contemplating this legislation going through the parliament. The situation will change in another 12 or 15 months when we have a federal election. When I go around my electorate of Lowe and talk about workplace relations, I can see that people are looking for leadership from a Prime Minister who has a heart, who is decent and who has compassion. Quite plainly, the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Kim Beazley, fulfils those criteria magnificently.

—You and the other minister at the table, the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, are laughing now, but I am very confident that when the federal election is called—most likely in the next 12 to 15 months—the people of Australia will vote for Kim Beazley; they will not vote for John Howard. Maybe the minister is cynical enough to think that that is an opportunity for him to sit in that chair. People want a Prime Minister who will govern for everybody, not just for the rich and powerful.

—That is true: he is looking after the interests of Mr Packer with free-to-air television. What other industry in Australia has legislation to protect it? What other proprietor with the wealth of Mr Packer is so protected? No-one else is allowed to get into the market for fear that if we have greater media diversity we will get broader opinions and views other than those in the interests of the government. Finally, it would be un-Australian to support this legislation, which breeds discrimination. In government Labor will abolish AWAs and work to implement a system which is fair and just. I oppose the bill, Minister—in fact, I condemn it.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr REITH
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —in replyI thank all members for their contributions. I must say we have not heard anything new. In fact, we have not heard anything of substance from the opposition in particular, exemplified by the fact that the last speaker strayed on to media policy to conclude his remarks. However, his remarks were rather typical, I have to say, of much of the rhetoric from the Labor Party on workplace relations issues. For example, he said that people in his electorate are coming in and are concerned about job security, and he then related this to the reforms the government has introduced. There are statistics available on levels of job security in the Australian economy, and those figures have been kept for many years. The latest set of figures reveals that the levels of job security as perceived by employees are pretty much what they were about 20 years ago. There was a significant increase in the concerns that people had about job security, and that big increase was in the early 1990s when, as a result of the recession that we had to have, instituted by the previous Labor government, many people lost their jobs and understandably the levels of job insecurity were very high indeed.

speech.para: The member opposite also repeated the claims of Labor members, both frontbench and backbench, that the government's policy obsession was with the interests of employers. It is a claim of course not backed up by any facts. Rather, the facts demonstrate the preoccupation that this government has with ensuring that we have a system that ensures that employees are better off. The official statistics reveal the substance of what I am saying. The official statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics demonstrate that in the 13 years that the Labor Party were in office wages for low income people actually declined. The purchasing value of the wages of low income people was five per cent lower at the end of Labor's 13 years than it was at the start. In contrast, real wages for low income people in the time that this government has been in office have increased by nine per cent. That is a claim based not only on official statistics from the ABS; the ACTU, in a policy document they issued last year, said that one of the best things about the Australian economy today is the fact that low income people have enjoyed significant increases in real wages—which demonstrates that the Labor Party are full of rhetoric. When they were in office they did nothing for low income people; in fact, low income people were significantly worse off. The hypocrisy of these people is incredible. Not only have wages gone up in the time that this government has been in office, but, furthermore, more people have had a job. It is no good saying, `We in the Labor Party are concerned about employees,' when so many people are in fact thrown onto the scrap heap of unemployment. And when did we have the highest level of unemployment in the last 50 or 60 years? It was when the Labor Party were running this country and when Kim Beazley, the now Leader of the Opposition, was employment minister. He gave Australia the highest unemployment we have had since the great recession. It is incredible hypocrisy for the Labor Party to claim to be pro-employee. When they were in office the people who suffered the most were the people least able to look after their own interests, the people most vulnerable to the chaotic pro-union leadership policies of the previous government.

It is a fact that on the front bench of the Labor Party today half of those people are former trade union officials. We have two former ACTU presidents. These people are in here not on behalf of workers but are in here on behalf of union bosses. It is just as bad in the Senate. Of the last 20 senators on the Labor side to come into the Senate, 17 of them are former trade union hacks—put in here not to look after workers but as a reward or as a factional deal for the interests of a few trade union bosses. Don't you tell us about looking after workers. No-one could have done more to disadvantage workers than did the previous Labor government, and no-one has done more in the interests of workers than has this government.

talk.start.para: —It was a most timely and appropriate interjection for the shadow minister to recall a headline in the Daily Telegraph not so long ago which, if I may say so myself, described me as the workers' friend.
—You can't even say it with a straight face.

—I will tell you why they said that. This just goes to show the hypocrisy of those opposite. The last speaker in this debate talked about the concerns that people have about job security. There is no better example of the concerns that people have about job security than when they lose their job. So this government for the first time introduced a scheme, the Employee Entitlement Support Scheme, to provide financial support to workers in their hour of greatest need.
—And have the state Labor governments backed you?

—Not only have the state Labor governments not supported us but, furthermore, the federal Labor Party have been encouraging the state Labor parties to oppose this scheme. You talk about job security and yet, on the significant extension of the safety net to provide people with security, you are publicly opposed to what we are doing for workers. That must be a source of private shame. But the fact is you do not have what it takes to stand up here and support a policy that helps workers. I do pay tribute to and acknowledge the labour movement in South Australia which is at least prepared to stand up and say, `Well, we may not agree with the details of this scheme but at least we support the federal government for being prepared to support workers.' The honourable member sitting opposite and the two frontbenchers here have never been prepared to actually give support to a scheme that helps workers when they most need it. I think that is a disgrace. I must say I am surprised by the overwhelming negativity of the opposition. They cannot support it because we introduced it. Quite frankly, that is pathetic and, quite frankly, it is typical of the way you people operate.

speech.para: The other point that the previous member made—and again this is a classic situation of hypocrisy from the Labor Party—was that the government is going to remove the protections of the umpire for workers. One of the protections for workers has been established by this government through the Office of the Employment Advocate. It is there to protect basic rights of workers. Yet the Labor Party's policy is to abolish the Office of the Employment Advocate. How can you stand there with a straight face and say that you are concerned about removing the umpire when it is your policy to abolish an office that was established not only to approve AWAs but also to provide support to employees on the very issues you raise? You talked about discrimination. We improved the discrimination elements of the Workplace Relations Act. You ought to read these things. If you want to be a serious contributor, you ought to read what we did. We actually improved the protections for people in respect of discriminatory behaviour and in respect of coercion. There are very strong laws against coercion. In fact, the Office of the Employment Advocate has taken action against employers on behalf of employees under those sorts of provisions. We are very happy to have a debate about these issues, but you ought to at least understand what we have done and what we are attempting to do, and you ought to look through the rhetoric and understand where the interests of workers are.

The one thing I did agree with the opposition on during this debate was their claim that the amendments proposed in this bill would increase the scope that there is in the system for making AWAs. That is absolutely true. That is our intention. The amendments would make AWAs more widely accessible, easier to make and more flexible. We do see increased scope for individual agreement making in a modern Australian economy as desirable, and we are not alone in coming to that conclusion. There are literally thousands—tens of thousands, probably hundreds of thousands—of employees who likewise like to have a choice of industrial instruments that they use for settling terms and conditions in their employment. It is no good you saying in one breath, `We don't like these particular proposals,' when in the next breath your real policy is just to abolish the choice altogether. Don't you understand that there is a basic inconsistency in that? You are not in favour of any individual agreements. Your view is that people should not have a right to an individual agreement.

talk.start.para: —You're just making it up as you go, Pete.
—Well, there is a pathetic interjection. It is based on the claim that you can have a common law individual agreement. That is what it is, is it not?
—Well, that's what most people are on now.

—Thank you very much. I do actually understand your argument. I make it my business to understand what you people are saying. What you are saying is that common law agreements are okay. But what you do not go on to say is that there will always be a second-class agreement and inferior to a collective agreement. In other words, if a union boss can coerce an employer into a collective agreement then, as far as you are concerned, the individual has no choice, no say whatsoever, in the terms and conditions of their employment. Thirty or 40 years ago when everybody was in the union maybe you had an argument for such a system. But today there are a lot of people who are not in unions. We have protected the right of people to be in unions. If you want to be in a union you are more than entitled to be. In fact, we have increased the protections for people against employers where those people want to be members of a union. We believe if you want to be a member of a union in this country you are more than entitled to do so, and we have bumped up the protections to that right. Our objection, and our point of contest with the Labor Party, is that if you do not want to be a member of a union you should not be forced to be a member of a union. That is the point of debate in this country.

speech.para: The fact is that this is a modern economy, and in a modern economy we see that many people are better educated and better informed. We have a more diverse economy. We hope over time there will be more opportunities for people. In that more diverse economy, within businesses employees want to have a greater say over the arrangements under which they work. To have the choice of an individual agreement simply provides people with that greater range of opportunities. That is all it does. It is just a range of choices. I find it quite bizarre that the Labor Party's policy, in a society that is becoming more diverse, where people are better educated and have more demands, not just in their work experience but in their family experiences, to have arrangements that suit them personally—and I do not reject that concept—is to prevent people having that choice.

It is simply an untenable policy position that you have today. In fact, it is not just untenable on the basis of what I put to you; at the last election your policy was to have AWAs. So you yourselves were saying only two years ago, `We should have AWAs.' You are going to neuter them, et cetera, but I will not go to the technicalities of it. You yourselves were saying that we should have AWAs. If they were okay two years ago, why is it your policy to abolish them today? The last member got up and said, `Our policy is to abolish AWAs.' Would you like to explain why it is that before the last election you were saying, `Our policy is to keep AWAs'? What has so changed in the world that something you were in favour of before you are now against? There is actually a quite reasonable explanation or should I say an understandable reason: that is, the Right and the Left and the trade union movement at the beginning of the year decided that they did not want to have AWAs. That is the only reason and it has not been denied. That is what has happened.

Let us look at what is happening in the real world. I say that a lot of individuals may want to have this choice, and that statement is backed up by the facts. The take-up rate of AWAs is a clear indication that Australian employees are embracing individual agreement making. In the first 12 months of the legislation, 11,000 AWAs were approved. By 1999, approvals were averaging approximately 3,000 a month. Now they are running at 4,500 a month. Overall, as at 31 July 2000, over 118,000 AWAs had been approved. Instead of debating the merits of individual agreement making and the rights which employees should have to make these choices, the opposition just use the debate to have a go personally at the Employment Advocate. Instead of playing the ball, they just play the man. You do not actually have anything substantial to say, so what do you do? You just go on to personalities to attack the advocate.

Even with the processing requirements for AWAs which presently apply, the Employment Advocate is able to report an efficient and effective conduct of its statutory responsibilities under the act. For the financial year to June 2000, filing procedures for AWAs were completed within three working days in 98 per cent of cases, and approval procedures were completed within 20 days in 92 per cent of cases. Our latest information shows that the commission takes an average of 27 days to approve a 170LJ certified agreement and around 30 days to approve an agreement made under section 170LK. The opposition spokesman does not even want to call AWAs agreements. He just says that they are documents, as if employees were not capable of understanding, pursuing or settling formal agreements about what is in their own interests. I think that is just a patronising insult to employees. What you are saying is that there are no employees out there who have the capability of actually entering into an agreement to suit their own circumstances. That is patently nonsense.

talk.start.para: —It's demeaning.

—It is demeaning. It is patronising. It is what the union leaders want to hear, but I can tell you that it is not what rank and file workers want to hear, including a lot of union members. To add insult to injury, the opposition continue to advise the parliament that individuals should not even be allowed to make this choice. The opposition spokesman said, `A Labor government, after the next election, will abolish AWAs.' How do they explain the fact that only two years ago they were actually in favour of retaining AWAs? There is no explanation. It is just the same old union heavies telling the Labor Party and Mr Beazley, who is a weak leader, what their policies should be. This is the same opposition spokesman who said in May of this year that pattern bargaining should be allowed because the Labor Party believed in parties having a choice in agreement making. That is in your press release. That is what you said. You said people should have choice.
—Get the quote.

—I have the quote. You said people should have choice in agreement making, yet here you are confirming that in fact they get no choice because you are not going to allow them a choice of an AWA. Not only is it incredible hypocrisy, but you don't seem to understand that this whole idea that the union leadership will run everything through a collective agreement operated 30 or 40 years ago when Australia had a closed economy, when we did not have the information age and when we did not have quite the same standard of education that we have today. That is in the past. This country has to move forward. We cannot now go back to a one size fits all mentality that might have been here in the 1960s and 1970s. Australia has to move on. We have the capacity to do so and we have got to have a modern industrial relations system.

speech.para: The Labor Party's policy is to tear up contracts that people have entered into. Their policy is to remove people's choice and to tear up these contracts. I think that is an absolute disgrace. People enter into AWAs and they do so willingly. They do so because it is in their own best interests. You have people on $60,000, $70,000 or $80,000 a year who are enjoying the benefits of an AWA, and because the union bosses do not like it, the Labor Party say to workers, `No choice when Labor's in.' Who will suffer as a result of that? The very people you claim to represent. We think workers ought to have a choice. They ought to have a modern system that suits them and that boosts productivity. If you boost productivity, you have higher wages, and we have proved that because wages are up under us. It is good for the country and more people have a job. That is why people should support this bill.
Question put:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Reith) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Dr Kemp:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 is intended to replace the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 from next year. This bill will provide continuing funding for the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program, IESIP, from 1 January 2001 to 30 June 2005, covering both recurrent and specific project funding, as well as the away from base element of Abstudy.

speech.para: The bill seeks to implement the 1999-2000 budget initiative which announced a new national indigenous literacy and numeracy strategy. Under the strategy launched in March this year, the government claims the funding will be performance based, with priority given to a focus on literacy, numeracy and school attendance. At the launch of this program, the Prime Minister incorrectly claimed that additional funding was being provided for indigenous literacy. He said:

quote.para: Today's strategy ... represents a firm commitment of resources from the federal government, as well as a commitment to better direct existing resources going towards indigenous programs ...

speech.para: Unfortunately, as is so often the case, the Prime Minister seems to have had little idea about what is actually going on in the education portfolio. In fact, at the very same launch that the Prime Minister was claiming that this strategy represented a firm commitment of resources from the federal government, we also had the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs stating the following—and I quote from the minister for education's speech at the launch of that strategy:

quote.para: $27 million from the pool of funding available for indigenous students will be provided specifically to support this strategy for literacy and numeracy.

speech.para: So in other words, we have the Prime Minister claiming that there was an increase in resources going to indigenous literacy and at the same launch the minister for education making it clear that this is simply an allocation of existing funds. When this matter was raised with the Prime Minister in the House, we had the Prime Minister stating that he stood by the statements he had made. In doing so, he misled the House. When this issue was raised with the Prime Minister, he gave me an assurance that he would investigate the matter, and I am glad I am not holding my breath because I have still not heard back from the Prime Minister for the obvious reason that, in fact, he understands that he misled the House in stating that new funds were being directed towards indigenous literacy in the new national strategy when, in fact, the minister for education has simply reallocated the existing pool of funding.

There are many people on that side of the House who would, I am sure, be quite keen for the Prime Minister to show a keener interest in education matters because the current minister for education—frustrated, temporarily, in his pursuit of university deregulation—is extremely busy elsewhere in his portfolio, cooking up plans to make more and more decisions behind closed doors and giving himself more unfettered power. As an example, this bill does not reproduce the table of per capita amounts payable to different types of education providers—preschools, schools and vocational education institutions—which is included in the current act. This appears to give the minister absolute discretion in the distribution of funding between different levels of education and between government and non-government providers. I will return to the subject of funding shortly.

In terms of the agreements to be made with education providers, while the current act gives the minister the power to set conditions not specified in the legislation, it indicates that the main conditions dealing with payments relate to the acquittal of the amount and monitoring, evaluation and reports on the education program—no penalties are specified. By contrast, the new legislation says that funds are recoverable if a condition of an agreement is breached. Neither the bill nor the explanatory memorandum spells out what the conditions might be, but the minister's letter of 8 June this year to state and territory education ministers regarding the new IESIP arrangements says:

quote.para: Accountability and reporting arrangements for IESIP will be strengthened for the 2001-04 quadrennium. An enhanced set of IESIP performance indicators was agreed at the March MCEETYA meeting. The indicators will form part of the forthcoming negotiations on IESIP indigenous education agreements ...

speech.para: I understand that performance targets also will be set as part of those agreements.

While even the states grants legislation currently before the parliament that provides funding to government and non-government schools across the country sets out a series of steps to be taken in the event of school authorities not meeting performance targets, this bill simply says that if one or more of the conditions of an agreement is breached, then the money is recoverable by the Commonwealth. I do not think that the minister would ever intend to apply the same onerous criteria to some of the category 1 schools that he seems to be so keen to give massive funding increases to.

This bill also states that the Commonwealth may recover the amount as a debt through the courts. I actually think that this is a fairly extraordinary provision to be placed in this bill, especially given that this bill is making grants for education. I would be grateful if, in the response to the second reading debate, the minister could clarify the government's intentions in this area. I would in particular like him to explain how he intends to deal with situations where providers may in good faith have tried to meet required performance targets but nevertheless have failed to do so.

The Labor Party will be strongly opposed to the use of the powers spelt out in the bill to recover moneys already paid and already expended by education authorities, except in the most extreme circumstances. Our preference would be, and we would certainly hope, that in the first instance the government would adopt a more constructive approach to addressing any concerns it may have about an education provider failing to meet performance requirements. In particular, we would hope that education providers would be warned that future funding was at risk if they did not meet particular performance indicators. I suspect that the government would have difficulty trying to recover money in court if it had not given a warning before action was initiated in court to recover money already spent on educating indigenous students.

I would like to return now to the issue of funding. I mentioned earlier the discretion given by this bill to the allocation of funding by the minister. It was with great concern therefore that the opposition found that this year's budget papers showed that only 45.7 per cent of IESIP funds was being directed to government providers. That was down from 56.7 per cent in the 1998-99 budget, and we raised this matter with the office of the minister for education. In a letter dated 7 September, the minister advised me that a so-called technical error had occurred and that Budget Paper No. 3 was incorrect, which is quite an admission from a minister who seems to specialise in making statistics say anything he wants. But we are pleased that the government has admitted that there is a technical error in Budget Paper No. 3. I understand that the technical error flowed from the fact that Abstudy away from base funding, which has now been incorporated with IESIP, had been incorrectly included with funding for non-government education providers. I am pleased that this situation has now been clarified because of the opposition's questions and that the split between the government and the non-government sectors appears much more stable. Rather than funding for indigenous education by government providers falling from 56.7 per cent to 45.7 per cent, in fact it rises from 56.7 per cent to 64 per cent. That certainly eases our concerns.

I note, however, that the attachment to the minister's letter to me on this issue is careful to state that, according to the minister, the sector split is `indicative only'. This again highlights the minister's much wider discretion under this bill, certainly compared to the current act, in the allocation of funds. As to how the money might be spent and what sort of agreement providers will need to sign, we have noted that the National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy focuses heavily on literacy, numeracy and school attendance. In addition, the minister's letter to states and territories, to which I referred earlier, says the following:

quote.para: The changes to be introduced for the 2001-04 quadrennium are significant ...

speech.para: In this context, I wonder to what extent providers will need to shift their focus away from cultural issues onto the more basic ones of literacy and numeracy. No-one is disputing that improvements need to be made. Only 32 per cent of indigenous students stayed to commence year 12 in 1998 compared with around 73 per cent of non-indigenous students.

Data presented by the minister for education at a gathering last year in Alice Springs shows that there have been some improvements in the last several years. The number of indigenous people participating in education increased from 1.8 per cent of total students in 1986 to 2.5 per cent in 1996. The number of indigenous people with an educational qualification increased from 10.6 per cent in 1991 to 13.6 per cent in 1996. There was a 28.3 per cent increase in indigenous school enrolments between 1991 and 1996, and a further 10.3 per cent increase to 1998. Vocational education enrolments by indigenous students almost doubled between 1994 and 1998. Also, indigenous students represented 1.3 per cent of higher education enrolments in 1998 compared with just 0.3 per cent in 1981. We have a great distance still to travel before indigenous Australians can hope to have educational opportunities that come near those available to non-indigenous Australians.

At this point I would like to highlight a report that was commissioned by, and recently provided to, the Northern Territory government. It is a report that was prepared by former Labor senator for the Northern Territory Bob Collins. Bob Collins and the members of his support staff did a great deal of work in seeking to investigate the problems in indigenous education in the Northern Territory. Highlighted in the Collins report are a few things that I wish to refer to today. It found that just six per cent of year 3 and only four per cent of year 5 indigenous students in non-urban Territory schools achieved national reading benchmarks in 1998. This compared with 54 per cent and 36 per cent respectively for their indigenous counterparts in urban schools. For non-indigenous urban students, the rates were 82 per cent and 78 per cent. So there is a massive difference, especially for indigenous kids going to school and living outside urban areas in the Territory. The Collins report in particular highlighted the massive difficulty of poor attendance by indigenous students at Territory schools. It said:

quote.para: Poor attendance at school for whatever reason remains the most significant direct cause of poor learning.

speech.para: It also highlighted the enormous difficulty that students face because of the high turnover of teachers in non-urban Territory schools.

For whatever reason, we can only hope that the Northern Territory will pick up and implement as soon as possible the very sensible recommendations that came from the Collins report. In many ways, we can never ensure that students will develop a strong foundation, especially in literacy and numeracy at school, unless they attend school and immerse themselves in their training every day. Having had the privilege of visiting some non-urban schools in the Northern Territory in my capacity as federal shadow minister for education, I know that some of those schools have very dedicated staff. They have people with enormous commitment to trying to ensure that the indigenous students have a better start in life through a decent education. Those people face an enormous task in trying to ensure that kids in those schools have a fair opportunity to build up literacy and numeracy skills. I know that many of the communities rely on the staff in those schools to ensure that their kids have a decent educational foundation. But addressing student attendance and trying to reduce the massive turnover of staff in non-urban schools right across the country is very important.

Several of those communities have also highlighted the importance of a bilingual education in ensuring that their culture remains strong and that the students not only develop a good foundation in English but also have a good foundation in their first language and a good foundation in the traditional cultural practices of their community. The Northern Territory some time ago was looking at winding back its commitment to bilingual education programs, and I note that at several stages the federal minister for education was giving his support to the Northern Territory government's decision to do so. I am pleased that the Northern Territory government to date seems to have had second thoughts about that decision. Certainly within those communities there is very strong support for the maintenance of the bilingual education programs to ensure that their culture remains strong. Some of those communities were represented in the opening ceremony at the Olympic Games. Any of us who had the chance to see those communities participating in the `awakening' segment at the Olympic Games would understand the enormous importance they place on ensuring that their culture is communicated in a strong way to their kids.

What we are suggesting is that there is still an enormous task ahead of us in indigenous education, whether it is in ensuring that kids have a chance to get a basic foundation in literacy or numeracy or whether it is in ensuring that as many indigenous students as possible complete year 12 and have a chance to study at TAFE or university. We still have great lengths to go before non-indigenous Australians will even begin to approach the opportunities that are there for them. What we need is greater cooperation and an intensified effort in implementing programs that are demonstrating success in indigenous education across the country. While the government has made much of its National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy, which was launched by the Prime Minister in March, we also have the minister claiming that this strategy was quite a historic leap. We certainly hope that it continues to lift the educational outcomes of indigenous Australians and that it does fulfil the ambitious claims made by the government about it. But we are concerned that, if the minister for education has his way, none of us will be able to tell. There is no provision in this bill for parliamentary scrutiny of ministerial decisions in relation to expenditure, agreements or performance information. The opposition will be circulating an amendment in a few minutes that seeks to deal with these issues. At the end of my speech, I will be moving a second reading amendment that deals with some of these issues as well.

I would like to take this opportunity to ask the minister once again to explain why he felt justified in reducing Abstudy payments, especially to older indigenous students. The government has never made public the findings of its review of Abstudy, on which it apparently based the changes, announced in December 1998. I cannot see any reason why the public should not have access to the review of Abstudy, which the government has used to justify the dramatic changes it has made. Those changes involved aligning many Abstudy payments with those made to non-indigenous students under the youth allowance. The minister claimed that the alignment was justified except in cases where `special provision needs to be made to cater effectively for the particular disadvantages faced by many indigenous students'. Students aged 21 and over were the biggest losers under the Abstudy changes brought in by the Howard government, with some payments dropping by around $65 a fortnight. The minister has never explained why these students do not qualify for his special provision, given that, while the proportion of indigenous people with a formal qualification rose to 13.6 per cent, as I mentioned, the comparative figure for the general population was much higher—34.4 per cent.

A report was prepared for ATSIC by Ms Wendy Brabham and Associate Professor John Henry from the Institute of Koorie Education at Deakin University dealing with the very Abstudy changes which came into effect some time ago. That report found that the changes would significantly disadvantage indigenous TAFE and university students who are aged 21 and older, are independent, are single or with a partner and are with or without children, of whom there were 9,950 in 1998. They also found that it would significantly disadvantage TAFE and university students who are getting either a sole parent or a disability support pension. There were 4,810 such students in this group in 1998. An important point about the ATSIC report findings is that it is mature age students who make up almost 80 per cent of the indigenous TAFE and university student population. The report quotes research over the last 30 years indicating that many indigenous people of mature age with community and family responsibilities return to education and training. These are the very people who are being hurt by the cuts to Abstudy payments, and there is a great deal of information to suggest that the cuts are already having a significant impact.

I will return to the bill before the House. The minister needs to explain why, if the government is serious about its stated aims for improvements in education outcomes for indigenous students, it seeks to pursue these aims behind closed doors. Why does this bill seek to reduce the information available to the public about what the government is doing in funding indigenous education? Why is this bill such a bare bones effort, with all the meat hidden from view? Where are the guidelines which will operate under this legislation? My office asked that the guidelines, at least in draft form, be provided before this bill was debated. We have not seen them yet, and I doubt that we will see them before the government rams this through both houses of the parliament. It seems this minister does not know the meaning of cooperation, openness, transparency or accountability. If there is one area where we do need cooperation, openness, transparency and accountability, it is in indigenous education in Australia. For this reason, I now move the opposition's second reading amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House
(1) notes the major disparity between the educational outcomes for indigenous Australians and the general population;
(2) calls for a renewed commitment from governments and education providers to address this disparity; and
(3) condemns the Government for:
(a) misleading the public by wrongly claiming the National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy contained additional funding; and
(b) providing incorrect funding figures for indigenous education in the Budget Papers.”.

talk.start.para: (Mrs Gash)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to speak on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000. This is a very difficult issue to address, the powers of political correctness being what they are, because dealing with the nitty-gritty of the indigenous education problems that exist in Australia involves a very frank discussion about what motivates people, what can benefit communities and what can hold them back. I was very pleased to hear what the opposition spokesman had to say in focusing to some extent on the problems of remote communities. The problems of remote communities are many times worse and more difficult to overcome than those of the Aboriginal communities that are better served in the larger, more populated areas of Australia. I commend the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 and also note that it provides funding for the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program which will total $591 million over the four years between 2001 and 2004.

speech.para: I would like to ambitiously turn to some of the problems that exist in remote communities. I anticipate that some difficult questions will arise in this debate but I shall proceed. In his speech, the opposition education spokesman referred to the findings of Bob Collins and his report commissioned by the Northern Territory government. I would like to endorse that. I do believe that Bob Collins has a very close understanding of the needs of remote communities, but he was not the first to identify the problems. I know that because I had a major role in preparing an earlier report, which was completed by the former Northern Territory Minister for Education Tom Harris in 1990. That report went into the needs of remote Aboriginal communities very carefully. I was working on Minister Harris's staff and the minister visited every single Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory, sat down with them, discussed with them their concerns and discussed with them what they wanted in Aboriginal education. I had the great privilege of being involved in that process, so I do have some insight into the comments that were made at the time, the very genuine concerns that those people felt in relation to their future and their concerns that in many ways the people whose job it was to meet those needs—the bureaucrats and the politicians—were not getting down to the grassroots level that they needed to get to.

You could go back even further. Back in the seventies, there was a report by a Japanese academic, Matsuri Shimpo, and Matsuri Shimpo uncovered many of the same things that Bob Collins locked into. So there is an absolute tower of material highlighting the way we need to address the problems of Aboriginal communities. Unfortunately, those genuine efforts to get to the needs of the people are constantly being frustrated and do not always fit in with the requirements of bureaucracies, so it remains a frustrating and difficult effort. Also, sadly, it is a process that is prone to gross political misrepresentation. There are no Aboriginal people from remote communities in the House today or sitting in the galleries or anywhere about here, and even when we do see Aboriginal representatives here they are not always without political pretensions and they are not the people to whom these services need to be directed—to whom these services absolutely, vitally, must be directed.

I will return to some of the figures that the opposition spokesman quoted. I think he said that six per cent of year 3 students in remote schools made the nationally accepted education benchmark in 1998 while 53 per cent in urban schools made the same level. So there is a severe problem in the remote communities and we do have an obligation to get out there and do something about it. But there is political static, there is political misrepresentation, there is inertia within the bureaucracies and there is an incapacity to communicate with the Aboriginal people in remote areas and to maintain that communication at the level that is needed.

I turn to some of the problems that exist in remote communities. The first problem—and this was referred to by the opposition spokesman—is attendance. Everything spins off this, because without attendance there is no schooling. I will tell you how bad the attendance problem in remote communities is. When I worked on that report with the Northern Territory education minister, we visited a community with 300 children. Sure, there was a school there, built to accommodate 300 children. It was a big edifice with rooms and seats for 300 children. There were 300 children running around the community ready to be educated but, on any given day, only 30 children were attending that school, and every day it was a different 30. With that level of chronic failure to attend school, with that low level of interest in school, how can you ever complete a successful education program? Clearly, you cannot, and it is not something that a bureaucracy can act upon to address. Will it be required that truant officers be sent into these communities? That is not going to work, and this is the fundamental problem.

Questions were raised when we visited these communities of whether teachers should be asked to go and round up their kids before school. People would know that in many places around Australia schools are running breakfast programs, hoping to entice the kids to school by offering them breakfast. That is a very difficult thing. The opposition spokesman talked about the value of bilingual education programs. For the information of members, a bilingual education program is supposed to work in the following way. Children who speak their own language are supposed to begin their school life learning in their own home language but, under a bilingual education program, they are supposed to transfer to a fully English program by the time they reach the end of the primary level, at the end of year 7. They are supposed to start off in their own language and then gradually transfer into English so that they are then ready to go on to high school and to the levels of education that other Australians rightfully expect—and Aboriginal people certainly expect access to that.

But imagine the problems you have with that concept when you throw in the difficulty of attendance. If people are not attending school, how are they ever going to transit from their home language into that language of English so that they can then go on into the outer, wider world, the community, and achieve their dreams? They can only achieve those dreams through education and through a program of opening up to the world, understanding it and making their own decisions based on information that they receive, that they accept and that they can make value judgments on. A bilingual education program is a wonderful idea if you have the attendance to back it up—that is the guts of the Northern Territory government's grave reservations about this program. If you continue to apply a bilingual education program before you have good attendance in communities, you are putting the cart before the horse. You are setting yourself up to fail; it is not going to work. The Northern Territory government has taken that concern on board and is endeavouring to deal with it. I suppose you could say, `Okay, let's find communities where there is good attendance and then implement a bilingual education program.' I think that is a great idea, but the problem is this: this problem of attendance does not exist in some communities because they are in some way uninformed; it is something that can be here today and gone tomorrow: you might have a year of good attendance and then you might have 10 years of no attendance. There really is a problem with a lack of understanding about the value of education and the need for attendance before that can occur.

One of the problems behind all of this is that the children in these communities are like children anywhere: they want to have fun; they want to enjoy their lives. Honestly, many of these children are living in places—and I am talking about those in the top end of the Northern Territory—that really are quite idyllic. If you want to go and catch a fish, you can catch one now. If you want to catch a turtle, you can catch one of them too. As a child you can have a heck of a good lifestyle in these places. Of course, it is different in some of the other areas that we are talking about—remote Aboriginal communities. For example, places in the Western Desert are a different story altogether, but for a moment let us look at the northern part of Arnhem Land. Honestly, if I were a child there and someone said, `Okay, you can go out fishing all day and you can enjoy yourself, or you can go to school,' I would say, `Where is school going to get me?' `Okay, that is going to mean that you leave all this fishing and your traditional way of life here behind and go out into the wider world to seek out a job.' Of course, that does not necessarily appeal to someone from that sort of an area and we really have to work harder to make sure that it does.

Let us move on from attendance and look at literacy and numeracy. I am pleased that the minister has made attendance, literacy and numeracy important goals within this legislation, because without those basic building blocks you cannot go anywhere. You need to have the basics of literacy to be able to proceed. The Commonwealth government is making this a goal not only for remote Aboriginal communities but for all over Australia, because it was not that long ago that there were reports that 30 per cent of Australians had literacy and numeracy problems. When 30 per cent of Australians are having difficulties reading or writing, imagine the situation in a remote community.

Let us also look at the structure of the education system that we offer in these areas. It is important that these Aboriginal people have access to the same standards of or opportunities in education that every other person has. I think one of the great things about living in a democracy should be that, no matter where you are or from where you start out in life, you can aspire to be whatever you want. You can be a spaceman, an astronaut, if you want to and if you study hard and you commit yourself.

Unfortunately, one of the great temptations in this whole process is for people to set up special deals, little special schooling operations, that are in fact dead ends that do not articulate back into the mainstream. If we set up a breakfast program and all kinds of other programs that bring people in but we do not really do education but do cultural things and we do not focus on the need to be able to read or write and on the need to then be able to follow on with further learning—if all we are doing is operating a kind of caring and sharing cultural enterprise that involves people and it turns out to be a dead end in educational terms, something that does not lead anywhere—what are we doing? We are not providing the access to the world that education must provide. So we have to be practical: we have to provide education courses that will carry those people forward and will offer them the opportunity to go on if that is what they want. We have to have institutions that do not have walls. You cannot have an institution that is only for Aborigines, because if you do that you are making a special case out of those people and it does not articulate. It needs to articulate into other areas of learning so that people then have the opportunity to realise the dreams that they hold.

The member also spoke about the difficulty of remote communities. That cuts two ways. There is the problem of attracting teachers to those remote communities and there is the problem, particularly at higher school levels, of taking people out of those communities and taking them to high schools or universities somewhere else—for example, a good institution like Batchelor College in the Northern Territory. It has a very appropriate system, but it is still difficult to bring people out of those remote communities and to take them there for that learning.

When we talk, firstly, about taking teachers into these communities, I can tell you that sometimes it is not idyllic coming to these places. There are times when some of these communities can, to an outsider arriving there to teach, feel like a war zone where they can be in fear of their lives. So, how much do you pay people? What do you do to entice them to these communities to teach, to open up this great opportunity in education to people, if that is what happens when they get there? I am not going to pick out particular communities, because it comes and goes. You can have a serious problem in one community this year and none at all next year. A lot of it is in the dynamics of the people involved: the people leading the community, the people who are the teachers, the people supporting them in the education department, the students, everybody else who is there. But if there is that risk, why would you go there, particularly with the levels of pay offered? They are higher, they do offer enticements—but, heck, it would have to be very good. We need to put value on this, because this is one of the key points.

Another issue is that there are also problems in fitting in the local leadership in the community. I remember some communities when we were looking at these problems, when we were involved in producing that report with Tom Harris. There were, for example, occasions in some communities where the school council we set up to try to empower the local community to support their school actually wound up being perceived by the community council as a threat to its sovereignty and control over the local community. In that case I recall the main issue was alcohol, because the community council, which was basically male dominated, was very keen to operate a wet canteen in that community. Then up sprang the school council, which was dominated by women—and I can tell you that in many cases the prime driving force supporting their children in schooling are the women in these communities; it varies, but that is largely a generalisation that I would hold to. Because they were opposing a wet canteen those people were perceived as the threat, and there was a ruction, there was an explosive division in that community over that whole question. All of these are serious and very difficult problems.

There are also problems with traditional customs themselves. Some of these communities are divided into what are called skin groups and so on. There are traditional customs, if you go back to the old times, that say that this skin group would not sit in the same shade as people from that skin group. What happens when the kids then are being expected to go into the same classroom? Or if, under the enlightened sorts of programs we have, there are local trained teachers from that community and teachers are from one group, what happens with the people from the other group? Are they expected to push their traditional custom aside and appear in the classroom with this person from the other group?

I am not saying that in any way we should throw it all away and forget it because of this problem; we have got to persist. But these are the reasons why we are not making progress. We sometimes hear bald generalisations. The member opposite did say that bilingual education programs are good. That may be true, but we have to put them in the context in which they exist. We have to be prepared to support them where they are effective, and where they are not effective we should not indulge people by just running those programs regardless. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the remarks made by my colleague the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, and the amendment which he has moved. The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 is designed to provide continued funding for the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program from 1 January 2001. It is also designed to implement the government's new National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy. The bill sets down a broad range of objectives, and this was reflected in the remarks made by the preceding speaker and comments made by the minister in introducing the bill and in discussion around it: that funding for this strategy will be performance based with priority given to a focus on literacy, numeracy and school attendance. There are many other objectives set down in the bill, and they are quite broad and comprehensive, but the focus seems to be narrowing more and more to these three goals.

speech.para: No-one can dispute that the goals of literacy, numeracy and school attendance are important. They are necessary but not sufficient conditions for the advancement of the education of indigenous children and adults in the Australian community. If they become too narrow a focus then we will lose some of the balance needed to advance comprehensively across a range of educational objectives. This is why I am so concerned about the point raised by the member for Dobell, and reflected in his amendment, that an extremely worrying difference between this bill and the bill which it replaces is that it lacks vital information enabling the parliament to monitor the conditions and distribution of money to education providers. It neither reproduces the table of per capita amounts payable to different types of education providers—preschools, schools, vocational education; such a table is included in the current act—nor sets out the conditions which will attach to agreements made with education providers. Certainly I believe one of those two is required, and that is what the shadow minister has set down quite specifically in his second reading amendment and what is covered in the committee stage amendments, of which he has given notice. Part 1 of the amendment refers to:

quote.para: (a) the failure of the Government to provide accurate details of proposed funding under this Bill; and
(b) the declining level of public and Parliamentary accountability ...

speech.para: Those go to my first concern, and they are stated quite distinctly. The second part of the member for Dobell's amendment to the second reading calls on the government to clarify the details of the distribution and release draft guidelines. I want to emphasise particularly (c) and (d) of part 2 of the amendment, which call on the government to:

quote.para: (c) commit to a regular, detailed report to Parliament in relation to Commonwealth indigenous education expenditure; and
(d) demonstrate a genuine commitment to improving educational outcomes for indigenous Australians by providing information in an open and transparent manner.

speech.para: Here we have a bill which appears to give the minister unfettered discretion in the distribution of funding between different levels of education and between government and non-government providers and in no way allows for the parliament to have regular access to a detailed assessment of how that discretion is being exercised—and we must have that. It is a prerequisite not just for some esoteric point of parliamentary reporting requirement and nicety but so that the concerns this money may not be appropriately distributed can be checked. It is inherent in a democratic process that people should have information to assess whether funding is being distributed appropriately. Of course simply providing the information does not mean that we will all agree. We may get a set of data from the minister that says, `This is how it is done,' and the majority of the members in the House might agree with that or the opposition might not or some of the Independents might not or one or two members might have an alternative view. But it will then be an informed debate, and that is the apprehension we have, which is reflected in the amendment.

There is a related worrying concern that the bill gives the minister power to recover money if so far unspecified conditions or an unspecified condition of an agreement are breached. Ultimately the Commonwealth has to have that power. If we enter into an agreement for people to perform certain functions in return for money from the Commonwealth and those functions are not performed, the Commonwealth has to have the capacity to reclaim that money. But what is the framework within which that recovery might be made? More particularly—and this is my other, more general concern—this bill, this lack of framework and the circumstances under which recoveries might be made appears not to recognise reality on the ground in indigenous communities. This sort of out-of-touch approach is one of the things that causes me concern, and about which I want to take a little bit of time.

I would like the minister to explain how he intends to deal with situations where providers who take every care to meet the required performance targets have nevertheless failed to do so for reasons beyond their control. What I mean by that is not again some generalised concern about accountability—although that is fundamental—but that when you have problems in literacy, numeracy or attendance in a community it often is not a product of an inadequacy in the education service provider—if we strip away the jargon—in the school; it often and more usually reflects a profound problem in the community that is leading to that outcome. This is most easily seen when you deal with the issue of attendance. I contend that when you see data throwing up attendance problems in schools in a particular community or communities it is more likely to be a red light flashing saying, `Here is a community with serious problems to which the government should give special attention and perhaps apply extra resources to meet those serious problems leading to this outcome,' rather than suggesting that the failure to achieve the attendance requirements means the funding for the school should be stripped away.

Attendance is very important. I have been to communities in the past, and also during the brief period in which I have been shadow minister responsible for indigenous affairs, and spoken to principals of schools. I have a particular principal in mind—a very concerned, committed principal—and when I asked, `What is the biggest problem in this school?' her concern was attendance. She was concerned about the implications for her school of the requirements of this legislation. But it was clear from the discussion—I do not want to pretend to be an expert about the school; there may be some changes that should be made there and that is for others to judge—that the principal drivers of the attendance problem were buried deep in the broader social and economic issues confronting the community and not in the school itself.

That is why the Labor Party strongly prefer that, rather than taking this punitive approach, we take a more constructive approach to addressing the particular education needs of indigenous people. I think ultimately the Commonwealth has to have the capacity to say, `You entered into an agreement with us and you are not fulfilling that agreement, so you should return the money.' We must have that because we are the custodians of the taxpayers' money. But it is not a good place to start, although it is a place in which we must ultimately be prepared to finish. I do not in any way wish to argue that numeracy, literacy and attendance are not urgent—that they are not pressing issues in some indigenous communities—nor would I argue that it is not a matter of urgency to see improvements made in indigenous education. Threatening the funding of education providers with as yet unknown guidelines does not attract itself to me as being the preferred way to getting results that go to the broader objectives, because literacy, numeracy and attendance are not the goal; they are the signposts towards the goal.

The goal is—I will put it more generally, and the bill, in its statement of objects, seeks to reflect this—to enhance the outcomes for young indigenous Australians from the education system to allow them to make more choices about their lives and about their employment, and to allow them to make more choices culturally and about the way in which their community operates—to empower them. It seems to me that there is a serious danger, and it is not unique to this bill, of our setting signposts along the way towards a general social goal and our aiming for the signposts instead of for the goal. Those things which are measurable could become the goals themselves and interfere with the broader achievement of profoundly important social objectives. It appears from the contents of this bill, and from the comments which have been made about it, that funding will be tied to essentially numerical outcomes—attendance, numeracy and literacy. That runs the risk, if it is applied as it appears on the face of it, of our not taking into account the appropriateness of the education or the quality of the outcomes. If we cannot see the guidelines, we cannot be reassured that that is not the case on the face of it. It does appear to be a serious cause of concern. As I have said, problems in achieving benchmarks in numeracy, literacy and attendance are not necessarily the fault of the school; they are often symptomatic of problems and disadvantage in the community. This is not a unique circumstance to indigenous communities, but it is especially true there. This was pointed out this year by the independent review of indigenous education in the Northern Territory and by the national inquiry into rural and remote education. Both reports referred to the broader causes of indigenous disadvantage in education: for example, the way in which poor health contributes to educational disadvantage, and the strong links between poverty, ill health and low education attendance.

There are other problems that we need to address and focus on. I want, in the time available, to deal with them briefly and then put them in a broader context in relation to funding. For example, in many indigenous communities there is no access to secondary schooling. It is estimated that half the indigenous secondary school age students in the Northern Territory are in non-graded programs taught at community education centres by primary trained teachers. There are problems with high turnover of staff and understaffing, there are problems with lack of housing and there are problems with lack of professional development and training and lack of appropriate cross-cultural training for teachers. These things can result—even with the best will in the world of individual teachers, who are usually well motivated; that is why they go to these areas—in poor educational outcomes for indigenous students. There are also things which are not so evident at first glance: the lack of appropriate available or affordable transport and communications infrastructure can disadvantage the educational outcomes of indigenous students. Many remote communities do not have easy access to transport to get their children to school, let alone the advantages of computers or IT to breach the distance and disadvantage barriers should they get to school. Given these formidable barriers to indigenous students participating effectively in the education system, this bill seems a rather simplistic response to the application of funds available for indigenous education. As I have said, this bill ignores the reality of life on the ground for indigenous communities. It is out of touch.

I have had calls in recent days asking that I express concern about the way in which ministers of this government are out of touch with the community on the profound issue of reconciliation. Callers are concerned about the attitude of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, who is, I think, in his comments in international media, reflecting views that are entirely inappropriate for a minister responsible for reconciliation. This is a democracy—he can hold any view he likes—but if he wishes to advance the cause of reconciliation this advocacy is a profound setback.

Similarly, I am concerned about what the package of education measures which the parliament is considering now—of which this is a part—says about the priorities of this government for education. We have before the parliament at the moment a related proposition to this bill which says that, in round figures, $50 million extra will go to the 62 schools which used to be categorised as category 1 schools because they are considered to be the wealthiest schools in this country. There is a serious debate, which my colleague the member for Dobell is pursuing effectively and forthrightly, about whether the new classification properly measures which are the most advantaged schools. That debate will continue to be pursued. Let me, for the moment, put that to one side and assume that we all know that the Kings School and Geelong Grammar—those sorts of schools—are amongst the 62 wealthiest in the country. The government has a package of measures before it which will give to 62 schools an extra $50 million. Who could argue that Australian social, economic and educational objectives would be better achieved by giving $50 million to those 62 category 1 schools than by identifying 62 high need schools in the most disadvantaged communities, and the most disadvantaged students in this country, and saying, `We can apply that $50 million to those people so that the most serious educational disadvantage in this country, the education problem that is contributing most starkly to the problem of economic and social disadvantage, can be addressed'? If you put to any Australian how $50 million targeted specifically at schools could better serve the national interest—would we give it to the 62 most advantaged schools in this country or the 62 most disadvantaged schools in this country?—who would argue that the government has got its priorities wrong? This is what goes to the heart of my concern about this bill ignoring the realities of life in this country, particularly on the ground for indigenous communities.

I am concerned about the matter raised by the member for Calwell regarding the impact on indigenous languages and cultures of this bill if the priorities are reflected too narrowly and tightly around some of the objectives, although the objectives of the bill do say some positive things about indigenous culture. I hope that is reflected in the guidelines, but it has not been reflected in the rhetoric surrounding them. I am also concerned that the bill and the guidelines may not pursue the objective of improving local community involvement and indigenous organisational involvement in educational policies and priorities. I am not sure why it is that the minister in a letter to state education ministers has promised to assess the contributions of state and territory indigenous education consultative bodies to indigenous educational policy. I hope this is not another move to marginalise that contribution. My concerns with this bill are that it misses the point, that it lacks a broader vision, that it reflects distorted priorities and that it points at the signposts about educational disadvantage but not the destination. I support the amendment proposed by my colleague the member for Dobell.

talk.start.para: —It seems to me that almost every week on Australian television screens the government sustains a bitter attack on its policies towards Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. We live in a democracy and people are entitled to their views and to put their case. I simply want to say that the bill that is before the House now, the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000, reflects in part the truth about the government's policies towards the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. The truth is this: in this financial year, 2000-01, the Howard coalition government will spend a record $2.3 billion on indigenous specific initiatives. To that amount can be added state and territory expenditure, mining royalties, land councils, universities and other sundry bodies which contribute another $800 million towards indigenous specific spending, giving a total of over $3 billion this year.Of course, that does not include other spending on indigenous people from non-indigenous specific sources. Over the past 15 years or thereabouts, indigenous specific spending has totalled about $20 billion. Of the 390,000 Australians who identify themselves as indigenous, only 230,000 rely on government support. In comparable dollar terms, in 1970 the Commonwealth spent $60 million on indigenous programs. In 1980 it grew sixfold to $350 million. By 1990 it was $950 million, and in 2000-01 it is now $2.3 billion. This bill is the means to provide the government's indigenous targeted education program for the 2001-04 quadrennium, and it will provide the authority to appropriate some $591 million in grants to indigenous education providers over that quadrennium.

speech.para: It is also the truth that there is more to indigenous wellbeing than issues that deal with land rights, which is a subject that has occupied so much public attention. I recognise that for cultural, spiritual, historic and symbolic reasons land is important. But we should not expect too much from simply restoring land ownership. Land is not a panacea to the social and economic challenges facing indigenous communities. Similar social problems exist throughout the Aboriginal community whether they be in communities where land has been restored or where land has never been taken or where people have been irrevocably alienated from their traditional country. But the need for education, particularly basic literacy and numeracy, is universal. When I was very young, my father once said to me that education is the only salvation for being born a woman. But, as an adult, I believe that education is the only salvation for everyone. The South African leader Nelson Mandela who recently visited Australia once said, `There are two ways to break out of poverty. The first is by formal education and the second is by the worker acquiring a greater skill at his work and thus higher wages.' Here in Australia the courageous Aboriginal leader Noel Pearson has said, `The most important and powerful resource that an individual can have is education. Education is the resource which can most mobilise and empower an individual and a society.'

When it comes to the deeds of the government and not the words of its opponents, the government delivers. And it does not just deliver to the squeaky wheel: it is committed to delivering to the bottom end of the Aboriginal community, many of whom are still waiting to see more of a trickle down of the $20 billion spent over the past 15 years. During the parliamentary winter recess I was privileged to visit many Aboriginal communities and discovered that the Aboriginal people who are never heard in the public domain often hold very different views about their situation and needs from the people who are regular commentators on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.

This bill deals with education, and it is one of four key areas of targeted assistance. The others are health, housing and employment. Indigenous specific spending across all four areas is now higher than it has ever been. To say this does not mean that there is not much more to be done, but the fact remains that there have been major improvements in indigenous education outcomes. For example, the proportion of indigenous adults who have never attended school has fallen from 14 per cent in the mid-1970s to three per cent today. The proportion of indigenous children who complete secondary schooling has increased fourfold since the mid-1970s, from 8.6 per cent to 33 per cent. The proportion of indigenous Australians with post-secondary school qualifications has doubled in the last decade, and indigenous higher education enrolments have tripled over the same period.

I was privileged to have been able to visit an excellent Aboriginal community when I recently visited the Northern Territory, and that was the Daly River community. I was grateful to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Denis Burke, for facilitating my visit and for introducing me to one of the most magnificent women I think I have ever met. Her name is Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr-Baumann. Miriam-Rose is the elder of the Daly River community. She holds a masters degree in education and is the principal of the Daly River School. She is a gifted artist and, amongst other works, the stations of the cross in the community church were painted by her. She is not only a brilliant role model for her people but as well she is a brilliant role model for the rest of us and a living example of the benefits of education.

One of the policies that will stand to the lasting credit of this government and the present minister is the determination to tackle the problem of literacy and numeracy. This policy applies to both indigenous and non-indigenous communities, to child and adult, to employed and unemployed. I am sure that all members are aware of the old saying: you can give a man a fish and it will feed him for a day, but if you teach a man how to fish he can feed himself for a lifetime. Teaching literacy and numeracy is like being taught how to fish. One of the keys to this is school attendance, and if children do not attend school they will not benefit from the teaching that is available. When I was in the Territory I witnessed one very successful method of encouraging indigenous children to attend school. In a community that had a swimming pool, the policy was `no school, no pool', which seemed to work exceptionally well.

Strategies to address poor attendance rates among indigenous youth, along with other issues, like those raised by the Learning lessons report that followed the Collins review, were the basis for the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister earlier this year as part of the $27 million National Indigenous English Literacy and Numeracy Strategy. It is a cooperative effort by local communities, parents, schools and federal, state and territory governments. This strategy seeks to increase parent and community participation, enhance performance and outcomes monitoring, address poor hearing and other health issues, lift school attendance rates, improve teaching training and use more responsive classroom teaching methods. This will help to facilitate the development of national reports in key areas such as attendance rates, literacy and numeracy levels, retention rates and indigenous employment.
