Illiteracy and innumeracy impact on so many areas. They immediately narrow down employment opportunities. Unfortunately, for indigenous youth aged between 15 and 19 the unemployment rate is around 36 per cent. Overall, the unemployment rate for indigenous Australians is around 38 per cent. This is five times the rate of the general population. Without the community development employment projects that figure would blow out to 56 per cent. In 1980, the unemployment rate was 43 per cent. Despite two decades and billions of dollars of expenditure, the employment rates have not significantly improved. Illiteracy and innumeracy limit the information that a person receives, including information about basic life skills, and it leads to frustration. It affects self-esteem and narrows the options available to people. All of these are some of the contributing factors to family violence. Since 1990, indigenous deaths from family violence have been almost 30 per cent higher nationally than indigenous deaths in custody for the same period about which we hear so much. Indigenous children are five to eight times more likely than other children to be subject to abuse and neglect.

Education is also one of the escape routes from welfarism. Sit down money or money for nothing has been a destructive curse amongst indigenous people over the past 20 to 30 years. This has led the government to try to distinguish between measures that perpetuate welfare dependency and those that genuinely alleviate long-term disadvantage and inequality. Two years ago, the minister released a discussion paper entitled Removing the welfare shackles. The government's efforts are now being supported by a growing number of indigenous leaders because, like all Australians, indigenous people prefer work to welfare. Until there are real improvements in education, together with employment and economic participation, dependence on the `sweet lolly' of welfare will continue. To help eliminate the welfare need, all Australians must have equitable access to education, and that is what this bill will help to do.

There are a lot of exciting good news stories in indigenous education; it is not all doom and gloom. But it is a struggle at times for local community leaders, and I have been humbled by the courage of many ordinary indigenous Australians whom I have seen battling against the odds to change things at the base of the pyramid. These are the people we should be listening to. As I mentioned earlier, during the winter recess I was able to visit the Northern Territory and travel widely to meet and visit many indigenous Australians. At Alice Springs I was able to visit the Irrkerlantye Learning Centre. The centre advocates an intergenerational approach to education through a holistic model of community development. It began as an educational alternative for Aboriginal students in Alice Springs considered to be most at risk. These students are considered to be at risk for a number of reasons, including a high level of substance abuse, violence surrounding them, their involvement in the juvenile justice system and the dysfunctional and antisocial behaviour they often display. They are considered not likely to complete an accepted level of schooling.

This centre offers support for Arrernte family members between the ages of 11 and 60—and, yes, I said the ages of 11 and 60. Youth suicide has been an issue for many of these families, and many family members pass away, mainly due to renal disease. The family nature of the program evolved because grandmothers and staff felt inadequate about the impact they were having on the lives and behaviour of youth accessing the program when the focus was solely on youth and education. It was realised that the family situation of many of the young people created a variety of social problems that interfered with participation and attendance in education. As a result, many displayed dysfunctional behaviour. It was found to be almost impossible to engage students in accredited lock-step mainstream educational programs or to assist individuals and families to be more functional within the original approach. So the intergenerational and community development model was devised to enable staff and family members to have more effective tools to get to the heart of student and family issues and the difficulties they suffer by working with the whole family.

Through the thoughtful guidance of Sister Helen Parer and Nicole Traves, the program helps a participating family to set goals and plan a pathway to improved lifestyles and work with links to other agencies. Through employment on the program, families take a day-to-day active role in and responsibility for the learning process, which can include accredited and non-accredited courses aimed at the young people. It provides a positive role model for teenagers, and it allows parents to be in closer contact with their children in a constructive and purposeful learning environment. The learning programs and work activities provide the students and parents with an immediate positive option for the day, which reduces the incidence of substance abuse and other antisocial behaviour among adults and youth in the community. As a result, whole families have a plan and a focus to work towards, and this motivates individuals to engage actively in processes that can improve their lives.

The reason I refer to Irrkerlantye is that it highlights some of the problems that indigenous education faces and the need for targeted assistance. Many of the youth and adults who attend the Irrkerlantye centre simply do not access mainstream schools or courses or work for reasons that I will now just briefly touch upon. Many of these youth have limited literacy and language skills. Their reading and writing ages are five or more years below the level they should be. This simply prevents them from engaging with the mainstream curriculum at their appropriate age level in mainstream classes. Almost all at the Irrkerlantye centre come from economic situations that prevent them from attending school every day. Many of the young people know that if they do not get their hands on some cash during school hours they will be hungry for the rest of the week. Many school days are spent down the street chasing family members for money. The level of substance abuse that surrounds them and their overcrowded living conditions work against the disciplined habits like attending school. Evenings can be noisy and disturbed by drunken behaviour of others, and attending school the next morning is certainly not a priority.

As a result of their living conditions, many students arrive at school tired, angry, sad, hungry, sick and despondent. Many are undernourished and lack energy and concentration. Many have medical conditions such as sores and boils that need attention, and these factors have to be dealt with before students can engage in any meaningful learning. Many of the students at Irrkerlantye have been substance abusers. Some have been heavily involved in sniffing substances such as glue and spray paint. Others have been regular consumers of alcohol or marihuana. Their erratic behaviour often has a very disruptive effect on students wanting to engage in an academic program, and it places great pressures upon staff. In short, there are a number of indigenous youths who are a long way from engaging in mainstream educational programs without a major support system to assist them with their academic learning needs and their health and family issues.

I know that what I have just described is probably a worst case scenario, but the factors that apply at Irrkerlantye are to a greater or lesser extent widespread throughout Australia in indigenous communities and in many places are endemic to indigenous education. It concerns me that, despite approximately $3 billion that will be pumped into indigenous specific programs this year from the government and non-government sources, staff at indigenous educational institutions like Irrkerlantye will still have to spend most of their time trying to secure funding for the next three to 12 months. Despite this, they are the other face of indigenous affairs. This is the courageous face that gets on with providing and developing programs that work. This is the courageous face that delivers tangible benefits to people at the bottom of the indigenous pyramid. This is the courageous face that represents the bottom-up delivery approach rather than the United Nations committee top-down approach to indigenous affairs.

Personally, I would like to see more direct funding from the federal government to organisations like Irrkerlantye, because this is a bottom-up approach and it does assist indigenous people themselves in planning their futures on a holistic family intergenerational basis. It is different, but it actually empowers these people and it works, and I urge the government to commit greater funding to its support. I believe that we have turned the corner on indigenous affairs because the government is addressing the hard problems at the bottom end of indigenous communities, and the uncomfortable truth is beginning to emerge that hand-ups are better than handouts. This bill is about giving people a hand-up through the sustaining asset of education. I support the bill and commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to address my remarks to the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 which applies to the indigenous education strategic initiatives program—IESIP. It seeks to implement the new national indigenous literacy and numeracy strategy but is not, and I emphasise not, providing additional funds. I do not want to go into the other features of the legislation because they have been canvassed by others. Basically I do not want to repeat what others have said. I do want to make some comments about the contributions that have been made by my colleagues from the other side of the House.

speech.para: I must say that, while I welcome tourists into the Northern Territory who visit Aboriginal communities, I, as the member for the Northern Territory, having been elected first in 1987, have a great deal more experience and understanding of these issues than the collective wisdom of the whole of the other side of this parliament. While I invite them to visit regularly, I hope they come back with a slightly different impression from the one that has been exhibited here in this House today. I am left to wonder when I hear the remarks of the member for Hughes that lead us to believe that across the indigenous community in northern Australia alcohol is a problem and substance abuse is a problem. Of course, that is not the case.

It is certainly true that substance abuse is a problem for some people in some communities. It is certainly true that alcohol is a problem for some people in some communities. What ought to be understood is that alcohol consumption rates among Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory are less than alcohol consumption rates among non-Aboriginal people.

Let us be very clear about it. Let us not paint a canvas, one which we have seen painted by the member for Hughes and before her the member for Blair, that blames the victims. That is essentially what has happened here. I for one reject the notion absolutely. I will not stand in this place and hear the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory insulted in the way they have been by members of the government.

I am pleased that the member for Hughes has at least come away from Alice Springs understanding that you need to have special targeted programs for indigenous students. I am pleased with the program she looked at because it is appropriate to that group of people and is very successful. But I also heard her make an assertion about land ownership in her contribution. I have to say to the member for Hughes: you need to get your head around the relationship between land and education. I know it is difficult. It is difficult for me and it is difficult for most non-indigenous Australians. But what I suggest you do, if you want to see how land and culture are fundamental to successful educational outcomes, is visit Yirrkala in north-east Arnhem Land; and that not only you visit Yirrkala and look at the community education centre in that community but you talk to the Laynhapuy Homeland Schools and see how they have melded the curriculum so that land and culture are the basis of the curriculum. They bind the curriculum together and, as a result, what we have got is one of the most successful educational opportunities for indigenous Australians in remote areas.

When the member for Blair gets up here and trots out rubbish about travelling around the Northern Territory with Tom Harris—I remember Tom Harris—I say to the government that they should remember that the CLP government has been in power in the Northern Territory since 1978; that Tom Harris was a minister in the Northern Territory government responsible for education, and the member for Blair worked for him—and that the educational outcomes for indigenous students in the Northern Territory have been abysmal.

There are a number of reasons for that, not the least of which is the way they have robbed the till. We are seeing IESIP funds being made available. There are a number of issues—I will come back to the till in a moment—but let me just say this: this bill, of itself, offers inadequate protection for students in their communities if the provider, in this case the Northern Territory Education Department, does not deliver and funding is withdrawn because there is no alternative provider for most communities. Does this mean the community school should be penalised if the system fails to deliver? If that happens, then where do the kids go? What safeguard is there against failures by the system to deal with the real educational needs of indigenous people?

The answer to question No. 3 is that there is perennial failure because there is no attempt to really understand the needs of indigenous people. In the case of the Northern Territory, when we talk about the allocation of resources, what we know is that historically when IESIP funds have been made available to the Northern Territory government, they have pilfered 46.1 per cent of the total funds for their own purposes, notionally administrative costs. The rate of on-costs for other states and territories varies between four per cent and 18 per cent. That is highway robbery. They they have substituted this money. There has been massive substitution of money which has been given to improve Aboriginal education outcomes. That money is taken historically by the Northern Territory government's treasury and used for other purposes, maybe for education, but massive substitution takes place as a result.

Who is responsible for that? I say to the member for Blair that the people responsible for that were the minister he was working for, Tom Harris, and successive CLP governments. It has been very difficult, I have to say—and I had experience of this when we were in government—to make the Northern Territory government accountable for the funds it receives from the Commonwealth. That is why I am attracted to the proposition of the member for Hughes in respect of direct funding of community based organisations. I agree. Not only do I agree with that, but I agree also that what we should be doing is developing regional agreements with groups of Aboriginal communities about funding for education. Then we should be putting the proposition, perhaps, that once we reach an agreement on outcomes, we fund them directly and not through the Northern Territory government—allow them to make some choices about who delivers educational opportunities in the Northern Territory. The bottom line is, of course, Mr Deputy Speaker—you need to know this—that the Northern Territory government gets 80 per cent of its budget resources from Commonwealth outlays. It gets 80 per cent, in large part, because of the Grants Commission formula which says that, based on need, the Northern Territory on a per capita basis should receive around 4½ times that of the average per capita distribution across Australia. The reason for that distribution is to take account of the special needs of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, distance, geography and a whole range of other issues. But it is not translated on the ground in terms of funding going to Aboriginal education. The people responsible for this are those in the Northern Territory government. They are making these decisions.

I am sure the member for Hughes would not want to be associated with the member for Blair's contribution, because if she reads it, she will discover a contribution which was patronising and demeaning. Instead of accepting the failure of the system to provide appropriate resources in an appropriate way to Aboriginal communities across Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory, he sought to blame the victim. He disparaged cultural programs. He talked about special deals. I say to him and to every member of this House that what is required to deliver better educational outcomes is a better understanding of the needs of indigenous Australians and that, when ministers come to the table, they accept, despite what the member for Hughes says about the massive allocation of Commonwealth resources into indigenous affairs in this country, that those resources are substantially inadequate to meet current needs. But as the member for Fraser said in his contribution, if we want to improve educational outcomes, we have to improve many other opportunities. For example, education relies on decent health outcomes. That requires a massive improvement in environmental health.

The member for Hughes talked about overcrowding in housing. It is a reality across northern Australia. It is not uncommon to have 18, 19, or 20 people in a three-bedroom house. It is not uncommon for them to have an inadequate water supply. It is not uncommon—these are the poorest Australians—for them to be living on incomes of $180 a week, which is about what they receive from CDP. It is not uncommon. These are poor people.

There are massive health problems with many indigenous Aboriginal students in the Northern Territory when they attend school. One of the basic problems is hearing. Otitis media is endemic in Aboriginal schools. But does the education system seek to properly accommodate those deficiencies? It is not successful. It has not done it.

A range of initiatives could be taken to improve educational outcomes for indigenous students, but we have to understand that the government—in this case the minister—needs to rethink the way in which he is dealing with these issues. It is absolutely 100 per cent correct to say that you cannot get a job unless you have a decent education. In the years I have spent travelling around the bush in the Northern Territory, sitting down in the dirt having a chat with people, I have not met one Aboriginal person who does not want their child to have a job. I have not met one Aboriginal person who does not want their child to have a decent education. But almost to a person they are frustrated by the inability of governments to recognise the need and to provide the appropriate programs that will give successful outcomes.

Bob Collins in his report made clear the percentage of Northern Territory students achieving national reading benchmarks in 1988. For indigenous students in year 3 in urban schools it was 54 per cent; and in year 5, 36 per cent. For indigenous students in year 3 in non-urban schools, it was six per cent and in year 5 it was four per cent. For non-indigenous students in urban schools the figure was 82 per cent. Compare it. An outcome of 82 per cent for non-indigenous students in urban schools as against six per cent for indigenous students in non-urban schools. That is a national disgrace. On top of that, even if we had students who could read at their chronological age levels in the equivalent of year 7 or year 8, I cannot think of one Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory—and remember some have 2,000 people or more—that has a high school. It raises very serious questions about the ability of government to come to terms with its responsibilities at a state and at a federal level. What is clear—what is abundantly clear—is that the way to deal with this issue is not, as the member for Fraser said, by giving $52 million to category 1 private schools around this country at the expense of public education. The answer to this is to shift the distribution of funds so they address the needs of those most in need. In this instance it is very clear—those most in need in Australia are indigenous students, particularly those living in remote communities. There are insufficient resources being addressed to the problem and there is insufficient understanding of the cultural aspirations and needs of indigenous Australians and the circumstances in which they live.

There are strategies which could be adopted, but they require acceptance of local priorities. They require the acceptance that Aboriginal mothers and fathers share a common objective when it comes to education outcomes. It requires accepting that they, like every other Australian, want educational and job opportunities for their children. It requires acceptance of the need to spend additional resources for communications infrastructure, road infrastructure, housing infrastructure and health infrastructure to improve educational outcomes. That means a rethinking of the way in which we deal with indigenous education.

I said before that one mechanism for dealing with this is to develop a system of regional agreements—contracts, if you like—between those people providing the funds and services and those people receiving the services. And this should be done on the basis of agreed objectives and agreed outcomes. However, they should be aware that, for example, in the case of the Northern Territory, Arnhem Land was recently 27 teachers short in the public education system. This meant kids going without school. The reason they were short was insufficient housing for the teachers. Whose responsibility is that? That responsibility lies fairly and squarely with the Northern Territory government.

Unless you are fair dinkum and unless you are prepared to do things differently, and unless you are prepared to sit down and provide the resources that are clearly required to achieve the sorts of outcomes you want and the community wants, you will not be successful. I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this should be one of the key national priorities. This should be at the centre of any development of public policy in this nation: improving the lot of indigenous Australians.

Today, hopefully, the Prime Minister might actually get up in this parliament and say something meaningful about indigenous Australians instead of listening to what is coming out of the mouth of the minister who is responsible for reconciliation. Perhaps he might start by thanking indigenous Australians for their performance recently at the Olympic Games and for they way in which they have helped bind this nation—no thanks to the government. What the government needs to do now is rethink its strategy for Aboriginal education. This is not good enough.

talk.start.para: —It is important to gain an understanding of the progress or lack of progress over the last couple of decades in Australia in terms of Aboriginal education. On that point, the number of people assisted by Abstudy, which is a program to help Aboriginal people pursue post-secondary studies, rose from just 115 in 1969 to more than 24,000 in 1987, and the number assisted by ABSEC, which is a program to ensure that Aboriginal people have the opportunity to gain the necessary secondary school education to take advantage of Abstudy, rose from to 19,621 in 1973 to 26,183 in 1987. Those results caused the then minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, to claim, and I quote:

quote.para: Abstudy and related Commonwealth initiatives are generally recognised as the means by which so many Aborigines have been able to undertake higher education studies.

speech.para: But if we look at trends from that time onwards, the picture becomes more ambiguous. Some indicators since the mid- to late eighties suggest there have been improvements, and others suggest there has been a deterioration. In fact, in a 1998 paper devoted to the question of whether or not school retention and participation improved for indigenous students, two researchers, Michael Long and Tracey Frigo, analysed a set of measures and found:

quote.para: The answers to the question vary by State and measure. There are indication of both absolute and relative improvement in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory ... [but] ... any improvement in retention and participation has not been sufficiently strong to be detected by all the measures used in this report.

speech.para: They concluded:

quote.para: Despite the evidence of positive outcomes from individual programs for indigenous students in terms of engagement in learning and personal development, and despite government funding support for schools and individuals, school retention and participation for indigenous youth has not improved markedly in recent years in Australia.

speech.para: Similarly, R.G. Schwab found in a 1999 analysis that it was difficult to quantify national retention rates prior to 1994, but nevertheless concluded that:

quote.para: While there have no doubt been real improvements since 1989, it is important to note that indigenous apparent retention rates declined between 1994 and 1996 before beginning to recover and climb in 1997; they have yet to return to 1994 levels. This pattern appears more akin to recovery from a stall and decline than a trend to improvement.

speech.para: We need to ascertain where we are now. What is the result of a period of apparent improvement and then a period of apparent stagnation? I am able to report on that because, for the latest years for which statistics are available, the school drop-out rate before year 10 for indigenous Australians is 25 per cent and for non-indigenous Australians it is two per cent. So we have 25 per cent of indigenous Australians dropping out of school before year 10 and only two per cent of non-indigenous Australians.

In relation to year 12 retention rates, the proportion of indigenous Australians who completed year 12 is 30 per cent, compared with a percentage for non-indigenous Australians of up around 75 per cent. So there are huge gaps here between the educational attainment of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

Let us look at participation in education—school and post-school—in the 18 to 20 age bracket. The participation rate for indigenous Australians is approximately 31 per cent, and for non-indigenous Australians 58 per cent. The percentage of the population aged 15 and above with post-school qualifications, firstly for university degrees, is indigenous Australians, 2.2 per cent, and non-indigenous Australians, 11.2 per cent; diplomas, indigenous Australians 3.2 per cent, non-indigenous Australians 13.5 per cent; and trade qualifications, indigenous Australians 5.2 per cent and non-indigenous Australians 11.4 per cent.

This latest information paints a clear picture of very real disadvantage suffered by indigenous Australians in terms of education attainment. So we have to do something about it and this legislation seeks to do something about it. How successful it will be we may not in fact know, because of the lack of accountability measures in the legislation. It does appear to give the minister huge discretion in deciding where money will go in terms of boosting literacy and numeracy for indigenous Australians. Previous speakers from the Labor side have expressed grave concern, and the second reading amendment goes to that very issue—that is, the lack of accountability.

I agree that performance based provision of funding is a good idea in principle, but what does performance actually amount to? How is it defined? Well, it is going to be defined in agreements reached between the minister and relevant education providers, but there are no guidelines for that. So this parliament is being asked to approve legislation which gives the minister very great discretion in setting the terms of those agreements and, disturbingly, the minister can withdraw funds if he judges the performance of particular schools as being not up to scratch. Hopefully that would be against objectively established criteria, but we need to be assured of that.

One issue to which other speakers have referred is the issue of attendance. It would seem to make sense that if attendance is low, and much lower than set out in an agreement, there is a real problem. But to deal with that problem by just withdrawing the funding may not be the appropriate solution. There could be more fundamental reasons for the low attendance than simply blaming a school for it and then withdrawing the funding and punishing the local communities accordingly.

My concern is that the lack of accountability here may give real expression to the minister's ideology in relation to education funding in general. I want to see this funding allocated on objective bases not on ideological bases. I do not think we have any assurances that that would be the case because this minister must be arguably the most ideological minister in the government ranks. He has particular obsessions and he gives effect to them through legislation. He would be very pleased for this legislation to be passed because it gives him such wide discretion in giving effect to his ideology in terms of preference for funding for non-government schools over government schools and, indeed, in terms of preference for funding wealthy non-government schools over needy non-government schools.

That is what is happening with legislation that has already been debated in this parliament. That is what has been revealed by the shadow education minister. My great concern is that the expression of that ideology in that particular piece of legislation, the schools funding legislation, will be carried over into this particular legislation where he has very, very wide discretion indeed.

In understanding some of the reasons why Aboriginal young people might have such relatively low retention rates in schools, I draw attention to a table that has been provided by the department and which recently came to my attention. I think it is quite important. In terms of year 12 completions, if we look at the distinction between students in urban, rural and remote areas, it turns out that in urban areas 67 per cent of students complete year 12. So two-thirds of students complete year 12 in urban areas, but in remote areas it is only 54 per cent, just over half. It seems obvious that remoteness itself is a source of disadvantage in terms of educational outcomes. Secondly—and this should not come as any real surprise either—if we look at the same year 12 completion rates, this time by socioeconomic status, a table provided by the department reveals that of those students from areas of low socioeconomic status only 56 per cent completed year 12 in 1996, whereas of those students of high socioeconomic status 77 per cent completed year 12. By both indicators, remoteness and socioeconomic status—for which basically read `wealth'—year 12 retention rates are much lower in remote and low socioeconomic areas, that is, disadvantaged areas.

Aboriginal people tend to be in remote areas and/or in low socioeconomic areas, so these would be contributing factors themselves plus there would be other factors obviously contributing to the low outcomes for indigenous Australians. We need to understand those as a guide to working out what are the best policy responses.

I want to raise a couple of possibilities here. The member for the Northern Territory has just spoken about the virtues of regional agreements and, I think, that sort of approach may well have a lot of merit because we can then look at the particular circumstances of indigenous children in that region and come up with an agreement that makes sense for that region, is tailor-made for that region. This sounds to me to be very similar to Labor's proposal for education priority zones. I think that that model of education priority zones, which has been adapted from the UK model under the Blair Labour government, may have some merit in addressing the problems of indigenous education in this country.

Other speakers, including the member for the Northern Territory, have identified a very important contributing factor to relatively low education attainment for Aboriginal Australians; that is, nutrition and health generally. Labor has been advocating for some time, through the shadow community services minister and other ministers, the concept of early intervention; that is, getting in very early, even in the preschool years and identifying what problems are likely to lead to children not achieving a really good educationproblems that may stem from the home environment and other contributing factors, such as nutrition, and dealing with those through home visiting programs, parenting programs and so on.

In that context I refer to the Headstart program in the United States, which has been running now for at least a couple of decades. In terms of the evaluation of the Headstart program there are differing results for different programs because it is funded centrally or nationally, but it is implemented at a state level and different programs are implemented by different states. Some of them have proved very successful; some of them have proved less successful or even unsuccessful. It seems to me that we can draw from the experience of the Headstart program in the United States and from the various evaluations that have been done and pick out the best features, because they are designed to directly address social disadvantage and make sure that kids get to school with the right opportunity to progress through school successfully.

In many of the Headstart programs nutrition is a really important component because, again—as the member for the Northern Territory said—children who have poor nutrition obviously find it pretty hard to perform well at school when there are other things on their mind—the fact that they just do not feel very well or that they feel hungry.

I would like to see this parliament embrace the concept of the Headstart program. I see great similarities between that and the concept of education priority zones and the member for the Northern Territory's concept of regional agreements. Surely as a parliament we can, in a spirit of bipartisanship, work out the best programs for indigenous Australians, for Australians located in remote areas and for Australians in disadvantaged areas in which many indigenous Australians are located. That is what I would like to contribute by way of this debate. There are models and successful programs nationally and, particularly, internationally, and we should take the opportunity as a parliament to examine those programs and to pick out the best. We can then draw from the best experiences and ensure to the greatest possible extent that we do not make the mistakes that have been made in other countries.

Perhaps I could finish on a somewhat philosophical note. In my view what this country needs to face is a task of redistribution. In the old days it used to be the case that people of the Left philosophy argued for the redistribution of income. In a progressive philosophy the most important thing was that income should be redistributed. I still happen to agree with that. But the best of redistributing income is to redistribute opportunities.

What we really should be focusing on is the redistribution of opportunity, because opportunity in Australia continues to be concentrated in already advantaged and privileged areas, and in disadvantaged areas there is a lack of opportunity. What goes to the heart of providing opportunity is a decent education. I would certainly like to see all members of this parliament embrace the notion of redistributing opportunities so that we have equality of opportunity. I have never been an advocate of equality of income. I do not believe all Australians should have the same income. There are a lot of choices they make but there are a lot of choices people in disadvantaged areas do not get to make. In many disadvantaged areas they do not get the opportunity. That is what we should be doing as a nation: ensuring that opportunity is distributed equally, so that every child in this country has the same opportunity irrespective of whether they are indigenous or non-indigenous and irrespective of the wealth of their parents. That is the philosophy that I think both the coalition and the Labor Party should be able to embrace. Unfortunately we are not at that point. I believe that the coalition, particularly through this minister, has a different philosophy. But there are many good people in the coalition and I at least call on those to start thinking in terms of the task of redistributing opportunity in this country.

talk.start.para: —This is a very important piece of legislation. It is very important especially today and especially in the circumstances in which we find ourselves because it deals with indigenous education. Most of the speakers have said that indigenous education is a key issue when we are talking about the future of the indigenous people and their role in Australian society and the whole process of reconciliation. If you read the fine words of the minister in presenting the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000, you would think, `Well, there are some very good objectives and intentions in this bill,' and one might say, `Why not wholly support it?'

speech.para: The problem is that, when one gets to the specifics of what is actually going to be delivered through this bill, there are many shortcomings in the way in which it has been formulated to this point. We need to bring a background to this matter and the background is that the government has promised a lot in this area of indigenous affairs, including education, and delivered little.

One of the areas which is most significant is the whole question of maintaining the culture and traditions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That is the most important matter if you are looking at education for this group of people, at helping them to maintain the culture and traditions which give them an identity, which make them what they are and which allow them to continue to contribute to the rich manifold of multicultural Australia.

I asked a question earlier this year of the minister for Aboriginal affairs. It was a three-part question and it had to do with what the government is doing to ensure that we do in fact maintain Aboriginal cultural traditions. The third part of the question was: `Does the government have programs to educate indigenous children about the cultural traditions of their Aboriginal backgrounds? If so, what are the details?' That is the question I asked the minister. I am sure the whole nation would be amazed to read this answer from the minister:

quote.para: ATSIC has no specific programs to educate indigenous children about the cultural traditions of their Aboriginal backgrounds.

speech.para: No specific programs. So in answer to a question about what we are doing to educate Aboriginal children about their own backgrounds in our education program, the government freely admits that it has no programs. This is an outrage and it is because of this outrage that it is essential, if this bill is to mean anything, that it actually have some teeth and some substance, that it actually require the teaching of Aboriginal culture, Aboriginal tradition and Aboriginal languages for those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. It is for this reason that I am moving an amendment in the committee stage to try to ensure that.

I am also going to support the Labor Party's amendments, which also seek to ensure that the government specifies in this chamber the guidelines which it is going to seek in this rubric of Aboriginal education, because if the government is not going to include culture, tradition, heritage and Aboriginal languages, then it is failing in its responsibility and it is failing in the objectives which it promulgated at the beginning of the bill. It has been asked by a number of members: where are the guidelines that the minister intends to put into place when he negotiates agreements with the state governments about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education? Where are those guidelines? We do not have them, nor have we got any indication from the minister what requirements he is going to have in relation to this matter.

You might say, `Well, why should the minister make requirements?', but this bill does make requirements. This bill says that there will be requirements in literacy, numeracy and school attendance. We do not have any problem with that, but the problem is the failure to have any requirement in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and traditions for the children. Why do I say this? This is important. We have all had to face, as a nation, the pain of the stolen generation saga, which involved Aboriginal children being taken from their mothers at a very early age and being brought up in the so-called Western tradition—completely away from their Aboriginal cultural traditions. The government is asked to apologise for this act. Never mind the human act of separating mothers from children—that itself is tragic—but what about the cultural act; the act of separating them from their culture so that they no longer are able to understand or have connections with their cultural traditions? What about that? Do we not have a responsibility not merely to say sorry but to restore the damage?

Unfortunately the minister for reconciliation has been criticised—it is not unfortunate that he has been criticised, but what is unfortunate are the comments he made. When he was asked about this question, he said in Le Monde newspaper:

quote.para: At the time, the decision to remove part-Aboriginal children from their families was made because it was considered that their mothers could not offer them the desirable educational opportunities. Many of these children in fact received a much better education than a lot of other Aboriginal children.

speech.para: A much better education according to whom, Minister? A much better education so that they forgot about their Aboriginal heritage and background? Is this what he meant? The minister has been condemned today throughout the media and everywhere because this comment, together with other comments that he has made about Aboriginal civilisation and Aboriginal culture, reflect the idea that Western society is far superior to Aboriginal culture and tradition. After all, they did not even have the wheel and, therefore, because they did not have the wheel in their technology, their culture does not have anything to offer.

What sort of an absurd statement is that? Has the minister studied the richness of Aboriginal culture and tradition? Has he studied the philosophy, the belief systems, the views of society, the views of human beings, the views of the environment which the Aboriginal people had in their cultural traditions? No, he has not done that.

He has not done that or, if he has, he has not taken the message. The message is that we could learn a lot from the values and belief systems of the Aboriginal people, especially about respecting each other as human beings, especially about how to organise society, especially about believing in the spiritual side of life, not thinking that the only thing in life is material goods. All those things are in Aboriginal culture and tradition. The minister has done nothing to promote this with his comments. In fact, his comments are disgraceful. He ought to come into this chamber and apologise for those comments and apologise for his concept of Aboriginal culture and tradition. How can there be reconciliation if the view is that we are the far superior culture and `You lot over there, well, never mind'? Is this the attitude? Is that going to lead to reconciliation?

In just the last few days we saw how the world appreciated the richness and the symbolism of Aboriginal culture when we saw the opening and closing ceremonies of the Olympic Games. So we have the minister making the opposite point. I am afraid that if this bill goes through without amendment, we will not be able to achieve some of the intentions expressed by the minister in relation to Aboriginal tradition and culture. This parliament needs assurances in the bill that we are going to be able to achieve those goals.

It is for that reason that I will move an amendment requiring curriculums under the legislation to contain a minimum 20 per cent Aboriginal or indigenous programs in general. It is a very low level, but at least it is a minimum to start teaching Aboriginal culture, heritage and tradition in the curriculums under this act. This is the view which is supported by Aboriginal leaders. I want to read from a letter I received today from the chairman of ATSIC, Mr Geoff Clark. He says:

quote.para: Dear Dr Theophanous
I understand that you are to propose amendments to the government's Bill, the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000.
While I look forward to seeing the details of the amendments when they are tabled I would like to provide some comments on your proposal.

Firstly, I must comment that ATSIC does have a role of advising the government and the Ministers on legislation affecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and will continue to provide as much positive input in that role to the government, whenever legislation is in formulation.

Secondly, ATSIC already has broad policy and strategic objectives which indicate our strong support for the inclusion of indigenous cultural and heritage education for our people. For example, the ATSIC Corporate Plan states, inter alia:
ATSIC will aim to be well placed to protect our existing land, sea and cultural heritage rights, as well as extend the formal recognition of these rights;
ATSIC will ensure indigenous people are aware of and can exercise their rights, by funding education awareness campaigns on rights for indigenous peoples;
ATSIC will promote the recognition of the right to use and be educated in indigenous languages in Australia.

Thirdly, I note that the UN Human Rights Committee, in its recent examination of Australia's compliance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights asked the Australian representatives how Australian law guarantees the continuation of indigenous culture and livelihood for the future—a question which unfortunately was not, and cannot be, given a positive response.

Given my preceding comments, I would like to add my own view that the proposed Bill will be insufficient if it does not carry provisions for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our own languages, of our own social Responsibilities and of our distinct indigenous cultural heritage. These are surely the fundamental components of our identity as Indigenous Peoples.

You may take from these comments that I am in support of your intention to strengthen the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 by including quantifiable targets for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people regarding our own cultural heritage.

I look forward to following the progress of your amendments during the parliamentary debate and I will ensure that ATSIC remains available to advise the government, the parliament and members of the parliament on this most important policy issue.
Yours sincerely
Geoff Clark

speech.para: These comments from Mr Clark reflect the great importance which ATSIC puts on Aboriginal education and for education to be targeted in, as he says, `our own languages, our own social responsibilities and our distinct indigenous cultural heritage.' This is what the chairman of ATSIC says. It is very important that this bill not go through merely as a vague bill, but that it have specific targets and specific rules and guidelines for indigenous education. It is important that it deal not merely with matters such as literacy and numeracy, which it ought, but also this dramatically important issue of helping Aboriginal people maintain their identity and culture by ensuring that the children are taught in the schools about these traditions. As Mr Clark says, `These are surely the fundamental components of our identity as indigenous peoples.'

I believe members should support an amendment which I will move in the committee stage to ensure that these guidelines are in force in the area of indigenous education. But I also want to say that if the government does not show some more goodwill in relation to this matter, this will be a further example of the government's behaviour in recent times in relation to indigenous affairs. As I said before, the attitude which the minister for reconciliation has shown in relation to Aboriginal culture and civilisation must be repudiated by the Prime Minister, by this parliament and by the minister himself in apologising to this House. This is a necessary step for us to get back on track the process of reconciliation. But another important step is to support amendments to this bill which will put into place guidelines and targets in relation to the protection of Aboriginal cultural heritage through the use of the education system to ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children are actually taught about these cultural traditions and about their heritage.

I have spoken on a number of occasions in this House about the richness of indigenous culture. Having some philosophical background, I have studied the philosophy and belief systems of the Aboriginal people. I can say that this is a very rich cultural tradition which needs to be strongly supported by this parliament. In fact, we should have in this bill and in general education bills a requirement to teach the whole Australian nation about our Aboriginal community, about the value and richness of Aboriginal culture and about the way in which they have been able to teach us certain fundamental values about humanity, spirituality, respecting one another and the way in which we should live our lives in society. These things in Aboriginal culture ought to be respected. I support the Labor Party amendment.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services will be absent from question time today due to ill health. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry will answer questions on his behalf.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister recall his letter to me which I received this morning in which he admitted misleading 3AW listeners about the size of the funding increases for his list of 67 wealthy schools? Prime Minister, can you explain why extremely wealthy schools, like the King's School, Melbourne Grammar and Geelong College, which are currently category 1 schools, are not even on your wealthy schools list?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Obviously, with a question like that, I would have to go and look at the list before I gave a specific answer. But the basis of the question of course is to continue the mythology of the Labor Party attack on the government—that is, that in some way the policies of this government are designed to help the wealthy schools of this country.

answer.para: The policies of this government are designed to promote choice. I wonder whether the Labor Party continues to oppose the opening of schools like the Thomas Hassall Anglican College in Hoxton Park in the western suburbs of Sydney where, I am advised, the fees for a primary school student are $2,200 a year and for a secondary school student $2,600 a year. There are many working families in Australia who are willing to make the sacrifice to send their children to schools with that fee structure but have no hope of being able to afford to send their children to schools that have a higher fee structure. It is schools like the Thomas Hassall Anglican College in Hoxton Park that are exemplars of the new schools policy which you voted against.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I was going to raise a point of relevance, but has the Prime Minister concluded?
—Has the Prime Minister concluded his answer?
—I have finished.

—I have a question for the Minister for Finance and Administration. Would the minister inform the House of the government's approach to the privatisation of Telstra? Is he aware of any alternative policies in this area?

talker.name: Fahey, John, MP
Mr FAHEY
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I am grateful to the honourable member for Moreton for asking me that question because it gives me an opportunity to state very clearly the approach that the government has taken in relation to the sale of Telstra. The government has been totally honest and up front in respect of the sale of Telstra. Before the 1996 election, we indicated quite clearly to the Australian public that we would sell one-third of Telstra, and we did. Before the 1998 election, we indicated quite clearly to the Australian public that we would not sell more than 49 per cent of Telstra until such time as an independent inquiry reported on the adequacy of service levels, and we have kept that commitment as well. On that basis, I noted with some interest statements made by Labor over the past several months. I note that on 18 April last the Leader of the Opposition promised:

quote.para: No Labor government presided over by me will continue the privatisation of Telstra, full stop.

answer.para: I also noted the documents flying out of the Labor Party national conference held in July in Hobart. Those documents stated:

quote.para: Labor opposes the sale of Telstra and will not sell any further portion of the company.

answer.para: I did not believe that, and I do not believe that the Australian people should believe it any longer either, because we know that the Leader of the Opposition is the man who privatised Qantas, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Commonwealth Bank. He would sell Telstra in a minute. If we once had suspicions about this, we no longer do because this has been confirmed. Labor is hatching a secret plan to privatise Telstra, and that plan is revealed in the 8 September edition of Telco Weekly. This is a publication issued by that pre-eminent investment house Macquarie Bank, and it states clearly that Labor is actively considering the break-up and privatisation of Telstra. Let me quote from the Macquarie report:

quote.para: The ALP is considering such a break-up for Telstra.
Our discussions with senior members of the Opposition has indicated that a split between Telstra's network and its retail businesses is an option being considered by the ALP.

answer.para: It goes on:

quote.para: It has been mooted that the government could 100% own the network business. The retail business could then be either fully or partially privatised.

answer.para: The report states further:

quote.para: ... such an idea was discussed by the previous ALP government when Paul Keating was Prime Minister.

answer.para: So the whistle has been blown on Labor. The whistle has been blown on the Leader of the Opposition. They are representing to the Australian people that they are opposed to the sale of Telstra—to `any further portion' of Telstra were the words of the Leader of the Opposition—but at the same time they have been holding clandestine meetings with investment bankers on how to break up and sell off the company.

I think it is time that the Leader of the Opposition confirmed to the Australian people what the true position of Labor is. I call on the Leader of the Opposition to come clean on the details of any plans to break up and sell off Telstra, to come clean on why unnamed senior members of the opposition are discussing with investment banks the break-up of Telstra, and to disclose which senior members of the opposition have discussed the break-up of Telstra with Macquarie Bank. There is some degree of continuity in those words in that particular report of a certain author who sits on the front bench of the opposition. Some particular theme runs through that. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to come clean. I do not expect an answer from the Leader of the Opposition. He has a convenient memory about his attendances at meetings where the sell-off or break-up of Telstra is discussed. We see here a grubby, politically expedient approach by the opposition on the sale of Telstra, and that of course is something that the Australian people deserve the truth on, just as they deserve the truth on roll-back, and we never hear about that. It is time that the Leader of the Opposition told the Australian people what he really will do if he ever gets the opportunity in government. It is the old story: say one thing when you are in opposition, but, if you ever get a chance at government, in one minute you will be flogging off Telstra, as that report proves. I table Telco Weekly.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to answer the questions that were put to me.
—What? I am not to be given leave to answer the questions that you put to me. You must have such a strength of belief in
—The Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.
—Oh, well, I will avail myself of—
—The Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.

—But, Mr Speaker, when you are asked a series of questions and the government do not have the guts to listen to the answers, what credibility do you give them? Since I am gagged on that front, my question is to the Prime Minister.
—The Leader of the Opposition will not reflect on the chair; he will come to his question.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the King's School in Parramatta, which is not even on the Prime Minister's list of 67 wealthy schools, is a category 1 school which charges $11,595 a year in fees? Are you also aware that the King's School advertises the following facilities: 15 cricket fields, five basketball courts, 12 tennis courts, 13 rugby fields, three soccer fields, a 50-metre swimming pool, a gym, a boat shed, two climbing walls and an indoor rifle range? Prime Minister, do you really believe it is fair to increase public funding to the King's School by $1.4 million a year when other schools with greater needs receive no increases at all?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his attempt—I think at his great political cost—to polarise this debate within the Australian community. The debate is about freedom of choice for parents, not the creation of an envy driven society, which is precisely the attempt which is being made. The Leader of the Opposition rails about need. I think the Leader of the Opposition should try to justify a policy approach by his party that would deny to working families in the western suburbs of Sydney the opportunity of sending their children to an independent school of their choice, which is what our policy is about. Our policy is about expanding options for parents. Our policy is not about aggregating comparisons of schools; rather, it is about expanding choice for Australian parents. I am very proud of the fact that Australian parents now have a lot more choice than they had under the policies of the former government. The reality is that, no matter what policy you have, there will always be a capacity by some parents in this country to send their children to schools like the school referred to by the Leader of the Opposition. That is a choice which is exercised by parents throughout Australia. That has always been there and it will always be there irrespective of the schools policy.

answer.para: The new element that this government has introduced, the new area of choice that we have introduced, is that we have created an opportunity for working families to exercise the option of choice. It is under this government that the option for working families to send their children to independent schools has been expanded. Schools like the Anglican school at Hoxton Park, with fees of $2,600 a year, would not have been possible under the policies of the Labor Party, and it was only the coalition, with the help of Senator Harradine, that brought about a change in the policy.

We have in this country an education system that increasingly is enabling people to exercise choice. It is based upon a strong government school system, and it is a government school system with which I am personally very familiar—just as familiar with, or more familiar with, than are many who sit opposite and who choose to pretend that they are the sole defenders of the government school system in this country. We need a strong government school system. The government school system has made an outstanding contribution to this country, and it has produced outstanding people in all walks of Australian life. But what this government has additionally done—and what the Labor Party hates because the teacher unions hate it—is to provide choice to those people who want to send their children to non-government schools. Labor wants a school system permanently set in the model of an elite group of GPS schools in the government system, the Catholic systemic system and nothing else. This government wants to preserve and strengthen those three existing elements, but to introduce a new area of choice. It is no surprise that the fastest growing area, as I understand it, in the area of education is not at the very top, not the so-called elite schools, but this new group of independent schools, which reflects the growing desire of aspirational Australia to exercise educational options—the growing desire of aspirational Australia to exercise education options which we are catering for, which are providing people with more choice and which is a policy which I believe is to the long-term benefit of the Australian community.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer inform the House what effect the privatisation of Telstra would have on the Commonwealth's debt position? Is the Treasurer aware of any alternative policies in this area?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Deakin for his question. I think it is well known that the government believes that Telstra, the telecommunications company, would be suited for private share ownership by the millions of Australians who want to invest in the stock market. With the proceeds of that, what this government does is pay off debt—free Australia from the Labor debt which would have otherwise chained us for generations. Just as Labor ran up $80 billion of debt in its last five budgets, so the coalition has paid off already $43 billion—and, by the end of this financial year, $50 billion—of the $80 billion Labor debt. That is freeing young people in the future from the effects of Labor wanton mismanagement.

answer.para: There has been a lot of talk in the community recently about Australia's future as a new economy in the area of IT and telecommunications. I cannot help but observe that the Labor Party, which would have you believe that it understands the new economy, as evidence of its commitment to the economy comes out with its first central key plank: the nationalisation of the phone company. You can imagine how this is received in the investment houses of New York when the Labor Party would walk in and say, `And just to illustrate how committed we are to a new economy, what we believe in is nationalisation in the telephone industry'—a complete contradiction of terms. I have hitherto actually thought that maybe the Labor Party did believe in the continued nationalisation of the telephone company. But I was rather taken with what has just been revealed to the House by the Minister for Finance and Administration in the Telco Weekly which he read out—and it bears reading again; it is very revealing. It says this:

quote.para: Our discussions with senior members of the Opposition has indicated that a split between Telstra's network and its retail business is an option being considered by the ALP. It has been mooted that the government could 100% own the network business. The retail business could then be either fully or partially privatised.

answer.para: Macquarie make this comment—I think it is a good comment:

quote.para: The current state of the polls indicates that the views of the ALP should be considered by investors.

answer.para: In other words, the ALP ought to come clean to investors on what it would do if it got into government. There are people who are making financial decisions at the moment. It goes on to say:

quote.para: Note that such an idea was discussed by the previous ALP government when Paul Keating was Prime Minister.

answer.para: It begs the question: who was the senior member of the opposition who met with Macquarie Bank? Who was the senior member of the opposition who met with Macquarie Bank? If the Leader of the Opposition wants to deny this, perhaps he could deny that a senior member of the opposition ever met with Macquarie Bank. I happen to believe that the senior member of the opposition who met with Macquarie Bank could almost be within arm's reach of the Leader of the Opposition right at this moment. If he wants to say that the Labor Party would never privatise Telstra, could he please explain why senior members of the opposition are going around investment houses talking about its break-up? We could launch another inquiry. You know we are having this inquiry into the frontbencher who said that Aboriginal affairs was like a toilet cleaner on the Titanic. We are still awaiting the results of that inquiry. We could add to that inquiry another inquiry where the Leader of the Opposition could go and inquire as to who was down talking to Macquarie Bank. He would probably show all of the energy that he is showing in his attempts to try to get to who the shadow minister was who made the comment about the Titanic.

But this is the last piece in the puzzle of something that has been worrying me for quite some time. I said to the House yesterday that there is a clipping, which I hold close to my chest on a regular basis, from the Financial Review of 14 August 2000 in which Labor pledged bigger budget surpluses—as I have said, `BS Crean, bigger surplus Crean.' In that we had the famous `Simply Simon' interview. The `Simply Simon' interview read as follows:

quote.para: At the same time—

answer.para: This is speaking of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition:

quote.para: he is also grappling with contradictory elements—

talk.start.para: —Listen to this!
—He is yelling as loud as he can; they are both yelling as loudly as they can to try to drown this out.
—Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—I have never known somebody who wanted to drown out his own words. All I am doing is quoting you and you are yelling at the top of your voice to drown out yourself. The words were the following—
—The Treasurer will address his remarks through the chair.
—Mr Speaker, he is yelling still at full pelt and people who are watching this may not know that the deputy leader is trying to drown out himself. He said this:

quote.para: ... At the same time he is also grappling with contradictory elements of Labor policy such as those relating to the sale of Telstra and GST.
He goes off the record quite often to express a personal view.

answer.para: I bet he goes off the record to express a personal view on Telstra. If he really believed that Telstra never would be broken up and never would be privatised, why would he go off the record? He would presumably just say on the record, `Telstra will never be privatised and Telstra will never be broken up.' Why would you go off the record when you were grappling with Labor's contradictory position on Telstra? There may be some Labor Party backbenchers who actually believe—when they hear the Leader of the Opposition say that he does not intend to privatise Telstra—that that is what would happen if he ever got elected. But those of us who have been here remember him saying over and over again that the Commonwealth Bank would never be privatised. We also remember that, on the eve of the 1995-96 budget, without telling the caucus, the decision was announced in that budget to privatise the Commonwealth Bank. Do you know who was informed before the Labor Party? We were informed, Mr Speaker. The Labor Party came to us to get our support to privatise the Commonwealth Bank—which it had pledged never to do—over the opposition of its own Labor backbench.

We have seen it before. We know what happens. There is no logical explanation for a frontbencher to be in Macquarie Bank making these inquiries. There is no logical reason for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to go off the record with his private views in relation to Telstra, except for one thing, and that is we know they did it in the past and they will do it again.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to address the questions that have been put to me by the finance minister and the Treasurer.
—The Leader of the Opposition has been in the chamber long enough to know that my tradition is not to have people heard until they are recognised. The Leader of the Opposition.
—I seek leave to answer the questions of the finance minister and the Treasurer to set their minds at rest.
—If the Leader of the Opposition has a question he will—
— Do I have leave? They can give leave, Mr Speaker.
—The indication has already been given by the chair that leave is not granted, as was indicated to me.
—They do not have the guts.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and it refers to the Prime Minister's claims that his new school funding system was designed to benefit low fee private schools in Western Sydney. Prime Minister, is it correct that the King's School in Parramatta, with its sporting fields, swimming pool and indoor rifle range, gets an extra $1,351 per pupil per year under your new funding system? Prime Minister, is it also correct that the Thomas Hassall Anglican College at Hoxton Park, which you have referred to, gets only an extra $458 per pupil per year under your new funding system? Prime Minister, if you say you are so committed to low fee private schools in Western Sydney, why does your new funding system give the King's School three times the increase that it gives to Thomas Hassel Anglican College, the sort of school you claim to care about?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Thomas Hassall Anglican College has in fact been opened after the changes to the new schools policy—which you opposed.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, what have been the economic benefits for Australia flowing from the privatisation of government business enterprises? Prime Minister, are you aware of alternative approaches to the approach currently being followed by the government?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Can I say in reply to the member for Groom that, in a word, the economic benefits flowing from the government's policy of privatisation have been `immense'. That is why the coalition parties not only since being in government but also when in opposition have been absolutely up-front in their support for policies of privatisation.

answer.para: One of the ironies of this whole debate about privatisation and one of the things that underlines the utter hypocrisy particularly of the Leader of the Opposition on this issue is that, when the Labor Party in government sought against its election commitments and in repudiation of its election commitments to privatise government business undertakings, it would not have been able to do so without the cooperation of the then coalition in opposition. I certainly remember conversations I had with the now Leader of the Opposition when he was Minister for Finance on the eve of a budget when he sought the support of the coalition in opposition in relation to the privatisation of one of the government business undertakings. Without our support, that would never have materialised.

But the advantages of privatisation are significant. Privatisation of Telstra, the continuation of the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank and other privatisations carried out by the coalition government have greatly facilitated the reduction of the debt run up by the Leader of the Opposition when he was Minister for Finance. We have taken about $43 billion out of the $80 billion of debt or more that we inherited in 1996. As a result, this country now has probably the lowest, if not one of the lowest, government debt to GDP ratios of any country in the world. We have reduced it from a level of 20 per cent of GDP to a figure of 8½ per cent of GDP. That has greatly strengthened the economy, and it is one of the reasons why privatisation is an extremely good policy.

We have also seen massive spending initiatives made possible by the privatisation of Telstra. We had the Natural Heritage Trust, worth $1.25 billion. We had Networking the Nation, worth $250 million. Out of the Telstra social bonus, we have had $1 billion—that was out of the sale of the second tranche of Telstra. That has provided untimed local calls in extended zones—$150 million. The extension of SBS in TV black spots to $120 million. Rural transaction centres—$70 million. Local government fund—$45 million. Expanded mobile phone coverage on major highways—$25 million. Tele-communications for remote and isolated islands—$20 million. And connecting Tasmanian schools—$15 million. All of those initiatives were opposed by the Labor Party, yet it does not stop Labor premiers like Jim Bacon turning up at the launch of telecommunications initiatives in Tasmania and seeking to share the limelight with the federal government. Labor say, `We will vote against it; we think it is absolutely terrible policy,' but when it comes to actually announcing an initiative which has been won for the people of Tasmania by the coalition and Senator Harradine and opposed by the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party Jim Bacon waltzes along and says, `Don't leave me out, John. Make sure I am on the platform. Let me share the limelight in the announcement.' Steve Bracks does exactly the same thing, and Bob Carr does exactly the same thing.

It is therefore no surprise to me to learn that a senior member of the Labor Party frontbench, who I think might be studying his brief at the moment in relation to the next question, should have been talking to Macquarie Bank about Labor plans for privatisation. Everybody around this building knows that, if Labor win the next election, they will find a reason to ditch their opposition of the sale of Telstra. Everyone knows that. Everyone knows that, just as they did it with the Commonwealth Bank, just as they did it with Qantas, just as they did it in relation to Australian Airlines, they will do it in relation to Telstra. They have done it before; they will do it again. If it is possible to have one policy in opposition and a completely different one in government, you can be absolutely certain that that is exactly what the Australian Labor Party are going to do. They are total, rolled gold hypocrites on this issue, and the Australian public knows it.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, if I cannot get—
—The Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.
—Mr Speaker, can I have leave to make a bet?
—The Leader of the Opposition is dealing flippantly with question time.

—My question without notice is again to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister again: is it correct that the King's School in Parramatta, with its sporting fields, swimming pool and indoor rifle range, gets an extra $1,351 per pupil per year under your new funding system? Is it also correct that the Tyndale Christian School at Blacktown gets only an extra $144 per pupil per year? Prime Minister, if you say you are so committed to low fee private schools in Western Sydney, why does your new funding system give the King's School nine times the increase it gives to Tyndale Christian School?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —As always with these, I will check the figures. It may well be that the base grants, the point from which you are starting before you add the additional amount, explain those differences. I think you will find out that they probably do, but as always I will have those figures checked, and if there is anything further I should inform the House of I will. As the member for Dobell has asked me a question about the government's new funding approach for schools, let me take him through the details of it. Let him be reminded that the state grants funding for schools bill contains the highest ever level of funding for government schools. A record $8.6 billion in Commonwealth funds will be spent on government schools, and that is an increase of 18 per cent on 1997. In this current year alone, total direct Commonwealth funding to government schools is $2 billion, and this is $402 million more than in Labor's last year of office. That is an increase of 26 per cent.

answer.para: The new SES policy, which we have introduced, is much fairer than the old ERI system. It is very much based on a school's capacity to pay. Under that policy, the 63 schools serving the neediest communities will receive an average increase—and I invite the member for Dobell to listen to this—of $207 per student next year, rising to $966 by the year 2004. This is five times the increase flowing to the 67 schools serving the wealthiest communities, who will receive $43 extra per student next year and $198 by the year 2004. Schools serving lower SES communities—that is, the schools with SES scores of 100 or less—and the Catholic systemic schools will receive over 79 per cent of government funding, while the 67 schools serving the wealthiest communities will receive only 2.3 per cent of Commonwealth funding. SES funded schools serving the very wealthiest communities receive per student 13.7 per cent of the total cost of educating a child at a government school. This compares with schools serving the neediest communities, which will now receive up to 70 per cent of the cost of educating a child at a government school.
