talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The widespread community concern about the Howard government's new school funding policy.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Yesterday the Prime Minister misled this House when he reaffirmed the incorrect and false statement that he had made on radio 3AW last Friday. The Prime Minister did not have the courage to come into this House this morning, and he did not have the courage to get up at the start of question time today, to admit that he had misled the House. Yesterday I said the reason the Prime Minister had misled the listeners of 3AW—the reason the Prime Minister had misled this House yesterday—was that he was lost in a fog of mistruths and falsehoods generated by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Today the Prime Minister is lost in a thicker fog. Today the Prime Minister fell off a cliff called Thomas Hassall Anglican College, a cliff of his own creation, when he came into this House to try to use that example to justify the changes this government is making in funding for non-government schools. Having been lost in the fog yesterday, having navigated his way into the thicker fog and having fallen off the first cliff called Thomas Hassall Anglican College, he then fell off an even higher second cliff when he referred to the measly $966 increase for the schools serving the 63 neediest communities in Australia. We will explain in this debate this afternoon why this Prime Minister either does not understand his own government's new funding system for private schools or has deliberately misled the listeners of 3AW and this House. That is the choice—either he does not understand it or he has deliberately misled this House.

speech.para: We know that the Prime Minister recently visited Melbourne Grammar. When he visited it to open some new facility at that category 1 private school, he said that under his new private school funding system the Howard government would provide more resources to those `that are more deserving of assistance'. Last Thursday we had the figures released to let us determine how this government is going to allocate funding under its new schools funding system. What we learnt concerned category 1 schools, the wealthier schools in Australia. Let us use King's School as an example. King's will get an increase of $1.4 million a year when this scheme comes fully into operation. So, under the Prime Minister's definition, the people in the communities that are served by the King's School are deserving of assistance valued at $1.4 million a year. If you divide that by the number of students at King's, you find that the government is increasing funding to the King's School by $1,351 for each pupil each year. That is how the government assesses their need for assistance.

The Prime Minister sought to use his support for new Anglican schools, like Thomas Hassall Anglican College, to justify the increases that the government is providing for other non-government schools. But when you look at the figures for Thomas Hassall Anglican College you see they do not get $1,351 per year per pupil which the King's School—a category 1 school—is getting; they get only $458 per pupil per year. So King's, according to the Prime Minister's words, is three times more deserving of assistance than his own example, the low fee Anglican college out at Hoxton Park. Let us have a look at Tyndale Christian School, which is out at Blacktown. Tyndale Christian School gets an increase of only $144 per pupil per year. According to the Prime Minister's definition, the King's School is nine times more deserving of assistance than a low fee Christian school like Tyndale.

If you are a parent who sends your daughter to Our Lady of Mercy College at Parramatta or to any other of the 1,500 Catholic systemic schools in the country, you get no real increase in your funding under this new system. The Prime Minister's response to that was, `Well, the parents who send their children to the Catholic schools have won, won, won in the past.' They do not need to win, win, win like the King's School, according to the Prime Minister. I challenge the Prime Minister to go to OLMC at Parramatta and ask the parents whether they think that they are less deserving than the parents who send their children to the King's School. At OLMC Parramatta they certainly do not have some of the facilities that King's School has; they certainly do not have some of the facilities that we mentioned earlier today. King's has 15 cricket fields, five basketball courts, 12 tennis courts, 13 rugby fields, three soccer fields, a 50-metre swimming pool, a gym, a boatshed, two climbing walls and an indoor rifle range. It has all those facilities, but the Prime Minister says, `This is one of the schools that deserves one of the largest increases in the country.'

This is an outrage! When the Prime Minister himself admits that the schools serving the 63 neediest communities in Australia only get an increase of $933 a year per pupil and King's gets $1,351 per pupil per year, it is an outrage. It is an outrage that this government says that King's is more deserving than the schools that you say are the 63 most needy schools in the country. The very schools that you say are the neediest only get $933 per pupil per year, and King's gets a $1,351 per pupil per year increase under the changes.

It is even worse if you look at the comparison between King's and a government high school like Parramatta. Parramatta High, a neighbouring high school, has none of these facilities. Parramatta High School has to use the sporting fields at Parramatta Park. Parramatta High School could do with some extra money. Parramatta High School could do with a federal government that supports public education. Parramatta High School deserves more than the $4,000 per year that government schools on average will receive across the country.

This government is delivering average increases of $911,000 a year for the 62 wealthy category 1 schools. The 1,500 Catholic systemic schools get an average increase of $60,000 a year. Government high schools and government primary schools across the country on average only get $4,000 a year after cost indexation. It is $911,000 for the wealthiest category 1 schools; 60,000 for the Catholic schools; and only 4,000 measly dollars on average to public schools across the country, which look after 70 per cent of the kids attending schools.

We are not against schools like King's. We actually know that they do get good performance. Many of the students who go to King's get excellent results. What we are against is a government that says they are more deserving of funding increases than needy non-government schools, than government schools—primary and high schools—that have got much greater need than King's. That is our point. We are not against the category 1 schools; we are against a government that says that category 1 schools have got greater need than decent low fee Catholic and Christian schools and government schools across the country. That is the outrage, and that is what we are going to hold this government accountable for. The Prime Minister misled this House yesterday and reaffirmed his statements on 3AW. It is quite clear that this Prime Minister does not have the courage to come into this House and admit it.

Let us make three simple points about what Labor's view is on this system of new funding for schools. First of all, Labor supports extra funding for needy non-government schools. Second, Labor supports a matching increase in funding for government schools. Third, Labor believes that the extra funding for non-government schools has to be allocated on a needs basis—the needs basis system that was introduced by Prime Minister Whitlam and education minister Kim Beazley Sr, unlike the Menzies government's science block and library grants that were not allocated on a need basis.

The need basis is and should remain a crucial part of allocating the extra funding for non-government schools. That is the reason why we have been so critical of this minister's ideological campaign to not only give modest funding increases to low fee Christian schools but also wrap up with that a massive avalanche of extra funding for the 62 category 1 schools. Only Dr Kemp, only the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, would think that the highest priority in education today is to deliver an increase of $56 million a year to the category 1 schools. Only Dr Kemp, only the minister for education, would think that part of that highest priority is to give an extra $1.4 million a year to the King's School. Labor is going to ensure that this debate takes place and that the public understands what this government is trying to do.

The point we make is that a month ago when this debate started we put out our estimate of what the impact of the changes would be. We said that we thought the 62 category 1 schools would get an increase of about $50 million a year and that on average the increases would be about $820,000 a year for each school. That was our estimate. The minister panned our estimate and said that we had misled people. Figures came out—they are on the Internet, available today—and, if you add up the 62 category 1 schools, what is the funding increase? We said it was about $50 million a year; the exact figure is $56.5 million a year going to the 62 category 1 schools, an average increase of not $820,000 a year, as we estimated it, but $911,000 a year. So we have been very responsible and conservative in the estimates that we have made.

What this minister does is part of the fog of misrepresentation and half-truths that come out of his mouth. It is no wonder the Prime Minister gets lost in his fog of misrepresentation. Part of the fog is he does not talk about the 62 category 1 schools; he talks about the 67 schools serving the wealthiest communities. The reason he does that is that he does not want to talk about the 62 category 1 schools; he only wants to talk about the 67 schools that are at the top of his SES listing. That is part of his trick, because under his definition of the 67 wealthiest schools the King's School is not wealthy and that is why it deserves an increase of $1.4 million a year. It is quite clear who is misleading whom.

The point we make about funding for schools across the country is that there are real needs in schools. There are needs in many of our government schools. There are kids who cannot read and write properly. There are kids who are weak in numeracy at government schools. There are kids who are not up to standards in many of the low fee non-government schools as well. We say they are the schools that should have the first priority in any funding that is available. They are the schools that should be getting the money—not the King's School, not Melbourne Grammar, not Geelong College; those are the schools that can actually lift their literacy and numeracy performance with some extra resources.

Money is not everything, but at poor government schools and at poor private schools extra money means you can employ extra remedial literacy teachers. At poor government and poor private schools extra money means you can invest more money in training up your teachers, in giving them some professional development. With extra money you can do things like fund our education priority zones that we announced earlier this year. With extra money we can make sure that in areas of low incomes, in areas of educational disadvantage, we can give those kids a decent start in life. That is the Labor priority.

This minister's priority is not to put money into the schools that need help. This minister's priority is not providing extra remedial literacy teachers in poor government and poor private schools. This minister's priority is to give an extra $1.4 million a year to schools like King's, with fantastic facilities already, which are getting excellent results with many of their students. We say that our aim should be that every child at every school should be striving to achieve the same sorts of results as we see at the category 1 schools. The first step along that path is to ensure that those poor government and poor private schools get a decent level of resources.

This minister claimed yesterday that we need to look at the objective evidence of the schools that have real needs. He claims that his new funding system uses the objective evidence to determine which schools need extra money. His system of objective evidence delivers massive funding increases—$56.5 million extra to the wealthy category 1 schools. We say that we are not opposed to extra funding for needy government and non-government schools; we are not opposed to the extra funding going to any school except those in category 1. It is the category 1 schools that we say are the outrage. It is the massive increase of $911,000 per year per school to those category 1 schools that we intend to make the centre of this debate. We are going to hold this minister accountable for the fact that, while there are deserved increases for some of the needy non-government schools, there is the outrage of a massive increase to those category 1 schools. We are determined to ensure that the Prime Minister comes out of the fog. No matter how many broken legs he may have after falling off those cliffs, we are going to hold the Prime Minister accountable every day by pointing out to him how unfair these funding increases are to those category 1 schools, and we are determined that this minister will be held accountable for his outrages. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —This is the MPI you have when you have the Australian Education Union riding very hard on your back. You have to offer them something and they love a bit of the politics of envy and the class-war rhetoric. The Labor Party are in a huge bind on this because the leader of the Labor Party and the member for Dobell have stated publicly that they intend to pass the government's legislation. The Democrats have said exactly the same thing. Of course the Australian Education Union are furious with the Labor Party over this. So before they pass the legislation the Labor Party have got to kick up a song and dance to tell Shazza, Denis Fitzgerald and all the others associated with the Australian Education Union that they are really serious—that they are really on their side. They know that unless they can get this message across the AEU will not contribute to the next election campaign, and they are deeply dependent on funding from the Australian Education Union for their election campaign. So no distortion is too great, no misrepresentation is too extreme. The AEU love to stir up a bit of division in the community. They love the class-war rhetoric and really welcome the attack on a school like King's, the parents of whom will be getting only 30 per cent of the cost of funding a child at a government school under this policy compared to the much higher funding for government schools. The Australian Education Union love this kind of rhetoric.

speech.para: The member for Dobell has to please them, and he has to please some of the ideologues on the Labor Party backbench because he has the shadow of the member for Werriwa looming over him. The difference between them is that the member for Werriwa can actually understand some of the issues involved here, whereas the member for Dobell does not understand the issues or else is deliberately misrepresenting the issues. We are seeing here a pathetic attempt to suggest that there is something unfair about the government's new funding system for non-government schools. Just think about this: the Labor Party says this is unfair when every element of the non-government school sector, every representative voice in the non-government school sector, says this is fair. This is the most absurd MPI topic this House has seen for a long time—concerning `widespread community concern'! The community concern extends just beyond the backbench of the Labor Party into the ranks of the officials of the Australian Education Union, and that is about the limit of it.

The community concern I find is the concern of every element of the non-government sector about the Labor Party's activities. Let me just go through them. I have here a series of statements from every element in the non-government sector. They put on the record their concern, and their concern is with the Labor Party. As Fergus Thompson, the Executive Director of the National Council of Independent Schools Association, said on 28 August:

quote.para: Any delay by the Senate in passing the schools funding legislation will cause serious problems for independent schools ... There is no reason to delay passage of the legislation. The SES funding system has been trialed. It has proved workable. This debate has gone on for years. It is now urgent for many schools. All school sectors depend on the legislation and all sectors would welcome its passage by the parliament without delay.

speech.para: On 4 September he also said:

quote.para: The families of the 300,000-plus students at independent schools around the nation will be seriously hurt by delays to reforming legislation that will means-test Commonwealth funding of non-government schools.

speech.para: In a media release on 29 September the Association of Independent Schools of New South Wales said:

quote.para: We urge Senators to pass the Bill without delay because all schools and parents need to know the funding levels as soon as possible to enable proper budgeting for next year.

speech.para: In a media release on 29 September the Australian Parents Council said:

quote.para: The States Grants legislation puts in place Commonwealth funding for Australian school students for 2001-2004. It should be passed without further delay so that all schools can adequately plan for 2001.

speech.para: On 28 August, Mr Leo Dunn, OAM, President of the Australian Parents Council, said:

quote.para: The Bill guarantees security of Commonwealth funding for non-government schools and students during the phasing in of the new funding mechanism. Commonwealth funding legislation for school education runs out at the end of this year. Legislation is necessary to ensure that Commonwealth funds flow for school education from 1 January 2001.

speech.para: The Rev. Tom Doyle, the Deputy Chair of the National Catholic Education Commission, in a recent media release, on 22 August, said:

quote.para: The Senate should pass the State Grants Bill 2000 intact.

speech.para: That covers the entire non-government sector. The Christian controlled Parents Schools have issued a statement saying:

quote.para: The Government is to be congratulated. Low income Australian parents and their families have been given a real chance to exercise genuine choice in the education of their children.

speech.para: Dr Peter Tannock has said:

quote.para: It will give them—

speech.para: Catholic schools and systems—

quote.para: real increases in resources, and a secure, long-term funding base. ... It will also help many Catholic schools to cope with cost pressures which are pushing up fees to levels which make it very difficult for families on low and moderate incomes.

speech.para: As Peter Crimmins, the Executive Officer of the Australian Association of Christian Schools, said:

quote.para: Choice in schooling is now a reality for working class Australian families.

speech.para: So the Labor Party has been abandoned by absolutely everybody who is affected by the new system. We have got the pathetic sight of the member for Dobell marching up and down here saying, `It's not fair to low income Catholic schools, it's not fair to low income independent schools, and it would be fairer if we changed it,' and yet all those who represent those schools say it is fair. Who should they believe? Should they believe the member for Dobell, the spokesman for the education policy that the member for Werriwa walked away from because it is so bad, or should they believe the people who represent them? The fact is the Labor Party stands alone with the Australian Education Union, opposing on its old class war grounds, its old left-wing ideology, legislation to give schools fair funding.

The fact is that we have put in place for the first time a fair measure against which the funding of schools can be determined. That fair measure is never better illustrated than by this fact: when you look at the schools which are servicing the wealthiest communities in Australia, according to the SES system—the system supported by every expert in Australia as fairer, and supported by all the school systems as fairer—when you look at the schools that are funded by this system, you find that the schools serving the wealthiest communities are funded at a lower level under our system than the level at which they were funded under Labor's system. About half the 67 schools serving the wealthiest communities will be funded at Labor's level, because we have agreed to maintain past levels of funding, and half will be funded at our level under our new system. The schools that are funded under Labor's system get 50 per cent more funding per student than the schools funded under our system. Why is that? It is because Labor's system was so absurdly corrupted by Labor's political manipulation over the years to gratify its base, without any regard to fairness, without any regard to justice.

talk.start.para: —I can tell the member for Dobell that it is a base that is shrinking all the time, and every time the member for Dobell opens his mouth it shrinks further. He and the member for Werriwa together have attacked virtually everybody in the non-government sector, and they are trying to mislead everybody in the government sector, but fortunately people can see through them. The reason we get these high funding levels for these wealthy schools from Labor's system is because Labor's system did not pay any real attention to equity, and that is why it has been abandoned by everybody in the non-government sector. Nobody supports it except the member for Dobell.

—The Catholics do not support it either. The Catholics have made very clear to us that they support the new legislation. The member for Dobell has now put the Labor Party in the most extraordinary situation, because he is saying that parents who receive 30 per cent, 35 per cent or 25 per cent of the cost of education at a government school for their child are overfunded—they are being overpaid by the government. They would get much more support for their children if they sent their child to the local government school; they would get 100 per cent of the cost of educating a child at a government school. They are only going to get about 35 per cent. So a school like King's School is saving the taxpayer—the parent at that school—millions of dollars. That money that they save the taxpayer is available for government schools, and that is why these schools are deserving of the funding that they get under this new system because it is a new, fair system. But Labor is going to cut their funding. Let us be quite clear, so that the message goes out to all the parents at these schools, that Labor is going to cut their funding because they are overfunded; according to Labor, it is unfair that they get even 30 per cent of the cost of educating a child at a government school.

speech.para: This new funding system that we have introduced is going to produce, finally and at last, a funding system which has credibility with those who are subject to it. The Labor Party not only is going to cut funding to these schools but also is going to reintroduce the new schools policy—the infamous new schools policy.

talk.start.para: —There we are; it is confirmed by the member for Port Adelaide. The member for Port Adelaide has confirmed the fact—let Hansard record this—that the Labor Party intends to reintroduce the new schools policy.

speech.para: That policy was designed by the unions to prevent new low fee schools opening up because people in the Labor Party think that the best way to protect public education is to stop parents on low incomes having a choice. He has no idea about proper reform of the public education system; he has nothing to do with proper reporting to parents. During their 13 years in office Labor did nothing to raise literacy standards. They left 30 per cent of young Australians unable to read and write properly. They do not believe in more autonomy for school principals and for parents. They do everything possible to bias parents against the public school system by making sure that it remains under the centralised bureaucratic controls that can be influenced by union officials. They do not really care about public education. They do not care about students in need. That is why, when they were in office, they did not do anything about the most important social justice issue in education—literacy. They do not really care about the need in schools. And they say the new system is unfair. The new system funds the schools serving the wealthiest communities at about 13.7 per cent of the cost of educating a child at a government school. It funds every student at a government school at 100 per cent. It funds the schools serving the neediest communities in the non-government sector at 70 per cent. That is a funding system that is based on need and on a recognition of need; not on need as I judge it or as the member for Dobell judges it. It is a funding system based on need and recognised in an objective and transparent way. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is typical of what we on this side have come to expect from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, but never have I heard a minister take so long to say so little. When he talks about credibility, I know he can spell it, but I ask, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, does he really know what it means? His Prime Minister certainly does not know what credibility means because again in this House today at question time we had the Prime Minister talking about choice. What about considering priorities when we are spending taxpayers' money? I would like to put to the Prime Minister some facts that he needs to appreciate and understand. His minister does not understand or appreciate them. The fact is that schools like the King's School are already providing a high standard of education for their students without the extra funding that Dr Kemp's bill will give them. Fact, Minister: schools such as these already dominate entry to the elite faculties of our universities. Fact, Minister: these students have little chance of leaving school with poor literacy and numeracy skills. Fact, Minister: few of the students when they exit this school will go onto the dole queues. Public policy commonsense dictates that additional education dollars should go to the schools that need to improve the most. If Australia is going to become a knowledge nation we need to raise the standard from the bottom to the top and not provide already high performing schools with added extras to give some students even more advantages than they already have.

speech.para: Last week the Prime Minister admitted that non-government schools receiving extra funding from the SES system were not obliged to spend the money on lowering fees. This one point totally undermines the rationale for the funding given by the minister for education that the new system will make private schools more affordable for parents and give them choice. There is that wonderful word: `choice'. At most, as the Prime Minister admits—even if the minister will not—it means that fees will now not go up, perhaps, at the same rate. I fail to see how slowing the rate of increase of elite private school fees will create extra choice for battling Australian families who want a better education for their children. By the Prime Minister's own admission—and thus this government's admission—the millions extra received by our wealthier schools will not significantly change the social and economic status of their intake. Instead, it will give these schools an even greater advantage over poorer schools than they have now by giving them extra money for extras such as heated swimming pools, high-tech music centres and overseas excursions. The Prime Minister also claimed that this new funding system will make it easier for our battling working-class families who work long hours to pay school fees to send their children to private schools. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I might say that perhaps the Prime Minister is more out of touch than I gave him credit for. The average working-class families that I represent who are paying off mortgages and running two cars are working two jobs now to be able to afford to send their kids to state schools with all the additional on-costs associated with doing that—excursions, uniforms, books, lunches, et cetera.

The fact is that the coalition is not interested in improving the standard of education for all Australians. They are interested in their ideological mission to set up a contestable market for schooling to eventually marginalise the state school system. Also, when this minister talks about his new funding scheme, he completely ignores the wealth that the more able schools can generate. I am talking about their school fees, their fundraising activities, their private donations, et cetera. I will give you an example. A high school in my electorate has a cake stall on election day to raise funds while the King's School on the same day has an art auction. Are we comparing apples with apples? I think not. As a parent who had twin daughters go to OLMC in Parramatta, which is within cooee distance of the King's School, I am insulted—along with a lot of my constituents—to think that that school will get not one penny of this funding. It does not have the playing fields and the tremendous surrounding grounds that the King's School has. Why are you disadvantaging this particular school? There are no answers, Minister. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask the minister again: why can't he answer these questions? If you want to have a lesson in politics, we can look today at the Australian Financial Review where Minister Kemp expresses his unfailing belief in his policy achievements, casting his detractors in the role of union red-raggers and labelling Labor's policy approach as nothing more than empty rhetoric. You are certainly wrong, Minister. You have alienated every reasonable thinking educationalist who believes in quality and equity in education around this nation. More and more attention is now being given to those issues by parents, and you are vulnerable, Minister. The more you try to disguise the truth about your SES model, the more you are being disbelieved. We now know in fact that 39 of the 62 category 1 schools which will share in the extra $50 million a year have annual fees in excess of $10,000.

The minister can filibuster in this House as much as he likes, but it will not disguise the fact that his new system will not apply to the vast majority of non-government schools, and I have given examples of those. Catholic parish schools in my electorate as well as the 1,600 around Australia will not be part of this new system. Where is your choice, Minister? This is what you want to throw back at us. A third of non-government sector schools, 750 schools, will be funded—only a third. And this is called by this coalition government `fairness with choice'. Seventy per cent of Australian children are educated in government schools, something the PM and this minister choose to overlook.

Parents within communities around Australia are now waiting for answers to a number of questions. Perhaps, Minister, I had better remind you of what those questions are. Will the schools fortunate enough to receive funding give a guarantee to you and this government not to increase fees over the next four years? If, as the minister claims, the wealthiest schools will receive no more than 25 per cent of funding but his department is saying 27.5 per cent, who is right—you, Minister, or the department? Is it a fact that only one-third of private schools will be funded under this new system? Minister, how much of taxpayers' money is being spent? Minister, can you not concede that you are on a crusade to abolish government schools? Why, Minister, are you hell-bent on forcing students from government schools to non-government schools? Minister, will the states lose federal funding if the public schools' share of the education market falls? Minister, you can come clean. Confession, we are told, is good for the soul. The minister would like us to forget the ERC meetings of 3 and 4 June 1991, the minutes of which state:

quote.para: It was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back to the Committee on:
* non-government schools—whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and in untied grants;
* government schools—administrative savings in devolving responsibility to the States;

speech.para: We all remember that leaked document. In that same article I referred to in the Financial Review today the minister very gloatingly said:

quote.para: When the submission fell into the hands of the ALP—there are still dark mutterings the document was leaked by one of Kemp's ministerial colleagues—the Government was forced to hastily backtrack.

While claiming the Cabinet submission is now only a “historical document”, he stretches credibility by suggesting the Government is actually moving ahead with a great deal of the controversial blueprint.
“We are now implementing a number of those options, the absolutely key options,”

speech.para: Minister, how can you justify ripping $60 million out of needy government schools and giving the richest 62 schools across Australia an extra $50 million a year? Again, an article in the Australian of 25 August states:

quote.para: Education Minister David Kemp wants us to believe his planned changes to funding non-government education aim to give low-income families greater access to the schools of their choice.

speech.para: That is what he wants us to think. This is the editorial in the Australian, not my words, not the union red raggers. The editorial in the Australian of 25 August states:

quote.para: He wants us to think the neediest school communities will benefit ... The plan even uses a socio-economic status index. One problem is—

speech.para: Minister, it does not work—

quote.para: it is flawed ... Another problem is that a school's funding cannot be cut, even if the SES says it should be. And just as the old system of categorising a school's need based on its perceived wealth was faulty, so is the new one for ignoring a school's assets and access to donations altogether.

speech.para: If time would permit me, I would say a lot more. The article goes on:

quote.para: While all parents must have choices for their children's education, a core group will always choose private—preferring the old boys' and old girls' networks, religion, philosophy or teaching methods. But the public system can and does deliver great students from great schools.

speech.para: The editorial also reminded the minister that his `system gives disproportionately more money to well-off schools and makes them more attractive'. This is not the union movement, Minister; this is the editorial of the Australian, a paper I believe you read succinctly from cover to cover. Maybe you want to ask them if they understand the word `credibility'. Maybe they are not credible, or maybe it is you, Minister, who is not credible. If you do not want to understand that, did you read the Canberra Times yesterday? It said:

quote.para: The Federal Government's philosophical commitment to private schooling has never been more evident than in its new Socio-Economic Status funding model.
The Government talks about “choice”, but what it would really prefer is for every parent to “choose” private schooling.

speech.para: The minister and the Prime Minister said today that parents have won, won, won. Minister and Prime Minister, I want to know when, when, when? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —About this time on most days of a parliamentary sitting week we have a debate called MPI, but I suspect from this day forward standing orders should be altered to reflect the fact that it should not be called `matter of public importance' but `matter of union importance' because there is a rotation through the various unions to which various members opposite have a certain amount of attachment and their expectations of funding after the next election. These various unions manage, on a very regular cyclical basis, to present their argument of the day, and their particular puppet on a string gets up here and proposes a motion which is then debated by the parliament for about 50 minutes. Today it is the turn of the Australian Education Union and their key operative, the member for Dobell.

speech.para: What is completely misunderstood by the member for Prospect and the member for Dobell, and all others opposite who seemed so engrossed in what the member for Prospect especially had to say, is that this is a government that has in fact increased funding to government schools. We have provided funding of $2 billion to government schools this year. That is $402 million more for this year than was the case in Labor's last year in office. This government will provide funding to government schools of $1.4 billion more over the next four years, and it is not even a core responsibility of the Commonwealth government to fund government schools. In Queensland we call them state schools, and they are aptly named: they are the responsibility of the state government. Yet the Commonwealth, prepared to ensure that we get good outcomes from the public education system, gives additional funding to boost the state government's efforts in this regard. I know that at schools in my own electorate we have seen direct capital funding going into major projects such as manual arts blocks and teaching blocks, and we see ongoing recurrent assistance to other schools in the non-government sector. So I am more than satisfied by this minister's complete commitment to the funding of schools, the funding of the education outcome—not simply the system but the outcome of the system that we expect for our students, our children and the future of our nation.

The literacy and numeracy focus this minister has brought to his job is heralded all around this country. I know that in visits he has undertaken to my own electorate he has been well received by teaching professionals, those in the government and non-government sector, students, parents and academic professionals at the university because of that commitment and because of his understanding of the issues. I do not believe for a moment that the record should be allowed to continue uncorrected in this `matter of union importance' debate that is taking place today. We should not allow the Australian Labor Party to get up the suggestion that funding to government schools has been cut, because it has been enhanced by this government and deliberately so.

What I am really concerned about is this envy driven society approach that the Australian Labor Party seem to be embarking upon yet again. We saw it for 13 years, and if they ever get back into office we will see them split the Australian society. It is a disgrace that during question time today the opposition saw fit to try to create false impressions based on a system of funding that is gone and is being replaced by a system that is more realistic and has the capacity to ensure funding goes where it is needed. They were trying to create the impression that the old system remains, and they were using that as the basis of their argument that some kind of class warfare has been created between a wealthy school and a non-wealthy school in the suburb of Parramatta in Sydney. I have to say that this sort of splitting of Australia and this divisionist kind of politics is just not good enough for anybody pretending to be an alternative government in this country. I am concerned that we have in waiting an opposition that, if in government, would take funding away from schools that are offering education services to students and try to prop up the public school system again. That is certainly their claim and it seems to be some kind of payback to the Education Union. I said a few weeks ago that it seemed to me that everything involving education would have to be checked in a future Labor government by the Australian Education Union. Under Labor, we would see a mega bureaucracy, with more funding going into education only for it to be soaked up by the bureaucracy they would create around their union mates and jobs for their friends. Have we ever seen this before under the Labor Party? Of course we have.

As a product of the public state school system—Runcorn State School and MacGregor State High School in my own electorate—I am also a strong defender of the rights of parents to exercise choice. If those parents back their choice, and they have to, by paying additional money into the cost of educating their child, which they do, they do so based on their ability to afford that particular choice. They are backed completely by this government in the exercise of that choice, and the system then is backing this government for offering and financing that choice. The member for Port Adelaide offered an interjection that was not noted by Hansard that suggested that any money that goes from the Commonwealth into non-government schools is robbing the overall education budget of other possibilities. The fact is that every parent who exercises their choice to send their child to a non-government school and pays for that privilege of choice is subsidising the overall education cost in this country. It is a simple fact. They are affording an additional amount of money into the education scheme which releases money out of the overall education budget back into the state school system. So every parent who is taking up their choice of sending a child to a non-government school—no matter what level parents believe they are able to subsidise the education cost of their child, be it sending them to the poorest of parish schools, like St Brendan's at Moorooka in my electorate, or the most prestigious of schools that exist in the city of Brisbane, like Churchie, Brisbane Grammar School or whatever—is making a great contribution to the overall cost of education in Australia.

So it is extraordinary in the extreme to think that the Australian Labor Party would come in here today and try to create some sort of classless warfare circumstance to defend a system that for 15 years never worked. The whole ERI system was broken virtually from day one. It achieved poor results as far as targeting the needs of those in the non-government sector was concerned. It somehow or other seemed to miss some of the wealthiest schools in so far as ensuring that there was equity compared to some that needed more. It managed to ensure that poor schools in my area did not get the level of funding they are now getting as a result of this government's direct approach of assisting them. I think it is parlous in the extreme.

Another matter I should raise in connection with this debate is the Southside Education Centre at Tarragindi, which Minister Kemp visited a few months ago. The Southside Education Centre was begun by the Baptist Church, the Bindari centre, and it takes care of about 30 young ladies who are rejects of the Queensland state school system, kids who have been through all sorts of deeply personal traumas that I shall not go into in this place. As a result of the state school system not taking up these people as well as it might, the Baptist Church has done the right thing and is providing education for people who did not just slip through the cracks but went under the path and were essentially swept away and not wanted. This school is now receiving direct funding from this government to the tune of $4,904 per student, which is 60 per cent of the cost of sending those kids off to the state school system. More to the point, we now have kids in those sorts of places getting education which they were not getting before. That in itself proves how wrong the Australian Labor Party are to suggest this government, this minister and this particular system we want the Senate to pass will not meet the needs of the very needy. These girls typify the very needy in society. They typify the direct focus and the very personal and deliberate approach of this minister in getting the right result out of education funding in this country. I know the parents of that school appreciate this minister's own determination and this government's approach in this matter. The Australian Labor Party should stand condemned for their divisionist approach, for their misleading approach, for plucking figures out of the air in this debate today and for the approach they have taken throughout. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Order! The discussion is concluded.

talk.start.para: —The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 replaces the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 from next year. The bill provides continuing funding for the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program from 2001 to mid-2005, covering both recurrent and specific project funding as well as the away from home element of Abstudy. In speaking to the bill, I would also like to speak in support of the amendment moved by the member for Dobell and shadow minister for education to the motion for the second reading.

speech.para: The bill, as the House will be aware, seeks to implement the 1999-2000 budget initiative, which announced the new National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy. Under that strategy, launched in March this year, funding will be performance based, with priority given to a focus on literacy, numeracy and school attendance. At the launch of this program the Prime Minister, as is so often the case, suggested that additional funding was being provided for indigenous literacy. Unlike the current act, the bill does not set out the conditions that will attach to agreements made with education providers. And, unlike the current act, the bill gives the minister the power to recover payments if any conditional agreement is breached.

In speaking to the bill, I suggest to the House that our education system must respect the unique history of indigenous Australians. We are all aware that there is a cultural element to indigenous education that makes it different. This has implications for how we define our goals and measure our success. I am concerned at how the government intends to recognise this. For that reason I think it is appropriate that, in responding to this debate, the minister should give more detail on his intentions in this respect.

The bill also does not reproduce the table of per capita amounts payable to different types of education providers—be they preschools, schools and vocational educational institutions—which is included in the current act. I ask the minister today: does he give absolute discretion in the distribution of funding between different levels of education and between government and non-government providers? I think that is also a question that he should answer in responding to this debate. The budget papers show a shift in the allocation of Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program funding away from government providers. The 1998-99 forward estimates allocated 56.65 per cent of funding to the government sector. This year's budget unfortunately shows a decline of 45.71 per cent. This does not seem to have been caused by any shift in enrolments. There has been virtually no change in the government sector's share of either school or VET enrolments of indigenous students over the last four years, with government providers enrolling around 88 per cent of indigenous school students and 86 per cent of indigenous VET students.

This bill provides the bulk of Commonwealth supplementary funding for indigenous education from 1 January 2001. It is therefore important for the House to note in the debate about indigenous education the clear size of the challenge and the struggle ahead of us on the indigenous education front. For those reasons I refer to the fact that fewer than 50 per cent of indigenous students remain at school to year 11 compared with over 85 per cent of non-indigenous students and fewer than 31 per cent remain to year 12 compared with over 72 per cent of non-indigenous students. Among 15- to 19-year-olds, indigenous Australians are a third less likely than other Australians to be attending school and less than half as likely to be attending a tertiary institution. When you consider that those with a degree or skilled vocational qualification, as you and I know, are about four times as likely to have a full-time job as a person who left school at age 15 or younger, these numbers I refer to say important things about the distance we still have to travel in indigenous education and, in thinking about indigenous education, employability.

The facts tell us that we are not providing pathways for all young indigenous people—pathways from early childhood, through primary and secondary school and on to employment and/or further study. We need to focus particular attention on the key educational institutions and transitions, whilst also recognising the impact that families, schools and community environments often have on educational prospects. There is more and more evidence emerging about what works in indigenous education. We as a community can no longer claim that we do not know how to do it. We can no longer continue to put the problem aside, and we can no longer claim that it is simply too hard.

What we are about is trying to learn from our past mistakes and also trying to learn from some of our more recent successes. In doing so, I refer to the development of a school culture, support for school attendance and the development of literacy skills early which provide a strong foundation for successful secondary school experience. The literature suggests a number of reasons why the school drop-out rate is so high for indigenous youth. These include a lack of relevant courses, a lack of culturally appropriate curriculum and low literacy levels that are first apparent at primary school—back to basics. If we want to improve the chances of our young indigenous people staying at school, then we have a fair idea of how to go about it. But this takes resources because it means getting behind those communities that are trying to develop the new approaches.

Over many years I have had an opportunity to visit communities in various states and territories of Australia. I am also pleased to note that as a result of my more recent appointment as shadow minister for regional development I have had an opportunity to visit a number of communities that are actually making gains when it comes to improving indigenous education outcomes. For example, I refer to an after school centre in Karratha where the schoolkids from Roebourne study in a nurturing, secure environment. The outcomes achieved through that program are quite remarkable and I welcome the fact that this program will soon spread to other areas. Roebourne and the school centre at Karratha prove that it can be done, but it takes leadership and resources at all levels of the community, including at a Commonwealth government level.

I believe that the reality for many indigenous youth is that they are participating in vocational education courses requiring low skill levels. While improvements in the level and quality of participation in further education requires improvements in schooling outcomes, we should also be looking at how to expand pathways within the VET sector. These pathways should be aimed at developing work related skills—because I think they are critical to employability—from prevocational and preparatory courses through to higher level vocational outcomes. And, wherever possible, there should be a work based component because we know from experience that that actually works.

Again, as we all know, getting these pathways right is not easy. It requires commitment and a willingness to actually try new things. When you talk to mining companies in the Pilbara about how they are going, you again see that dedication can get you somewhere. I recently therefore spent some time with Hamersley Iron looking at how their indigenous training programs are working. As the minister clearly indicated today from his own experience on the indigenous education and training front—and I know he has also been there to look first-hand at the Hamersley experience—we have some prime examples now which clearly demonstrate how it can be done. We should be taking that experience beyond Hamersley and the Pilbara to assist in other difficult areas of indigenous education.

I therefore also want to refer briefly this afternoon to another important pathway on which I believe we have much work to do. It relates to opportunities for indigenous people to be trained in providing the growing service needs of their communities. If anything, it is about taking employment and training back into local communities. We know as a community that there will be growth in the demand for health, education, welfare and community development services, but we do not yet have in place a strategy to ensure that indigenous Australians build local capacities to provide these services in their own communities. Some attempts, I think it is fair to say, have been made in indigenous health, but the approach surely has broader application than indigenous health. Our training framework has been slow to adapt to the needs of indigenous people and indigenous communities. Community work apprenticeship options need to be pursued more vigorously in cooperation with indigenous communities.

Moving on, we should not forget the barriers facing those indigenous students who have successfully completed year 12. We are all aware that achieving a year 12 qualification is, for indigenous people, something to be exceptionally proud of. Indeed, it is something we are all exceptionally proud of with respect to our own children. We therefore have a responsibility to ensure that those indigenous children who actually achieve year 12 have the opportunity to further develop their potential for employment or further education.

The literature emphasises the multiple disadvantages experienced by indigenous youth, including low educational attainment, issues of speaking English as a second language or dialect, and how English literacy levels count. When young indigenous people manage to overcome these barriers we should express as a community our pride in them. Their families and their communities are entitled to celebrate their achievements in the same way in which we celebrated Cathy Freeman's achievement on the sporting field last week. We need role models in indigenous education in the same way as we need indigenous achievers on the sporting field. It is up to government to recognise and promote those who achieve in indigenous education equally with those from the indigenous community who achieve on our sporting fields. I simply suggest to the House this afternoon that more has to be done when it comes to recognition and promotion in expressing our pride in the achievements of our indigenous people in the education field.

There have been changes in the Australian labour market in recent decades that have made life more difficult for young indigenous people who do not find work. Employed indigenous youth are often concentrated, unfortunately, at the lower end of the labour market in part-time, low paid and insecure employment. They often still suffer from discrimination in employment practices. Geographic isolation also contributes to the disadvantage experienced by indigenous youth. In places that lack employment opportunities, CDEP offers a valuable source of employment for indigenous people. Concerns have been raised in some quarters that indigenous youth may move into CDEP in preference to completing secondary school. But the more important concern with CDEP is the difficulty in accessing accredited training modules. We as a community need to be more serious about developing CDEP as a pathway, not merely as something to do—as has all too often become the end result of CDEP in some communities.

However, I am also going to suggest to the House today that the most successful CDEP projects have access to training, and there are also innovative approaches that use the pathway from CDEP to get from community based employment to private sector employment. Unfortunately, in doing so, I need to also point out that the Howard government has not yet fully grasped the potential of this approachand it shows no sign of doing so, which is more unfortunate.

One disturbing finding from the research is that, even when educational attainment was the same for a non-indigenous person and an indigenous person in a similar geographic location, employment opportunities for indigenous youth were poorer. We know that educational outcomes are affected by family, school and community environment. Getting families and communities behind the learning experience is critical to improving indigenous education outcomes. We know this, but where is the policy framework which reflects this challenge?

Clearly there is evidence of positive outcomes from programs for indigenous students in terms of engagement in learning, workplaces and communities. The challenge we have is to apply those lessons more broadly—to actually take and extend them from those successful communities to other communities that have the same challenges.

But, as we are also aware, overcoming disadvantage in indigenous education requires a commitment. Skills and capabilities are the future for all Australians—not just some Australians. For indigenous Australians, they also offer something very important: recognition. For indigenous Australians, skills improve the chance to progress their own lives, the lives of their families and the quality of life in their communities. At the same time, we have to face up to our other obligations. Indigenous Australians often lack access to basic health care and housing, and many live in conditions that many of us would only describe as `abject poverty'. We cannot deny that these environmental factors affect the learning experiences of our indigenous kids.

With this bill, the government has once again unfortunately chosen to mislead the public on the level of funding for indigenous literacy. Consistent with its broad philosophy, the government has shifted indigenous education funding away from students in government schools. We have many challenges, and I hope that the amount of time this House has spent debating indigenous issues in recent times will be reflected in future budget allocations. I look forward to the day when the Howard government's budgetary commitment to indigenous Australians comes near to matching some of its claimed concern. That is not the case with this bill, and I suspect it will not be the case in the future.

But this is just not about funding; it is about a commitment to develop new policy solutions. As I have travelled around Australia, I have observed that there are communities developing their own local solutions in the areas of indigenous education and employment; there are committed people working hard to improve the appalling situation we face. But what they feel they are lacking is a federal government that is prepared to back them; they lack a federal government that is prepared to be on their side. That is the feeling of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians alike. As a result of this debate, I hope not only that we consider the issue of indigenous education in the form it is in the current bill before the House but also that we actually take on board some of the success stories that have been referred to by both sides of the House in this debate—and that we work out how they can become more the order of the day rather than the exception to the rule when it comes to indigenous education.
Debate (on motion by Ms Worth) adjourned.

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —On the evening of Tuesday, 12 September 2000, my daughter and several of her friends, along with hundreds of others, gathered outside Crown Casino in Melbourne to peacefully demonstrate against the World Economic Forum meeting. The atmosphere among protesters was positive and non-violent. Into this peaceful scene at around 8 p.m. came riot police, armed with extra-long batons and wearing helmets and visors. They outnumbered protesters by two to one. The riot police charged the protesters, without warning or provocation. At no time during the many hours my daughter spent at the World Economic Forum protest did she see anyone throw objects at police or behave violently towards them. The police still charged. The officers—the overwhelming majority without identification—launched themselves at the crowd and began to relentlessly beat and punch the protesters with fists and batons, aiming for their heads and faces.

speech.para: Mounted officers then attacked from behind, forcing protesters forward into the line of police who were armed with batons. Protesters who were forced to the ground were trampled by horses, police and other protesters. Police lashed out at everyone in their path, beating many violently. Many protesters were trapped in the crush caused by the police, and attempts to escape were met with further violence. Police hit retreating protesters with batons. One friend of my daughter was hit repeatedly across his back and legs as he tried to escape the violence. Another was hit in the head by police trying to break up the protest and consequently suffered headaches and dizziness for days afterwards. Police were merciless and brutal in their treatment of the peaceful protesters. More frighteningly, the majority of officers who perpetrated this violence were not wearing identification.

At the end of this charge, more than 30 demonstrators were hospitalised, and countless others suffered minor injuries as a result of the police baton charge. These injuries were not necessarily physical. Fortunately, my daughter was not assaulted—only manhandled by police—but she has been scarred by the experience, even now becoming upset when watching television footage of the charge. She is haunted by the sound of the boots of the riot police marching down to attack her. The shock of seeing one human being—an Australian—mercilessly beating another was a very depressing, disheartening and distressing experience for her. Any respect for the Victoria Police and its members has vanished.

Not only is it the police that we have lost faith in but Steve Bracks, the Victorian Premier, described protesters as `fascists' and `un-Australian' and said they `deserve everything they got'. Is this a Labor Premier? Do he and I really share the same ideals? I am ashamed of him, and I am not alone. I condemn Bracks's endorsement of the police violence against protesters at the WEF. For Bracks to be uttering the same word—`un-Australian'—as Richard Court is a damning indictment of the Victorian Premier. Is this what ALP supporters in Victoria have fought so long for: the replacement of Jeff Kennett with `Jeff' Bracks?

Bracks praised police for an `absolutely outstanding' job on 12 September. What part did he find outstanding? The unannounced baton charge? The failure of police to wear identification? The inability of protestors to identify police and hold them accountable for their actions? The response to alleged individual acts of violence by protestors with violence against the demonstration as a whole? Police were entitled to enforce the law by making arrests using only reasonable force, and they were duty-bound to use minimum force only. However, on 12 September, police were aiming not to arrest but rather to overcome through overwhelming force. As police attacked, my daughter heard them shout repeatedly to protestors, `You're going to get hurt. You're going to get hurt.' In contrast, protestors chanted, `No violence, no violence.'

The role of the police force in our society is primarily to bring people before the courts so they can be judged and punished. Police have no right to dish out punishment themselves. Given that the Victorian Premier has endorsed violence against demonstrators, what are the implications for people's rights in Victoria? Will union members and workers be safe from police brutality the next time they are on a picket line? A citizen who is engaged in civil disobedience is a citizen nonetheless, and he or she is entitled to the protection of the law. Demonstrators outside the WEF had the right to protest and congregate in a public place without the fear of being beaten up. Importantly, they also had the right to be able to identify those police who assaulted them. In a democratic society, it is crucial that police, as an arm of government, are accountable. The behaviour of Steve Bracks and the Victorian parliamentary Labor Party over the last month has been a disgrace. The Victorian government must now fully support the independent inquiry into the police violence against protestors and return to the principles of democracy and accountability that got it elected last year. As protesters chanted throughout the three-day protest, `The whole world is watching.'

talk.start.para: —Let me cast a rather different light on the rose-coloured view the member for Franklin has of the activities of those protestors. As our nation basks in the afterglow of the Sydney Olympic Games, we can reflect quite rightly on the profile that Australia and Australians have been able to present to a worldwide audience. Not just in the sporting sphere, where the extraordinary feats of our athletes were applauded, but in other spheres, there will be other images etched into the minds of the international community, those of an idyllic country filled with friendly people with a positive, progressive outlook, a sophisticated approach to technology and a healthy, growing economy—a country of enormous potential. It was an unparalleled opportunity to showcase contemporary Australia to the world as a modern, exciting and socially cohesive nation. Yet only a matter of days before Australia stepped on to the world stage, just days before the pageantry and magic of the opening ceremony of what were to be the best games ever, the international community was treated to an ugly, strident view of Australia in the form of the protests at the 2000 Asian Economic Summit of the World Economic Forum held in Melbourne.

speech.para: Yes, we live in a democracy. We have democratic rights to freedom of expression and with those the right to protest and the right to congregate. But, when the tactics of the S11 and its assorted constituency, comprising the S11 alliance, led to the detention of the elected political leader of a state, the Premier of Western Australia, and in the democratic federation of this country he is held hostage while protestors wreck his vehicle, then such protestors forfeit their right to protest. I must say, even though the member for Franklin has left the chamber, their actions must be and have been condemned by all right-thinking members of the community, and I add my voice to that condemnation. Physical confrontations, the use of violence and the deliberate tactic of preventing delegates and the media from attending the summit were simply deplorable behaviour. Those claiming the right to free speech deliberately prevented others from exercising the same right. While these protesters say that they will continue their antiglobalisation, antitrade, pro-environment cause, however misguided and mistaken they are in much of what they stand for—

talk.start.para: —They are not mistaken.
—The member for Franklin has been heard in silence and will extend the same courtesy.

—They should acknowledge that only peaceful protests will win any credibility in this country. I say that they are misguided in their attacks on the WEF, for since its formation as a meeting of European CEOs in 1971 the World Economic Forum has increasingly integrated political, economic, social and environmental issues into its activities. The mere convening of its meetings in various countries over the past two decades has heralded substantial benefits to the economic reform policies of such countries: to China after the Beijing symposium in 1979, to India in 1985, to central and eastern European countries, to the former USSR, and to Latin America in 1995, heralding its entry into the world economy when the first Mercosur economic summit was held in Sao Paulo. The basic philosophy of the World Economic Forum is that the greatest challenges facing humankind in the next century can be met only through the joint efforts of governments and business, and the meetings are the best opportunity for a truly global representation of business, governments, media, academia and civil society—people who are committed to improving the state of the world—to come together to discuss key political, economic and social issues.

speech.para: What the protestors refuse to see is that globalisation is not a barrier to equality; it is a necessity. Entrepreneurship and capitalism can be the basis for economic and, ultimately, social progress—entrepreneurship or capitalism in the framework of social responsibility. Globalisation in the form of free trade, access to technology, access to new ideas and innovation, open markets and access to new markets can lead to incredible opportunities not only for developed countries but for developing countries—opportunities for jobs, for investment, for sustained economic growth and for better living standards. The facts cannot be ignored. As the Prime Minister said in his keynote address to the summit in Melbourne on 11 September, `Globalisation has been a ticket to prosperity for many nations.' Contrary to the claims by critics of globalisation, all of the benefits of economic growth do not immediately accrue to the wealthy. The opening up of an economy to world trade raises the income of the poor by raising overall growth and incomes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In the past few years, much has been written and spoken about the stolen generation. I have been moved by so many stories I have heard and read, but I have found none so moving as one which recently came to my attention. The story of Valerie Wenberg Linow, who is now living in the Fowler electorate, is one of the many that can be told. Valerie shared her early life, tragic as it appears to us now, with many hundreds of other members of the stolen generation. One of nine children, she was taken from her home near Grafton in New South Wales at the age of two. Her early years were spent at the Bomaderry Children's Home. Later, she was taken to the Cootamundra Girls Home, where her three elder sisters had been taken earlier. Her three brothers had been taken to Kinchela Boys Home near Kempsey.

speech.para: From Cootamundra, Valerie was placed in domestic service, from which she fled after being raped and beaten by her employer. She has spent much of the time since then unable to reconcile her removal from her home, the tragic consequences for her brothers and sisters, and her at times brutal upbringing in the institutions responsible for her care. Valerie felt that she could not take part in the National Sorry Day earlier this year. She believed that healing was impossible for her. With the support of friends, she was persuaded to make the bridge walk on the day. The event affected her greatly, and she says:

quote.para: I looked up at the `sorry' in the sky and around at the thousands of people. Tears flowed down my cheeks and I have found healing.

speech.para: Since then, this remarkable woman has told her story to many people, and her involvement with the National Sorry Day Committee led to my meeting with her recently. At our meeting, I was moved by the depth of the tragedy which had struck her and her family. In reconstructing her life, Valerie has put together a folio of documents and photographs which confirm the details of her early life. Among the class photos of Cootamundra Primary School is a photograph of a couple and a young baby. Valerie has no memory of her parents and the photograph is her only link with them. The picture, taken in the early 1940s, shows Valerie's mother dressed neatly and wearing a sunhat, as if she had attended her baby's christening. Valerie's father stands holding the baby. He is dressed in the uniform of a soldier of the Second AIF—his slouch hat worn proudly, as it is in so many photographs of that era. When you look at the photograph, you cannot help but wonder how her father felt. Valerie can recall two occasions when she saw her father as he attempted to contact her. Both times he was taken away by the police. While he served his country in time of war, his own family was taken from their home. His young children were split up and subjected to years of abuse and torment in institutions.

Valerie Linow's story shows the hypocrisy of those who cannot bring themselves to say sorry to the stolen generation. We show great respect for those men and women who served our country in time of war. While they take pride in their heroic deeds and express gratitude for their sacrifice, they refuse to acknowledge the hurt and suffering caused by the misdeeds of others acting in the service of government. They cannot say sorry for the misdeeds of the agents of government who were responsible for the stolen generation. The process of reconciliation has helped Valerie Linow to begin her healing, but it is a long process. Valerie beautifully expresses her sorrow:

quote.para: No wind or dust could dry my mother's tears as we were torn apart ...
Yes, I know today if she was here she would say: `My daughter we made the rivers you see today
Our tear drops are proof of the flowing waters
No wind and dust can dry my tears.'

speech.para: Valerie Linow and her husband, Warren, are in the gallery this evening. I understand Valerie has today told her story to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Valerie, I admire you, I respect you and I say to you—as my parents, Alan and Lois Welsh, have always said to me—never, ever give up the good fight. Very shortly there will be a Prime Minister who can say sorry for the wrongs of past governments.

subdebateinfo.title: Robertson Electorate: Olympic and Paralympic Games
Robertson Electorate: Netball Childflight Appeal

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to add my congratulations to the millions of people who have offered congratulations to the athletes and the organisers of the Sydney 2000 Olympics—and particularly to the over 40,000 volunteers that made the games such a success. I am privileged in that my electorate is only some 40 minutes away from the Olympic site, so I had the opportunity to visit the Olympics on a number of occasions. I see the Minister for Finance and Administration at the table: the Hon. John Fahey had a great deal to do with getting the Sydney Olympics and I am sure he was heartened as well to see that they were so successful.

speech.para: I was impressed with the transport arrangements. I drove from the Central Coast to the Hornsby railway station, caught the train in and walked the 20 minutes to Concord West. It was a great opportunity to meet many people from all over the world—in fact, I think I met more of my own constituents there. Certainly the city of Gosford was quite empty for those two weeks as many people made the journey. It was a great success. It was a great opportunity to profile what is good about Australia. One of the lasting successes of the games and one of the great achievements will be the reinforcement of the positive feeling for people in Australia who sometimes like to knock their own country. I have never seen so many Australians so proud and so happy to recognise that they are Australians and that we have a great country.

I would also like to pay tribute to the Paralympians. On this the day the Paralympic torch was lit in Canberra—and it will be travelling around Australia—I would urge all Australians to make the same efforts to visit the Paralympic Games that they made for the Olympics, to have an opportunity to watch these magnificent athletes compete on the world stage.

I would also urge many people to get out, have a look at and support the Paralympic flame as it travels around Australia. I am certainly urging the people of the Central Coast to come out and support the Paralympic flame as it travels around. It will be travelling to many areas that the Olympic flame did not travel to. Certainly it will be in the Woy Woy peninsula area—Woy Woy, Adelong and the Umina area down to the village of Patonga. They missed out on seeing the Olympic flame travel around the coast. The Paralympic flame will be travelling to those areas over the next couple of weeks and I would urge all the residents of my electorate, particularly those in those areas, to make an effort to come out to support the Paralympic flame as it travels around and then heads to Homebush for what I know will be the best ever Paralympic Games.

I mentioned earlier in my speech the efforts of the volunteers that made the games so successful. In fact, volunteers in our community and other people who give up their time freely make Australia what it is. The level of services that we have in this country could never be provided by any government without the contribution of volunteers. I would also like to raise tonight the recent efforts of some volunteers on the Central Coast. There was a netball match organised to raise money for Childflight, the helicopter rescue service that is so valuable to our community. It was organised by two young ladies, Corinne Garland and Monique Kassi, obviously netball players, who wanted to do something to raise money for Childflight, so they organised a six-hour marathon netball game. I went along to the game and I thought they would probably play 40 minutes on and have 40-minute rests, but I can assure you they did not. They had 40-minute games, had about a five-minute rest and then kept playing. Throughout the day they actually scored 382 goals between the two teams, which were made up of netball players from the Central Coast and also volunteers from the Childflight organisation who competed in the game. There was also a charity netball game in which I was a participant over the lunchbreak, and I can assure you that was some sight.
